Accepted as Trioceros schoutedeni in Tilbury and Tolley (2009). This species overlaps in distribution with T. rudis and is morphologically similar, resulting in confusion between the two species. Where the two species co-occur, it is not possible to determine which records belong to T. schoutedeni and which to T. rudis. It differs from T. rudis mainly on the basis of a much reduced gular, and ventral crest.
Accepted as Rhampholeon boulengeri, but the wide but disjunct distribution could suggest this is a species complex (Tilbury 2010).

This species was referred to the new genus Trioceros by Tilbury and Tolley (2009). Its taxonomy is somewhat complex, as a number of subspecies have been described and their validity challenged (see Tilbury 2010 for a summary), and the status of records from Kenya, Tanzania, South Sudan and the Democratic Republic of Congo (outside Kivu Province) is in need of verification. These records are provisionally assigned to "Trioceros rudis incertae sedis" by Tilbury (2010) and are consequently not included in this assessment pending taxonomic investigation. Records from Ethiopia may represent confusion with T. bitaeniatus (Tilbury et al. 2010) and are not considered here. Trioceros sternfeldi, previously considered a subspecies of T. rudis, is now considered a full species. The population from Aberdares National Park in Kenya, previously also considered to belong to T. rudis (Tilbury 2010), has been described as T. kinangopensis (Stipala et al. 2012). Finally, records of T. rudis from the Albertine Rift region make up the bulk of this species occurrence, but in general they are of uncertain status and may not be T. rudis sensu stricto - unless they come from the Rwenzori  Mountains, which is the type locality of T. rudis.
Accepted as Chamaeleo gracilis in Tilbury and Tolley (2009).
Some records from the western portion of this lizard's range may be confused with Chamaeleo senegalensis (Tilbury 2010, Trape et al. 2012).
Accepted as Kinyongia xenorhina in Tilbury et al. (2006, 2007).

Tilbury and Tolley (2009) elevated the former subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) to generic rank.The combined molecular and morphological analysis of Barej et al. (2010) necessitated major taxonomic changes to this taxon, and these authors elevated the subspecies T. w. perreti to species rank and removed T. serratus from synonymy. The correct assignment of one record close to the north Manengouba Mountains (Gounwouo et al. 2006) is uncertain, as this may represent either T. wiedersheimi or T. perreti (Barej et al. 2010). T. serratus is difficult to distinguish morphologically from T. wiedersheimi, and the distributional limits of these two taxa are in need of resolution (Barej et al. 2010).
Accepted as Kinyongia carpenteri in Tilbury and Tolley (2009).

Tilbury and Tolley (2009) elevated the former subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) to generic rank. Two morphologically distinct subspecies, corresponding to a northern and southern distribution within the Cameroon mountain chain, are traditionally recognized, the southern T. q. quadricornis (Mertens 1968) and northern T. q. gracilior (Barej et al. 2010). Molecular data supports this division, although suggests a very recent split between these taxa (Barej et al. 2010). Klaver and Böhme (1992) suggest that the assignment of Mt Kupe specimens to T. q. quadricornis requires verification, and that these records may in fact represent a separate, isolated lineage. Barej et al. (2010) also supported the finding by Pook and Wild (1997) that the morphologically divergent and geographically disjunct Eisentraut's chameleon (T. eisentrauti) should be treated as a subspecies of T. quadricornis on molecular grounds, and formally made this change. Accepted as Trioceros quadricornis in Tolley and Herrel (2014) and Glaw (2015). Glaw (2015) recognizes three subspecies: Trioceros quadricornis quadricornis, Trioceros quadricornis eisentrauti, and Trioceros quadricornis gracilior.
The subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) was elevated to generic rank by Tilbury and Tolley (2009). Accepted as Trioceros pfefferi in Tilbury and Tolley (2009), Tolley and Herrel (2014), and Glaw (2015).
Accepted as Trioceros johnstoni in Tilbury and Tolley (2009).

Accepted as Kinyongia adolfifriderici in Tilbury and Tolley (2009), however there is considerable uncertainty with the taxonomic status of many populations (Greenbaum et al. 2012). The recent recognition that Kinyongia gyrolepis, a "superficially similar" species, is a sister taxon to Ugandan K. adolfifriderici, renders K. adolfifriderici as paraphyletic (Greenbaum et al. (2012).  

The type locality, "Irumu-Mavambi Urwald", provided by Sternfeld (1912) is considered vague, as Irumu and Mavambi (now Mawambi) are separate localities around 150 km apart along the Ituri River (Greenbaum et al. 2012), in the Orientale Province of the Democratic Republic of Congo. Both sites are however in areas of historical lowland rainforest, and this and other historical collections, from Medje and from "lowland and montane" areas of Rwanda and Uganda (Greenbaum et al. 2012 and references therein), show that the species occurs in lowland rainforest. The only recent records are from Afromontane forests in the Albertine Rift. Given that recent studies suggest the presence of multiple taxa within K. adolfifriderici, it is possible that lowland and montane populations belong to different species. Should this be the case, the name K. adolfifriderici would be applicable to the lowland populations conspecific with material from Ituri (Greenbaum et al. 2012). Furthermore, the isolated montane forest fragments along the Albertine Rift (e.g. Bwindi Forest, Nyungwe Forest) may house additional cryptic species.

Tilbury and Tolley (2009) elevated the former subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros), of which T. oweni is the type species, to generic rank. Accepted as Trioceros oweni in Tolley and Herrel (2014) and Glaw (2015). The southern form was originally described as Chamaeleon unicornis and was differentiated by males having either no or reduced pre-orbital horns. This form was later considered a subspecies, but was synonomized and is regarded as a variant of T. oweni (Tilbury 2010).

The genus Amietina Cambefort was only described in 1981 and now comprises four species (ScarabNet 2009). The relatively recent discovery of Amietina larrochei probably owes to its small-body size, forest distribution, and probable specialized habits.

The taxonomy of Chamaelo dilepis, which may instead be a species complex, is uncertain and problematic (Largen and Spawls 2006). Pending resolution of this situation, Chamaeleo quilensis from Central and East Africa are here treated as "sporadic variants of Ch. dilepis" following Tilbury (2010). The name Chamaeleo ruspolii has historically been applied to a morphologically uniform population from Somalia and northern Ethiopia, however, broader geographical sampling within the range of C. dilepis indicates that C. ruspolii is likely to fall within the range of natural variation in C. dilepis, and moreover that it appears to represent the northern end of a spectrum of intergradation, with southern Ethiopian populations exhibiting characters intermediate between "C. ruspolii" to the north and East African C. dilepis (Largen and Spawls 2006).

Although some authors still recognize the form C. d. quilensis as well as subspecies (C.d. roperi Boulenger 1890, C. d. idjwiensis Loveridge, 1942, C. d. isabellinus Günther 1893, C. d. martensi Mertens, 1964 and C. d. petersi Gray, 1865), these should be treated with extreme caution pending a full taxonomic review of this species. Considerable confusion in identifications as well as complete overlap for sub-species records exist. Recognition of these subspecies at this time over-inflates the taxonomic quotient and unnecessarily complicates the situation (Tilbury 2010).



[[Taxonomic Notes for South African Regional Assessment - relevant parts can be incorporated into the global Taxonomic Notes above as required and this section can then be deleted:
A number of subspecies of C. dilepis (C. d. dilepis, C. d. idjwiensis, C. d. isabellinus, C. d. martensi, C. d. petersii, C. d. ruspolii) are recognized, partly due to morphological variation across the species' very large geographic range (Klaver and Böhme 1997, Neças 2004). The validity of these subspecies is unclear and a detailed taxonomic revision of the species complex would be useful. A preliminary phylogenetic analysis indicates there are multiple species within this complex, even within South Africa (Main et al. 2018). Included in the C. dilepis species complex are the extralimital species C. roperi and C. quilensis, but their taxonomic status also requires investigation. Tilbury (2010) considers all of the above-mentioned taxa, as well as C. angusticoronatus, as variants of a polymorphic C. dilepis.

Only one subspecies is present in South Africa, Lesotho and Eswatini, namely C. d. dilepis., however, a recent molecular study suggests that the South African subspecies may actually constitute two separate taxa (Main et al. 2018).]]
O. brachyantha A. Chev. & Roehr. is tertiary wild relative of rice (O. sativa L.) and African rice (O. glaberrima Steud.) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2017).
O. glaberrima Steud. is a cultivated rice speces (African rice) and is also a primary wild relative of cultivated rice (Asia rice) (O. sativa L.).
O. barthii A. Chev. is a primary wild relative of rice (O. sativa L.) and African rice (O. glaberrima Steud.).
O. eichingeri Peter is a secondary wild relative of cultivated rice (O. sativa L.) and African rice (O. glaberrima Steud.) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2017).

This species was treated as belonging to Arthroleptis adolfifriederici prior to its formal description (Perret, 1966; Amiet, 1975). Confusion may also have occurred with A. variabilis (Blackburn et al. 2009).
It may be a synonym of Lutjanus dentatus.

Mesoprion retrospinis Valenciennes, 1830 may be the oldest name for this species as the original description agrees closely to that given by Delais, 1952. There are some taxonomic problems with the correct name for this species.
Also listed as Arius gambensis (junior synonym).
This species was proposed by Harms, later transferred to the current genus by Dunn (Kew Bulletin 1911: 362-364) who revised it there. Subsequent authors have all accepted this as a good species.

J.B. Gillett in his key and notes to the genus (Kew Bulletin 14: 464-467 (1960)) remarks: "no specimen has been seen: it is difficult from the description only to assess the importance in the indumentum of the leaves which alone seems to separate this species from P. pulchrum."

Memecylon alipes is an evergreen rainforest shrub or small tree 5-7 m high with clusters of rose-pink flowers.The young branchlets and peduncles are strongly quadrangular-alate, the wings 1-1.5 mm wide. Leaves are ovate-oblong or elliptic-oblong, 17-22.5 x 5.5-7 cm with a narrow acumen 1-2 cm long.

It was described in the field notes of Bos 6940 (type) collection from Kribi as " Shrub or small tree up to 12m high, usually 3-5m high, ashen stem and branches, twigs dull pale green, leaves thinly coriaceous, smooth, rather glaucous green above, pale green and densely reticulate below, peduncle and bract pale green, pedicels blue, calyx pinkish white in old flowers, corolla and stamen not seen, developing fruit vividly bright purple and depressed globose, crowned by similar coloured calyx lobes.

Warneckea ngutiensis is a forest undershrub to 1.5 m tall. Flowers are borne in axillary fascicles, with purple petals. The stamens have purple filaments; anthers yellow. It is unique in its species group in lacking oil glands in the flower (R.D. Stone pers. comm. 2011)
There are no taxonomic issues at present, although this species can be confused with female Trioceros montium (Tilbury 2010).

The subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) was elevated to generic rank by Tilbury and Tolley (2009). Barej et al. (2010) elevated the former subspecies to species rank based on molecular and morphological differences from the nominate taxon. Accepted as Trioceros perreti in Tolley and Herrel (2014) and Glaw (2015).

Tilbury and Tolley (2009) elevated the former subgenus Chamaeleo (Trioceros) to generic rank. Mertens (1940) synonymized Chamaeleon (=Chamaeleo) serratus within Chamaeleo wiedersheimi on the basis that specimens examined, including those from the Bamenda Highlands, were indistinguishable from a C. wiedersheimi paratype from the same locality. This view was subsequently supported with reference to additional material and the original description (Mertens 1968, Klaver and Böhme 1992). The holotype of C. serratus, with the unspecific locality "Südkamerun", is lost, and was probably destroyed during World War II (Klaver and Böhme 1992), so has never been available for comparison. Combined morphological and molecular research by Barej et al. (2010) found that Bamenda specimens belong to a clade separate from Trioceros wiedersheimi. Designating a neotype for T. serratus, these authors therefore resurrected this name for the newly-recognized species, fixing the type locality as Belo, Mt Oku, and removed it from synonymy with T. wiedersheimi. The two species are, however, difficult to distinguish morphologically, and the distributional limits of these two taxa are in need of resolution (Barej et al. 2010).

Warneckea wildeana is a small tree 8 to 10 m tall. The leaves are elliptic, 20 x 9 cm, with a 1.5 cm acumen and 1 cm petioles. The inflorescences, with 16-20 flowers each, appear as small cushions, 3-4 cm wide on older leafless stems.

Includes B. jussiaecarpa Warb. of Flora of West Tropical Africa. This species, of sect. Tetraphila A.DC. is closely related to B. preussii and can be regarded as an altitudinal vicariant (information on these species provided by Marc Sosef and Hans De Wilde, Wageningen).

This species has been considered by some botanists to be conspecific with Afrocarpus falcatus in South Africa, but these species are not only geographically separated but also distinct in several, albeit minor, morphological characters and are maintained as separate species here following Farjon (2010).
Synonym = Oreacanthus mannii Benth.

The species as assessed here is probably a species complex comprising multiple species. The true Dalbergia oligophylla may be a highland species which dries a distinctive black. Specimens from lower altitudes and lowland forest habitats probably represent different species.

Coffea bakossii occurs in the same geographic area as C. montekupensis and C. liberica and related taxa (Davis et al. 2006, Davis et al. 2011). It is a wild relative of commercial coffee species, C. arabica and C. canephora (Vincent et al. 2013) and the minor crop species C. liberica (Davis et al. 2011). The species is classified in Gene Pool 2 for both species, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).

The African Nile Crocodile is now recognized as two distinct species: one occupying eastern Africa, the Nile valley and southern Africa and retaining the name Crocodylus niloticus Laurenti, 1768; and the other occupying west and central Africa, including the Congo, Niger and Ogoue drainages and assigned to the existing name Crocodylus suchus Geoffroy, 1807 (Schmitz et al. 2003, Hekkala et al. 2011).  Red List assessments now treat these two taxa independently.

We consider this species to be confined to central and eastern Africa; we follow J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.) in considering records from Cameroon to belong to another, possibly undescribed, species. J.C. Poynton (pers. comm.) considers that animals from Kenya and Tanzania are probably specifically distinct from true A. adolfifriederici in Rwanda, Burundi, Uganda and Democratic Republic of Congo. The name leleupi is available for Tanzanian and Kenyan animals. There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

Arthroleptis lonnbergi was removed from the synonymy of Arthroleptis stenodactylus by Pickersgill (2007). However, the species was synonymized again under Arthroleptis stenodactylus by Blackburn (2010 in Frost 2013). Current systematic work is expected to result in recognizing some populations currently assigned to Arthroleptis stenodactylus as two or more distinct species (D. Blackburn pers. comm. October 2015).
This is a restricted concept following the split of the broader concept into this and Sclerophrys pusillus (Poynton et al. 2016).

This form is a complex of more than one species, probably comprising several species (M.-O. Rödel pers comm.). In many parts of its range, the distinction between this species and Hemisus marmoratus is not clear. Ongoing taxonomic work (by de Sá and colleagues) will result in reshaping our knowledge of cryptic species richness and distributions of populations currently assigned to Hemisus marmoratus and H. guineensis.

It is possible that the subspecies Hemisus marmoratus sudanensis constitutes a separate species (Rödel 2000). This species is probably a complex comprising several species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.). Ongoing taxonomic work (by de Sá and colleagues) will result in reshaping our knowledge of cryptic diversity and distributions of populations currently assigned to Hemisus marmoratus and Hemisus guineensis. In several parts of its range, this species is not readily distinguishable from Hemisus guineensis.
Although this species has often been confused with Leptopelis kivuensis (see Schiøtz 1999), Roelke et al. (2011) clarified the difference between the two species.
This is a complex of several species (Portillo et al. 2015)

Recent DNA and morphological studies suggest that this species belongs in its own monotypic genus, Mecistops (McAliley et al. 2006).  This finding has been supported by all subsequent phylogenetic studies (e.g., Hekkala et al. 2011, Meredith 2011, Oaks 2011,Shirley et al. 2013) and Mecistop has gained wide use and acceptance in the literature and is hence used here.

A recent study (Shirley 2013, Shirley et al. 2013) has found significant molecular and morphological support for two divergent taxa in this genus - one distributed entirely in West Africa and the other in Central Africa. Formal taxonomic revisions and recognition of these two unique taxa are expected soon.

The taxonomic status of this species in relation to Phrynobatrachus parvulus and P. ukingensis requires clarification (Poynton and Broadley 1985b). It is likely to represent more than one species based on molecular evidence (S. Loader pers. comm. Nov 2012). Zimkus et al. (2010) noted that nominal Phrynobatrachus mababiensis covers two distantly related species.
This form almost certainly consists of a number of cryptic species (Rödel 2000).

This species is one of a group of cryptic species resembling Xenopus fraseri but which is distinguished from it by chromosome number (2n = 72) and a mating call of a single note (found elsewhere within the genus only in X. borealis).

Uniquely among vertebrates (except Xenopus eysoole, X. kobeli and X. ruwenzoriensis), this is a dodecaploid species, and it is therefore of considerable scientific interest. It was probably formed by both hybridization and polyploidization (Loumont and Kobel 1991).
This species is part of a complex of poorly understood species closely related to Xenopus laevis.

The status of Phrynobatrachus hailiensis Meek and Eliot, 1897 from northern Somalia remains obscure. It is usually considered to be a synonym of this species, but its type locality falls far outside the otherwise known range of Ptychadena oxyrhynchus, and so it is not included here, pending further investigation of its status.
We treat this as a species distinct from Ptychadena pumilio, following Poynton and Broadley (1985).

Tomopterna kachowskii and T. elegans have been removed from synonymy with this species (Zimkus and Larson 2011). This species still requires taxonomic research to understand its full distribution and status, particularly subpopulations in Zaire (Zimkus and Larson 2011).

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. This is likely to be a complex of several species (V. Gvozdik pers.comm. Nov 2012). In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology. J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.) considers that Artholeptis adelphus might be a synonym of A. tuberosus.

This species was historically listed under the family Rhinolophidae. Taxonomic revision is required as Hipposideros caffer is considered a species complex (Kock et al. 2008). Three subspecies have been listed by Simmons (2005), including: H. c. angolensis Seabra, 1898; H. c. nanus J.A. Allen, 1917; and H. c. tephrus Cabrera, 1906. Vallo et al. (2008) recognises several species lineages within the caffer-ruber complex throughout Africa, and assign southern African populations to H. c. caffer. The presence of multiple cryptic species in this caffer-ruber complex is supported by Monadjem et al. (2013). Molecular data are required to resolve the taxonomy.
The taxonomic relationship between Hipposideros curtus and H. vittatus is unclear and needs further investigation.
The relationship between Hirthia and Lavigeria is under discussion. Species in this genus may be members of the Lavigeria clade (E. Michel, pers. comm.).
The relationship between Hirthia and Lavigeria is under discussion. Species in this genus may be members of the Lavigeria clade (E. Michel, pers. comm.).
No synonyms or subspecies of Kinixys homeana have been described, and no geographic variation is known.

The taxonomy of Lavigera is currently under large-scale revision. Existing taxonomy (Brown 1994) recognizes only two species (L. grandis and L. nassa), however revision (Michel and Todd, in prep.) will include approximately 43 species. Included here are a few of the name-bearing taxa whose names (from older literature, but not always consistently applied) have been used in relatively recent literature and are included in West et al. (2003). West et al. 2003 includes 20 Lavigera species, Michel et al. 2004 includes 28 species. Extensive ecological information is available on a number of Lavigera species, especially in the Kigoma, Tanzani region. Lavigera grandis is a relatively well defined species and references to it are generally reliable, with the exception of a few confoundings with Lavigera coronata (e.g. Wilson et al. 2004) (E. Michel, pers. comm.)

The taxonomy of Lavigeria is currently under large-scale revision. Existing taxonomy (Brown 1994) recognizes only two species (L. grandis and L. nassa), however revision (Michel and Todd in prep) will include approximately 43 species. Included here are a few of the name-bearing taxa whose names (from older literature, but not always consistently applied) have been used in relatively recent literature and are included in West et al. (2003). West et al. 2003 includes 20 Lavigeria species, Michel et al. 2004 includes 28 species. Extensive ecological information is available on a number of Lavigeria species, especially in the Kigoma, Tanzania region. (E. Michel, pers. comm.)

Three elephant taxa remain from the sixteen elephant-like species that were found across the planet in the Pleistocene: Asian Elephant (Elephas maximus), African Savanna Elephant (Loxodonta africana africana), and African Forest Elephant (Loxodonta africana cyclotis) (Faurby and Svenning 2015, Malhi et al. 2016). The Asian and African ancestral lineages diverged approximately seven million years ago, and the African savanna and African forest ancestral lineages diverged approximately one million years later (Brandt et al. 2014, Roca et al. 2015, Rohland et al. 2010, Meyer et al. 2017, Palkopoulou et al. 2018). This and other recent genetic findings support the designation of two species of African elephant (i.e. Savanna and Forest) (Ishida et al. 2011, Mondol et al. 2015, Roca et al. 2007, Palkopoulou et al. 2018, Kim and Wasser 2019). However, two species have yet to be formally recognized by the IUCN in part because of known hybridization; the species designation is currently under review by the IUCN African Elephant Specialist Group.

Formerly placed by some in the genus Papio (Wolfheim, 1983), genetic analyses shows Mandrillus is more closely related to Cercocebus than to Papio (Disotell et al. 1992, Disotell 1994); morphological research concurs (Fleagle and McGraw 1999, McGraw and Fleagle 2006).  There are two subspecies: M. l. leucophaeus on the mainland, and M. l. poensis on Bioko (Zukowsky 1922).  Grubb et al. (2003) commented that on present evidence the two forms appear very similar.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Sudanonautes (Sudanonautes) aubryi aubryi. Cumberlidge (1994, 1997, 1998, 1999) revised the taxonomy of this taxon as the valid species Sudanonautes aubryi.
Bott (1955) treated this taxon as Potamonautes (Orthopotamonautes) depressus dybowskii (Rathbun, 1905). Cumberlidge (1998) and Cumberlidge and Tavares (2006) treated it as a valid species.
This species was described in 2000 and has not been collected since then.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Sudanonautes (Convexonautes) africanus chavanesii. Cumberlidge (1995, 1997, 1998, 1999) redescribed this species as Sudanonautes chavanesii.
Bott (1955) treated this taxon as Potamonautes (Lobopotamonautes) perparvus minor Bott, 1955. It is recognised here as the valid species Potamonautes minor.

This species was treated by Bott (1955) as Potamonautes (Erimetopus) brazzae brazzae. Its taxonomy was revised by Cumberlidge and Reed (2004) who treated it as Erimetopus brazzae, and this opinion is followed here.
Bott (1955) referred to this taxon as Potamonautes (Obesopotamonautes) langi. Cumberlidge (1998) treated this species as Potamonautes langi.
Bott (1955) referred to this taxon as Potamonautes (Tripotamonautes) walderi. Cumberlidge (1997, 1998) treated this species as Potamonautes walderi.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Sudanonautes (Convexonautes) africanus chaperi. Cumberlidge (1994, 1998, 1999) redescribed this species as Sudanonautes faradjensis.
Bott (1955) referred to this taxon as Potamonautes (Lobopotamonautes) perparvus perparvus. Cumberlidge (1998) treated this species as Potamonautes perparvus.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Sudanonautes (Sudanonautes) aubryi floweri. Cumberlidge (1995, 1997, 1998, 1999) revised the taxonomy of this taxon as the valid species Sudanonautes floweri.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Sudanonautes (Sudanonautes) decazei orthostylis Bott, 1955. Cumberlidge (1995; 1999) redescribed this species as Sudanonautes orthostylis.
This species was described by Cumberlidge and Clark (1992), and Cumberlidge (1993, 1998, 1999).
Bott (1955) described this taxon as Potamonautes (Longipotamonautes) ballayi acristatus. This taxon is recognised here as the valid species Potamonautes acristatus.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Rotundopotamonautes) loashiensis. This taxon is referred to here as Potamonautes loashiensis.
Bott (1955) referred to this taxon as Potamonautes (Platypotamonautes) ecorssei. Cumberlidge (1997, 1998, 1999) treated this species as Potamonautes ecorssei.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Lobopotamonautes) stanleyensis. It is listed here as Potamonautes stanleyensis.
Bott (1955) treated this species as a junior synonym of Potamonautes (Lobopotamonautes) aloysiisabaudiae. It is recognised here as the valid species Potamonautes congoensis.

Bott (1955) treated this species as Sudanonautes (Sudanonautes) africanus africanus. Cumberlidge (1995, 1997, 1998, 1999) revised the taxonomy of this taxon as the valid species Sudanonautes africanus.

Bott (1955) treated this species as Sudanonautes (Sudanonautes) decazei granulatus, a junior synonym of Sudanonautes (Sudanonautes) decazei decazei. Cumberlidge (1993, 1997, 1998, 1999) revised the taxonomy of this taxon as the valid species Sudanonautes granulatus.
This species was described by Cumberlidge (1993) with additional localities and ecological notes provided by Cumberlidge (1997, 1998, 1999).

Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Longipotamonautes) ballayi ballayi. This species is considered here to be Potamonautes ballayi. Bott (1955) included two subspecies with this species: Potamonautes (Longipotamonautes) ballayi adentatus Bott, 1955; and Potamonautes (Longipotamonautes) ballayi acristatus Bott, 1955. These subspecies are not recognised here.

Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Isopotamonautes) anchietae. This species was redescribed by Cumberlidge (1998) and Cumberlidge and Tavares (2006) as Potamonautes anchietae. The subspecies Potamonautes (Isopotamonautes) anchietae machadoi Bott, 1964 is treated here as a Species Inquirenda.
Bott (1955) referred to this taxon as Potamonautes (Longipotamonautes) paecilei. Cumberlidge (1997, 1998) treated this species as Potamonautes paecilei.

Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Potamonautes) bayonianus bayonianus. Cumberlidge (1997, 1998) and Cumberlidge and Tavares (2006) referred this species to Potamonautes bayonianus and the latter authors considered P. (P.) dubius jallae to be a junior synonym.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Sudanonautes (Convexonautes) aubryi monodi. Cumberlidge (1997, 1998, 1999) redescribed this species as Sudanonautes monodi.

This species was previously included under Hipposideros commersoni. However, H. commersoni is now considered endemic to Madagascar (Monadjem et al. 2010). It is likely that specimens in West Africa, identified as Hipposideros gigas, may in fact represent H. vittatus (J. Fahr pers. comm.). Taxonomic revision is required to clarify the relationship between H. vittatus and H. curtus (Mickleburgh et al. 2008), as well as between H. vittatus and H. gigas (Monadjem et al. 2010).

Grubb et al. (2003) treated this taxon as a subspecies of C. aethiops, but it is here listed as a distinct species (see C. aethiops for further details). Kingdon (1997), Groves (2001, 2005) and Nakagawa (2013) include this taxon in Chlorocebus and recognise three subspecies: C. t. tantalus, C. t. budgetti and C. t. marrensis.

Although Humans express a staggering diversity of skin colour and morphological attributes, gene flow is steady enough to prevent speciation. Kurzweil (2005) estimates that the “singularity”, the hypothesis that the rate of technological advancement will lead to runaway artificial intelligence exceeding Human intellectual capacity and control, will occur around the year 2045.
Synonym = Neritilia manoeli

This species has two subspecies, the typical filipendulum and subsp. amaniense (Engl.) Nordal & A.D.Poulsen; these have not been assessed separately.

This species is closely related to C. comosum (Thunb.) Jacq., and the two may in fact be conspecific, but for now are treated separately.
At least six subspecies have been recognized.
The taxonomy of this species and its relatives in the cognatus-group is dramatic and in need of an urgent revision.
Confused with N. farinosa of eastern and southern Africa, status of the western African species requires further study.
Pinhey (1970) treated a different, as yet unnamed, species from eastern Africa as T. basitincta. Many old records under this name refer to T. aconita (see Dijkstra 2007).
Formerly placed in the genus Eothemis.
Genus Lokia is most likely a synonym to Aethiothemis (Dijkstra unpublished).

Concerning the taxonomy of the difficult supinus-group consult Dijkstra (2007). The taxonomy of this species requires further work to determine the correct identity of this species. It may be quirki , seydeli or styx .
Isomecocnemis is a synonym of Chlorocnemis (Dijkstra unpubl.).
This species will become Aethiothemis erythromelas.
The subspecies leonense (incorrect spelling: leonensis) is invalid, as the distinguishing character of the thoracic markings is variable (Dijkstra, unpubl.).
Possibly all western African records follow a confusion with E. girardi.
This genus was recently revised by Libert (2000).
This butterfly is from one of three genera in a genus group that was revised recently by Henning and Henning (2004). No subspecies have been described for this species.

The species was first definitively raised to species rank by Larsen (1997) and until then had been under-reported. Until 1997, six valid species were subsumed under one or two names (T.B. Larsen pers. comm. 2008).
This species used to be considered a subspecies of Hewitsonia boisduvalii with which it is sympatric in the most western parts of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) (Bouyer 1997).
This genus falls into the genus group that was recently revised by Libert (1999).

The nominate subspecies of this butterfly was described from Ethiopia and Sudan. Two additional subspecies are recognized from Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Burundi, the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and Rwanda (ssp. extendens) and another from western Tanzania (ssp. similis).

It is likely to be a valid species since there are no indications that it might be an aberration. The genus was recently revised by Michel Libert who examined the quasi-totality of voucher material in public and private collections: about 70% of all are in the African Butterfly Research Institute, <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Nairobi (Libert 2007).</st1:city></st1:place><st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on"></st1:country-region></st1:place>

This species was described as being from Sierra Leone but this is considered patria falsa by Larsen (2005), since none has since been collected between Sierra Leone and southern Cameroon. One record from Côte d’Ivoire is certainly just a misidentification.
Anthene fulvus has no recent synonyms. It was previously placed within the genus Neurellipes (T. Larsen pers. comm. 2009). There are no subspecies currently recognised.
This species has the two subspecies, H. a. auricostalis and H. auricostalis frommi. The Tanzanian subspecies name frommi may be redundant (T.B. Larsen pers. comm. 2008).
Synonyms: Hypokopelates or Deudorix anettae – usually including ssp. anetia [a valid species]
This species has three subspecies: A. r. rutherfordii, A. rutherfordii cyclops and A. rutherfordii herwigii.
There are no formally recognized subspecies for this taxon, nor are there any widely used synonyms.
A large number of subspecies are described for this extremely widespread butterfly.
This butterfly has no recent synonyms but has three subspecies; the nominate, ssp. bamendanus, and ssp. felthami.

The nominate subspecies was described from Angola and is found also in Zambia and southern DRC. A further subspecies (ssp. kongwana) occurs in Malawi, much of eastern Tanzania, Uganda and southern Kenya. Ssp. peeli is also recorded from Somalia, but this appears to be biogeographically anomalous. It has been suggested that ssp. peeli may simply represent a dry season form of the nominate subspecies (D'Abrera 1997). Therefore, the taxonomy of this subspecies remains uncertain.
This butterfly has two subspecies called P. o. octavia and P. octavia sesamus.

This butterfly has the three subspecies Paradeudorix eleala eleala, P. eleala viridis and P. eleala parallela. The subspecies P. eleala cufadana is also used by some but is probably a junior synonym of ssp. parallela (Larsen 2005).
This species has two subspecies. The nominate subspecies C. c. candiope is found on mainland Africa, while the subspecies C. candiope velox is limited to the island of Socotra.
This species was only described in 2007 following a revision of the genus (Libert 2007).
Two subspecies are formally recognized for this taxon: Cymothoe weymeri weymeri Suffert, 1904 and  C. weymeri mulatta Belcastro, 1990.
This butterfly was described by Libert as recently as 1996 and is difficult to identify with certainty.
This genus is part of the genus group Epitola that was recently revised (Libert 1999). It occurs in two subspecies.
This butterfly has the three subspecies P. violinitens violinitens, P. violinitens coniger and P. violinitens bwamba.
There are no formally recognized subspecies for this taxon, nor are there any widely used synonyms.
Records for Côte d'Ivoire in Ackery et al. (1995) are based on misidentification of material belonging to Liptena similis (Larsen 2005).

This butterfly has the nine subspecies Charaxes imperialis imperialis, C. imperialis albipuncta, C. imperialis dargei, C. imperialis graziellae, C. imperialis lisomboensis, C. imperialis nathaliae, C. imperialis pauliae, C. imperialis ugandicus and C. imperialis werneri.
This species was formerly included in the genus Castalius. The Nigeria/Cameroon population is particularly isolated and may possibly be a distinct species.
The subspecies Colotis eris contracta (Gabriel, 1954) from Arabia appears to be valid, while other subspecies may be questionable (e.g. ssp. johnstoni Butler, 1886 from the eastern Cape Province).
This butterfly is separated into the three subspecies, B. a. anynana, B. anynana centralis and B. anynana socotrana.
This butterfly has four subspecies; these are Protogoniomorpha anacardii anacardii, P. anacardii ansorgei, P. anacardii duprei and P. anacardii nebulosa.

The two subspecies B. p. phantasiella and B. phantasiella simulata have been proposed but simulata is highly likely to be another species. It has not been possible to examine this taxon, but a search for B. phantasiella revealed no material from east of Cameroon and so in all likelihood simulata pertains to another species.
This species is split into the four subspecies E. losinga losinga, E. losinga wardi, E. losinga limita and E. losinga knoopi. These subspecies do not differ much from each other.

This butterfly has 18 subspecies: A. e. echeria, A. echeria abessinica, A. echeria chyuluensis, A. echeria contracta, A. echeria fernandina, A. echeria jacksoni, A. echeria katangae, A. echeria kikuyu, A. echeria lobengula, A. echeria meruensis, A. echeria mongallensis, A. echeria mpala, A. echeria occidentalis, A. echeria septentrionis, A. echeria serica, A. echeria steckeri, A. echeria terrena and A. echeria whytei. Only thirteen of these subspecies are considered valid (T.B. Larsen pers. comm. 2008).

There are two confirmed subspecies of this butterfly, the nominate and ssp. praecyola, which intergrade in eastern Nigeria. The ssp. filaprae Suffert, 1904 from southern Cameroon, Gabon, and parts of the DRC is of uncertain status and the proposed ssp. fernandus on Bioko is better classified as a distinct species (Larsen 2005). Classification of ssp. praecyola as a ssp. of Papilio fernandus Fruhstorfer, 1903 is widely believed to be incorrect due to major morphological differences between the two.

Fourteen subspecies have been described, listed below. It should be noted that ssp. zoroastres is isolated in Bioko and the Cameroon highlands: it was described as a distinct species and given the huge disjunction may actually deserve species status, but most authors presently treat is as subspecies.

Papilio echerioides oscari, Rothschild, 1902

Papilio echerioides zoroastres, Druce, 1878

Papilio echerioides wertheri, Karsch, 1898,

Papilio echerioides shirensis, Hancock, 1987,

Papilio echerioides pseudowertheri, Kielland, 1990,

Papilio echerioides nyiro, Carcasson, 1962,

Papilio echerioides leucospilus, Rothschild, 1902,

Papilio echerioides nioka, Hancock, 1989,

Papilio echerioides kiellandi, Clifton & Collins, 1997,

Papilio echerioides joiceyi, Gabriel, 1945,

Papilio echerioides homeyeri, Plötz, 1880,

Papilio echerioides ambangulu, Clifton & Collins, 1997,

Papilio echerioides chirindanus, van Son, 1956,

Papilio echerioides echerioides, Trimen, 1868.

The taxonomic status of this butterfly in relation to Megalopalpus zymna is not clear. Some authors treat the two as distinct species, others as subspecies of the latter. The taxon included as M. simplex is small and has a light underside compared to the brown of M. zymna and appears to be the only morph that flies in Tanzania and Uganda.
This butterfly has three subspecies, B. s. smithi, B. smithi eurypterus and B. smithi fernandina.
This butterfly has the two subspecies E. s. splendens and E. splendens ghanaensis.
There are no described subspecies for this little known species.
This species is split into the two subspecies Myrina sharpei sharpei and M. sharpei fontainei.
This butterfly consists of the two subspecies O. faunus faunus and O. faunus camerunica.

Collins and Larsen (1998) reviewed the extensive material of Eresiomera held by the African Butterfly Research Institute, Nairobi. They described three new species. They also found two Cameroon males that seemed close to Eresiomera ouesso, but there were minor differences in both morphology and in the configuration of the genitalia and a definite conclusion was not possible.
Older records of the species are not trustworthy because of much recent revisionary work on the genus by Libert (1996).
There are no formally recognized subspecies for this taxon.
Two weakly differentiated subspecies are recognised: Tuxentius carana carana Hewitson, 1876 and Tuxentius carana kontu Karsch, 1893.

Whether all populations of this species are genuinely conspecific remains to be ascertained by DNA analysis. The type locality is Mabira Forest in Uganda and the populations in western Kenya and northwestern Tanzania all belong to this species sensu stricto. Those in Kivu Province in the DRC probably also belong to this species sensu stricto, while records from Congo and Cameroon might be different. Material resembling Mylothris continua in Ghana would be a distinct species.
This species was described recently following Libert's revision of the genus (2007).
This species has three subspecies: Iolaus hemicyanus hemicyanus, I. hemicyanus barbara and I. hemicyanus barnsi.
This upland species has no recent synonyms or any  recognised subspecies.
Some females of this species are difficult to identify with full confidence, however, this is a valid species (T.B. Larsen pers. comm. 2008).
Records from west of the Dahomey Gap are misidentified females of Liptena helena (Larsen 2005).

Some of the western specimens pertain to the composita­-form, which might be a distinct species or a morph of the same species. The taxonomy of these species is still in flux. It cannot be treated as a subspecies since it is sympatric with E. themis throughout and is just possibly a distinct species. It will need close study in an area of sympatry to be sure (Larsen 2005).

The species was originally described in 1969 after a few Nigerian specimens and a female from Côte d’Ivoire (the latter subsequently reassigned to Torbenia wojtusiaki as have all other similar material from west of the Dahomey Gap). Therefore, the genus revision confirmed that the species is found only east of the Dahomey Gap (Libert 2005).
This species was described only in 2005 following Libert's revision of the genus (Libert 2005).

Specimens recently collected in Ghana and Guinea probably comprise one or more different species (M. Libert pers. comm. 2008). The assessment is therefore based on A. prouvosti sensu stricto as in the original description.
There are no formally recognized subspecies for this taxon, nor are there any widely used synonyms.
This butterfly has the four subspecies C. e. etheocles, C. etheocles carpenteri, C. etheocles evansi and C. etheocles ochracea.

The relationship of this species to Hewitsonia bitjeana from southern Cameroon is disputed. Bouyer (1997) considers them a single species for which the latter name would take precedence (Bouyer now tends to consider beryllina a western subspecies (pers. comm.)). Larsen (2005) considers them two species. However, very few records exist (five or six in all) for either taxon.
This species contains two subspecies: B. i. ikelemba and B. i. kamituga.
This butterfly consists of the following three subspecies: P. leonina leonina, P. leonina dimitris and P. leonina indentata.
This butterfly has two subspecies, the nominate and ssp. fournierae.
The genera formerly included in the genus Epitola were recently revised by Libert (1999).
There are no described subspecies for this butterfly.

This species is only known from a single specimen caught at Kigour Forest, DRC. Some uncertainty remains over whether the taxon is distinct from Neptis rothschildi, or whether the taxa are synonymous, as proposed by E. Vingerhoedt (pers. comm. 2008). This uncertainty is likely to remain while records of the species continue to be scarce (T. Larsen pers. comm. 2009).
This butterfly has two subspecies, B. e. evadne and B. evadne elionias.

It used to be thought that the range of this species stretched from <st1:country-region w:st="on">Sierra Leone</st1:country-region> to <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">Uganda</st1:country-region></st1:place>. However, M. Libert is currently in the process of revising the Afrotropical Lycaenesthini and has divided the species into three sibling species with slight overlap in distributions (M. Libert pers. comm. 2008). Therefore, the true distribution of this butterfly is now defined as from Ghana to Cameroon.
This butterfly has two subspecies called Precis rauana rauana and P. rauana silvicola.
This species had previously been confused with Ornipholidotos ntebi, which is effectively limited to east of the Albertine Rift (Kenya, Uganda, northwestern Tanzania).
This butterfly has the two subspecies N. ophione ophione and N. ophione nucleata.
This butterfly has the two subspecies S. o. occidentalium and S. occidentalium penricei. Historically this species was placed in the synonymous genus Asterope.

This species was previously considered to be a form of Neptis nicomedes but was recently upgraded to species level by Larsen (2005). The taxonomic complex remains a difficult one: both species are forest butterflies which may occur together or either of them singly. In addition, more than one species may be covered under the taxon Neptis quintilla, as subpopulations of the species come in two colour morphs: one is the usual dark blackish-brown of the genus, while the other is a lighter blackish-grey with no hint of brown (T. Larsen pers. comm. 2009). The valve of the grey form is 25% longer than that of the dark. As a whole, therefore, some degree of uncertainty remains over the status of this difficult taxon.
The species has been documented in Guinea and Ghana, though these records are considered to be erroneous and suggested to refer to darker specimens of Belenois theora.
As many as 27 subspecies have been described for this species.

This species was assigned to the new genus Cerautola following Libert's recent revision (1999) and it divides into four subspecies. The nominate subspecies is found from Guinea-Bissau to western Nigeria; ssp leucographa Libert, 1999 is in Cameroon, Congo, Gabon, northern Angola, Central African Republic and western Congo and ssp. holochroma Berger, 1981 flies in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and Uganda, with ssp. congdoni Libert & Collins, 1999 in northwestern Tanzania and Zambia.

A number of subspecies – difficult to characterize properly – are recognized. In the eastern parts of the range a number of similar species occur, which are difficult to tell apart from this butterfly.

Three subspecies are currently recognized for this widely distributed taxon: one occurring in western Africa (from Guinea to eastern Nigeria), another in the equatorial zone, and a third in the coastal forests of East Africa (T. Larsen pers. comm. 2009).
This genus was recently revised by Libert (2007), whereupon two subspecies of this butterfly were described, the nominate and ssp. depuncta.
This butterfly has the two subspecies, I. i. iasis and I. iasis albomaculatus.

Current taxonomy of Paramelania is under revision. Brown (1994) lists only two species, but West et al. 2003 identify six. These are listed here under their previous names, which are likely to be resurrected in revision.
This species is split into the two subspecies B. l. laetitia and B. laetitia vesta.
This butterfly has two subspecies, B. m. martius and B. martius sanaos.
This butterfly has the three subspecies Pseudathyma plutonica plutonica, P. plutonica expansa and P. plutonica shaba.
Two putative subspecies have been proposed for this butterfly: Junonia oenone oenone and J. oenone epiclelia.
Ammania senegalensis occurs as two forms: A. senegalensis f. senegalensis and  A. senegalensis f. indica (Diwakar 2001)
Gabbiella neothaumaeformis is taxonomically insufficiently known.
Recent morphological and molecular investigation in Nigeria indicates that identification of B. senegalensis on morphological characteistics only is unreliable.
Formerly placed in family Thiaridae, this genus is now placed in Paludomidae.

Aspatharia pfeifferiana was formerly considered as a species ranging from Senegal to Zambia (Mandahl-Barth, 1988). We here follow the taxonomic interpretation of Graf & Cummings (2019), which confines Aspatharia pfeifferiana to the region of the Congo basin and Gabon.
Formerly placed in family Thiaridae, this genus is now placed in Paludomidae.

This taxon is polyspecific, but most probably only one species occurs in Western Africa. The southern African species will be assigned to a separate species in future after taxonomic study. A taxonomic revision is planned (Snoeks, pers. comm.).

Hipppotomyrus has recently been restricted to four species (Hopkins et al. 2007). The genus Cyphomyrus has been resurrected and includes seven species from the Congo basin (Sullivan in lit.). Cyphomyrus are deep-bodied with a dorsal fin base longer than the anal.

Hipppotomyrus has recently been restricted to four species (Hopkins et al. 2007). The genus Cyphomyrus has been resurrected and includes seven species from the Congo basin (Sullivan in lit.). Cyphomyrus are deep-bodied with a dorsal fin base longer than the anal.
Cyphomyrus psittacus is the only species among the mormyrids with the dorsal fin origin clearly ahead of the anal fin origin.

Hipppotomyrus has recently been restricted to four species (Hopkins et al. 2007). The genus Cyphomyrus has been resurrected and includes seven species from the Congo basin (Sullivan in lit.). Cyphomyrus are deep-bodied with a dorsal fin base longer than the anal.
Generic assignment is in need of confirmation.
This species is similar to Hippopotamyrus pictus and Hippopotamyrus paugyi.
Generic assignment is in need of confirmation.

Leptoglanis brevis was synonymized with Zaireichthys rotundiceps by Roberts (2003). He comments though that the types are "closely similar, possibly conspecific". Due to this uncertainty, these two species are treated separately in this assessment.
Whether this species has to be placed in the genus Zaireichthys or Leptoglanis or that a new genus has to be designated, remains a point of discussion (Roberts 2003).
This is a western Africa species and further taxonomic work is needed to confirm its occurrence within the southern Africa region.
Previously placed in Allorrhizucha (Dijkstra and Vick 2006).
Previously confused with central and east African species P. aureozona, P. caneri and P. insignis.
The status of the species is uncertain, and is based on unseen records.
Records from east of the Dahomey Gap (Nigeria, etc.) are treated as T. tropicana.
All listed names treated as synonyms by Carfi & D'Andrea (1994). Legrand (2003) raised Chlorocnemis rossii to species level, but the basis is suspect.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
Subgenus (Paludopanchax)
Two subspecies are known - P. a. annectens and P. a. brieni.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
Subgenus (Diapteron).
There are two subspecies: E. bifasciatus bifasciatus and E. bifasciatus taeniatus.
This species is considered by all Tanganyika cichlid scientists to be E. melanogenys. However, this needs to be verified (Snoeks, pers. comm.).
Possibly a synonym of N. parvus
The Congolese specimens belong to a new species of Grasseichthys (Stiassny et al., 2007, Schelly and Britz, in prep.). G.gabonensis is restricted to the Ogowe/Ivindo basin.
There is very little information available about Labeo luluae.
Subgenus (Epiplatys).
Subgenus (Chromaphyosemion).
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
Taxonomic status of the Tanzania population uncertain.
The records of the Lower Congo need to be reviewed as they are possibly misidentifications.

Subgenus (Paraphyosemion) : Berkenkamp (2003), describing the results of hybridization tests with the other species of the Fundulopanchax mirabilis-group, (Fundulopanchax intermittens, Fundulopanchax gresensi, Fundulopanchax moensis and Fundulopanchax traudeae), indicates that all crosses resulted in a viable F3 generations. These results suggest that, following a biological species concept, these taxa may be considered conspecific.

Vences et al. (2004) confirmed the validity of Hemidactylus mercatorius as a species distinct from H. mabouia, with which it had previously been confused, considering that it represented mainland African and Madagascan members of this species complex. Uncertainty over the exact definitions of these two species, and potential confusion with additional species of Hemidactylus, remain, making it difficult to establish the global distribution of either H. mercatorius or H. mabouia. Vences et al. (2004) found that Madagascan H. mercatorius were genetically distinct from a sample from Mozambique. Within Madagascan H. mercatorius, at least three distinct lineages appear to exist (Vences et al. 2004, Boumans et al. 2007). Rocha et al. (2005) found that Gulf of Guinea "H. mabouia" identified by Jesus et al. (2005) belonged to the northern Madagascar lineage of H. mercatorius identified by Vences et al. (2004). This concept of H. mercatorius as a widespread island species appears to correspond to Clade A of "H. mabouia" identified by Rocha et al. (2010), which is also found in Tanzania, South Africa (where three separate lineages have been identified), Uganda and the Seychelles, including a lineage endemic to the Aldabra archipelago. However, given the apparent basal relationships of mainland African members of this clade and continuing uncertainty over their taxonomic assignment, this assessment follows Rocha et al. (2010) in restricting the name H. mercatorius to island populations within this clade, with continental populations remaining under the name H. mabouia until the taxonomy of this species complex is resolved.
This species is also known as Prisodontopsis johnstoni (E.A. Smith 1893) in recent literature, but that name is a primary homonym of Unio johnstoni Etheridge, 1881.
Mandahl-Barth (1988) has divided this species into four geographical races.

The African representatives of the family Ancylidae need to revised,  since the present taxonomy is based on questionable morphological  characteristics. This  taxonomical incertainty makes the formulation of  assessments unjustified
.

In recent treatments, Mutela dubia has been regarded as a number of subspecies: Mutela d. dubia, M. d. nilotica, M. d. emini and M. d. garambae (Van Damme 1984, Mandahl-Barth 1988, Daget 1998, Graf and Cummings 2007). M. d. garambae is morphologically distinct and geographically isolated from the others in this complex and perhaps represents a distinct species.
The identification of a Pila population as P. wernei  in Lake Nasser (Egypt) (Ibrahim et al., 1999) needs confirmation. The specimen figured in their study may be in our opinion a Pila ovata.

Elongate Mutela species with pointed posteriors and green periostracum from the Nile basin, West Africa and the Congo basin have all been treated as Mutela rostrata (Pilsbry and Bequaert 1927, Van Damme 1984, Mandahl-Barth 1988, Daget 1998), but the Congolese populations may represent a separate species based upon their distinct morphology (Graf and Cummings 2006, 2007). A revision is needed.
It is not evident to identify Biomphalaria camerunensis and therefore the range cited may be altered in following assessments.

This is an exclusively western African species. The record by Ibrahim et al. (1999) from Lake Nasser (Egypt) is erroneous and appears to be an abberant juvenile form of L. carinatus The spiral banding is similar to that of L. carinatus, while L. varicus usually is homogeneously dark brown.

The taxonomy of the minute Assimineidae is completely outdated and in need of revision. Assimineids seem to be easily spread by birds and their distribution is erratic and instable. The species Assiminea hessei may possibly not belong in the genus Assiminea (Brown 1994). It is also possibly that the Nigerian species may be a different taxon, as the originally described Congo species, which is only known from shells. Since shells are near useless for identification, the type material can not be identified anymore.
The representatives of the genus Pachymelania are presently ranged in the family Hemisinidae

The taxonomic arrangement of Graf & Cummings (2019) is here followed.  Accordingly, all references of Coelatura gabonensis from West Africa are considered to be misidentifications of C. aegyptiaca specimens.

Subspecies:
A. irregularis angeli Laurent, 1950
A. irregularis bipostocularis Boulenger, 1905
A. irregularis conradsi Sternfield, 1908
A. irregularis parkeri Laurent, 1945
A. irregularis uelensis Laurent 1945.
Trioceros feae and T. camerunensis have previously been considered to be subspecies of T. montium.

This species occurs in several disjunct subpopulations, and this unusual distribution may reflect a complex of several cryptic species (K. Tolley pers. comm. 2012). J. Mariaux (pers. comm.) suggests that Congolese specimens at least may represent a separate species.

This species was previously considered to occur throughout western and central Africa, from Gambia to western Uganda (Spawls et al. 2002). Trape and Mané (2006) re-examined specimens of this species and Dasypeltis scabra from West Africa, erecting three new species distributed in the Sahel, Sudanese savannah and the Guinean tropics respectively. Trape et al. (2012) re-examined the systematics of West African Dasypeltis, and confirmed that D. macrops is a junior synonym of D. fasciata.
The taxonomy of this species in southern Africa is being investigated, and the presence of cryptic taxa has been suggested (Bates et al. 2011, 2012).
This species is sometimes included under the genus Abildgaardia.
Only subspecies chaetaria of Eleocharis retroflexa occurs in India.
Valid name of the species is Kyllinga tenuifolia Steud.
This species is closely allied to Hemarthria altissima (Poir.) Stapf & C.E. Hubb., some authors consider them as a single species.
Mariscus cyperoides is the valid name of Cyperus cyperoides.
Synonym of Crinum lorifolium is Crinum pratense.
Mariscus maderaspatanus is the valid name of Cyperus maderaspatanus.

This species has two subspecies: Prosymna a. ambigua Bocage, 1873 and P. ambigua bocagii (Boulenger, 1897)  P. stuhlmanni, formerly a subspecies of P. ambigua, is now generally considered a full species (e.g. Branch 1998, Broadley 1992, Spawls et al. 2002, Uetz and Hallerman 2012).
The validity of Psammophylax tritaeniatus fitgeraldi Broadley, 1960 has been questioned (see Uetz et al. 2018).

On the basis of molecular evidence, Greenbaum et al. (2011) erected the new genus Congolacerta for Adolfus vauereselli and the newly-described Congolacerta asukului, and assigned Lacerta vauereselli as the type species.
The relationship between this species and U. palmeri requires additional research.
The currently valid name changed from Rhinotyphlops stejnegeri (Loveridge, 1931) to Letheobia stejnegeri (Broadley and Wallach 2007).
It is thought that populations of Leptosiaphos aloysiisabaudiae from Nigeria and Cameroon may represent a separate, undescribed species (Chirio and LeBreton 2007).
According to the PhD thesis of Risch (1968, unpublished), Gephyroglanis habereri is a synonym of Chrysichthys congicus.
Subgenus (Epiplatys).
This species is probably heterospecific and further study is required.

The description of Varicorhinus lufupensis has been based on two specimens from the same locality and were both purchased in fresh condition from local fishermen (Banister and Bailey 1979). These are the only two records that have been made of this species.

Microsynodontis used to be one species Microsynodontis batesi. It has been split into nine species. According to Brummett, R. it is almost impossible to tell them apart and it is doubtful regarding their species status (pers. comm. Brummett, R. and Reid, G. McG.).
The taxonomy of Pelmatochromis nigrofasciatus and Pelmatochromis ocellifer needs to be reviewed.
This species has affinities with Mormyrus rume and Mormyrus subundulatus, Mormyrus tapirus has a longer snout, longer anal fin and 10-15 scales on caudal peduncle.
The generic assignment of this poorly known species is clearly erroneous (Asian genus).
Clariallabes manyangae could be a synonym of Clariallabes laticeps (Steindachner, 1911) (Musschoot, T., unpub.)
The generic and family placement of Leptoglanis bouilloni is not yet completely resolved.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
Bagrus lubosicus could be a synonym of Bagrus ubangensis (Stiassny, M., pers. comm.). The taxonomy of this species needs reviewing.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
Subgenus (Paraphyosemion).
According to the PhD thesis of Risch (1968, unpublished), Gephyroglanis longipinnis is a partial synonym of Chrysichthys longipinnis and Chrysichthys longibarbis.

Microsynodontis used to be one species Microsynodontis batesi. It has been split into nine species. According to Brummett, R. it is almost impossible to tell them apart and it is doubtful regarding their species status (pers. comm. Brummett, R. and Reid, G. McG.).
Subgenus (Fundulopanchax).
It is only known by type specimen. Other specimens of this species have been misidentified. Type is aberrant in having a long dorsal, and it will be checked shortly (J. Snoeks pers. comm. 2006)
Bagrus lubosicus could be a synonym of Bagrus ubangensis (Stiassny, M., pers. comm.).
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).

Within Lower Guinea, there are two specimens from the Niari River (MNHN 1962-118) that agree in most counts and measures with the types of S. polylepis, but differ from them in the size of the eye which is small in the types (8.3–9.8% HL), but large in the Niari specimens (11.5–13%). Future study may reveal the Niari specimens to belong to a new species. (Stiassny et al., 2007).
It is distinguished from Neolebias by its complete lateral line.

Loiselle (1979) comments on the presence of dwarfed populations of an “elongatus-like” fish in Lakes Barombi Kotto and Mboandong, Cameroon and these may represent a distinct species. With the availability of live specimens from the Congo basin and Upper Zambezi there are indications that these populations may also represent distinct species (Stiassny et al., 2007).

Mastacembelus niger Sauvage, 1879 was originally described from “Doumé” (Gabon). Mastacembelus marmoratus Perugia, 1894 from “Congo” (DRC) [“Lower Congo” (Boulenger, 1916)], M. goro Boulenger, 1902 from “Ubanghi à Brazzaville” (DRC), M. batesii Boulenger, 1911 from “Ja River at Bitye, South Cameroon (Congo basin)” (Cameroon) and M. ubangensis Boulenger, 1911 from “Banzyville, Ubanghi” (DRC) have been described from the Congo River basin. Mastacembelus brevicauda Boulenger, 1911 was originally described from “South Cameroon” (Kribi River, Zima Country, Ja and Bumba Rivers)” (Cameroon).

Several diagnostic characters have been reported for these species in the literature. However, a detailed study of these characters revealed that: (1) with increasing size the preanal length decreases proportionally to the increase of the postanal length. (2) The preorbital spine, if present, has a tendency to disappear with size. In small specimens, the presence/absence of a preorbital spine may vary according to the basin of origin. (3) Preopercular spines, if present, have a tendency to decrease in number with size. The number of preopercular spines may vary considerable between specimens of the same basin. (4) The number of dorsal spines shows an important amount of geographical variation. Intrapopulation variation can be relatively large and these taxa are herein synonomized with M. niger.
In Bishai and Khalil (1997), the taxonomic authority is "Cuvier & Valenciennes, 1840"
Subgenus (Chromaphyosemion).
The specimens of Pool Malebo (Stanley Pool) have to be re-examined to clarify the strange distribution pattern.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
The taxonomy of this species needs to be reviewed.
The taxonomy of this group is in need of revision and the distinction between this species and Alestes macrophthalmus is poorly defined.
The genus Cyphomyrus has been resurrected and includes seven species from the Congo basin (Sullivan in lit.). Cyphomyrus are deep-bodied species with a dorsal fin base longer than the anal.
According to the PhD thesis of Risch (1968, unpublished), Chrysichthys uniformis Pellegrin, 1922 is a synonym of Chrysichthys cranchii Leach, 1818 (=Amarginops cranchii (Leach, 1818)).
The status of the two subspecies needs further investigation. Formerly in the family Kneriidae.
In Bishai and Khalil (1997), the taxonomic authority is "Geoffroy, 1827"

The status of Epiplatys boulengeri and Epiplatys multifasciatus is under discussion. Huber (1998) studied the types of E. boulengeri (from Kidada, Mogenda and Tshimbu in west-central ZaireDemocratic Republic of Congo) but was unable to compare them with those of E. multifasciatus (from Kondué, Kasai Province, southeastern Democratic Republic of Congo). He suggested that E. multifasciatus from the northeastern Democratic Republic of Congo and the eastern Congo-Brazzaville are conspecific with E. boulengeri.
Cited by Bishai and Khalil (1997) as Tetrodon linneatus Linnaeus, 1766
According to the PhD thesis of Risch (1968, unpublished), Gephyroglanis longipinnis is a partial synonym of Chrysichthys longipinnis and Chrysichthys longibarbis.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
The species level taxonomy of this genus is in need of revision.
Subgenus (Diapteron).
Subgenus (Chromaphyosemion).

Clarias pachynema is closely related to C. ebriensis. It is possible that these species are synonymous, but since their geographical areas are distinctly separate and no material is available from the intermediate zone, it is better to consider them as separate species
Specimens from the northern tributaries of the upper Zambezi in Zambia are larger and more boldly pigmented and further taxonomic investigation is needed (Tweddle et al. 2004).

Aphyosemion bualanum, as defined by Scheel (1968), is regarded here as Aphyosemion elberti. Therefore, all scientific as well as popular aquarium articles about Aphyosemion bualanum, published prior to 1990, in fact deal with the species Aphyosemion elberti. Aphyosemion cameronense that was reported in Blache et al. (1964) from the Mayo Kebbi basin of northern Cameroon, might be identical to A. bualanum.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
According to the unpublished PhD thesis of Risch, L.M. (1986) Chrysichthys mabusi is a synonym of Chrysichthys sharpii.
The juvenile specimen of Ctenopoma muriei of the Lualaba system is considered to be Microctenopoma ocellifer.

authority: (Taverne, Thys van den Audenaerde, Heymer & Géry, 1977)

taxonomicNotes: There is very little information available about Synodontis katangae.
There is very few information available about Clariallabes attemsi.
Subgenus (Fundulopanchax).
Subgenus (Diapteron).
The taxonomy of Pelmatochromis nigrofasciatus and Pelmatochromis ocellifer needs to be reviewed.
It is in the subgenus Chromaphyosemion.

The genus Barbus (Cyprinidae) is restricted to a small number of species mainly inhabiting the European ichthyographic region including northeastern Africa. Most of the African species which are currently included in the genus, taxonomically do not appear to be closely related to the genus Barbus sensu strictu. However, no attempts have yet been made at an adequate nomenclature of the African forms. We therefore follow Berrebi et al. (1996) and use in this paper the term ‘Barbus’ for the cyprinid fish species which were previously considered as Barbus (Seegers et al., unpublished).
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
Taxonomy of haplochromine cichlids is in disarray. The species is often included in Thoracochromis. Further phylogenetic work is necessary to resolve generic placement.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
The species Petrocephalus simus apparently does not exist in West Africa (Leveque et al. 1992; Paugy at al. 2003)
There is very few information available about Opsaridium maculicauda.
There is very little information available about Synodontis iturii.
Subgenus (Epiplatys).
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
The specimens of Amphilius lamani of the upper Mpoulou River are Amphilius mamonekenensis.
Subgenus (Paraphyosemion).

This species is also reported from Lake Turkana under the old name Alestes nurse (Rüppel, 1832). Turkana specimens of this species are noticeably smaller (12 cm fork length) than specimens from other populations, which grow up to 218 mm SL. Therefore the Turkana population was described as a distinct subspecies (Seegers et al. 2003), however Brycinus nurse nana is not a valid subspecies.

Microsynodontis used to be one species Microsynodontis batesi. It has been split into nine species. According to Brummett, R. it is almost impossible to tell them apart and it is doubtful regarding their species status (pers. comm. Brummett, R. and Reid, G. McG.).

The generic placement of this species remains unclear. The species appears to occupy an intermediate position between Oreochromis and Sarotherodon. The structures and coloration of the mature males and what is known of the breeding habits are characteristic of Oreochromis. The general appearance is that of Sarotherodon galilaeus. Before sexual maturity preserved specimens are indistinguishable from the latter. The species is perhaps best regarded as a Sarotherodon that has developed reproductive features largely paralleling those of Oreochromis (Trewavas 1983).
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
This species is in need of further investigation and may be heterospecific and including a number of undescribed species with restricted distributions.
Although the species has been assumed to be an inhabitant of rapids Teugels et al. (1992) have collected it in both rapids and in non-rapidly flowing stretches of the Cross River.
Specimens in Madamyana tributary of Upper Zambezi have distinctly barred tails and need taxonomic study (Tweddle et al. 2004).
Subgenus (Aphyosemion).
All Polypterus under revision
This species is under revision, and is possibly a species complex.
There is very little information available about Synodontis cuangoanus.
All Polypterus under revision

It is commonly misidentified as Aplocheilichthys macrophthalmus in scientific literature. There are two subspecies A. macrophthalmus macrophthalmus (Meinken, 1923) and A. m. hamnerzi. The former is widespread while the later is restricted to Nigeria. A. m. macrophthalmus range from Togble-kope in Togo through southern Benin, southern Nigeria and southwestern Cameroon.

Subgenus (Chrysichthys) : C. auratus exhibits pronounced intraspecific variability, and a clinal series can be demonstrated in the size of the adipose fin and the number of gill rakers (Risch, 1986): populations from the Nile, Chad, Senegal and the upper reaches of Niger River, Comoe, Benue and Volta have a lower number of gill rakers and a larger adipose fin than the populations of the coastal areas from Liberia to Cabinda. The populations of the middle and lower reaches of the Niger, the Comoe, the Benue and the Volta are more or less intermediate between the two. Therefore we consider all populations to represent a single, highly variable, species (Geerinckx et al. 2007).

Chrysichthys persimilis and Chrysichthys rueppelli are considered to be males of Chrysichthys auratus (Risch and Vreven 2007).

There are significant differences in the fin ray counts and other meristic descriptors between the forms from Liberia and Sierra-Leone and in Cameroon (Jégu and Lévêque 1984), suggesting either clinal variation, or the possibility of two distinct species.
Taxonomic revision is needed.
Subgenus (Pauciradius).

A monotypic genus. species small-sized, elongated body, short and deep head. Position of pelvics below dorsal. Caudal peduncle extremely slender and hard. Principal dorsal and pectoral fin ray minute. A row of bony scutes at each side of back and belly as well as around caudal peduncle.
Clariallabes dumerili (David & Poll, 1937) is not a valid name or synonym for Clariallabes teugelsi Ferraris, 2007.
There is very few information available about Synodontis camelopardalis. This species is currently being reviewed.
For Bisahai and Khalil (1997), the validate name of this specie : Gnathonemus cyprinoides (Linnaeus, 1764)
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).

Hemichromis frempongi (Loiselle, 1979) has been mentioned as a synonym of H. fasciatus but previous works in Ghana (Paugy et al. 2003, Dankwa et al. 1999) indicate that the species does not exist. FishBase (2018) indicates that the name has been misapplied

Subgenus (Kathetys). The nomenclature of this species is presently under discussion. Huber (1996) indicates that the correct name should be Aphyosemion bualanum. As no freshly collected material from the type locality of Aphyosemion bualanum is available we prefer to follow the latest available revision (Seegers 1988). Wildekamp (1993) regards Aphyosemion bualanum as defined by Scheel (1968) as Aphyosemion elberti by Seegers (1988).
Subgenus (Paraphyosemion).
There is very little information available about Varicorhinus wittei.
It can be differentiated from genus Brycinus by the presence of adipose eyelids.
All the specimens of Tylochromis aristoma are collected by Roberts, T.R. in 1987.
Raiamas nigeriensis maybe sympatric with R. senegalensis and R. steindachneri and has always been mistaken for R. senegalensis, which is the reason for it not being discovered.
A group of melanophores above the base of the anal fin is more pronounced than that observed for Micralestes species.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
Subgenus (Parepiplatys).
Barboides gracilis is distinguished from small Barbus species in sight by absence of barbels, absence of lateral line and 1 single nostril in form of 8 at each side of snout.
The taxonomy of Congochromis squamiceps needs to be reviewed. The distribution is probably more restricted.
Clariallabes manyangae could be a synonym of Clariallabes laticeps (Steindachner, 1911) (Musschoot, T., unpub.)
This species was erroneously synonomized with X. spilurus. X. crassus is a valid species and its resurrection is in prep. (Vreven, Stiassny and Mamonekene).
Subgenus (Chromaphyosemion).

Micralestes humilis is most similar and possibly conspecific with M. stormsi Boulenger, 1902 and M. sardina Poll, 1938. Apart from coloration, it is distinguished from the latter two species on the basis of slight differences in overlapping features. From M. stormsi, it is distinguished on the basis of greater number of scales in the longitudinal series (25-27, vs. 22-24 in M. stormsi) and from M. sardina by a slightly greater head length (26-29% SL, vs. 24-27% SL in M. sardina). Furthermore, the presence of dark pigmentation along the base of the flank scales, considered by Poll (1967) and others as characteristic of M. humilis, was observed to be variably preserved in the material examined in this study. These species are distributed broadly in the Congo basin and material referable to all three was observed in the Lower Guinea region. However, such small differences are of dubious diagnostic utility in light of insufficient knowledge of intraspecific and geographic variation in these species. At present, it seems most reasonable to refer all to the older available name, M. humilis.
According to Maugé (1986), reports of the Western Atlantic species Guavina guavina from Senegal are probably based on misidentifications of Bostrychus africanus
This species has been misspelled as H. forskali or H. forskalii (Seegers et al. 2004)
The status of this species is currently in doubt and is under investifation. Hardman (in lit.) proposes the synonomy of C. delhezi with C. cranchii.
The genus Cyphomyrus has been resurrected and includes seven species from the Congo basin (Sullivan in lit.). Cyphomyrus are deep-bodied with a dorsal fin base longer than the anal.

The taxonomy of Nanochromis nudiceps is currently under revision.
Gnathobagrus depressus is probably a synonym of Chrysichthys ornatus (Mo, 1991). This has been confrmed by Hardman, M.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
The generic identity of this species is tentative, pending the availability of specimens for anatomical analyses.

According to the PhD thesis of Risch (1968, unpublished), Chrysichthys uniformis Pellegrin, 1922 is a synonym of Chrysichthys cranchii Leach, 1818. Hardman (in lit) also considers C.delhezi to be a synonym of C. cranchii.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).

The subpopulation close to the source of the Zambezi is morphologically distinct, being larger and less deep than fish elsewhere in its range. The fish have red fins compared to the colourless or creamy fins of those elsewhere. This requires taxonomic investigation (Tweddle et al. 2004).
The species level taxonomy of this genus is in need of revision.

The distribution map of L. markerti and L. tigripictilis in Tougas and Stiassny (2014) show that L. tigripictilis only occurs upstream of the Inga rapids. They indicate that a specimens from Nziya village previously identified as L. tigripictilis by Schelly and Stiassny (2004) in fact represent L. markerti (AMNH 233568). However, they do not explain the distribution and do not reveal the taxonomic position of L. tigripictilis specimens from Matadi (BMNH 1899.2.20.10) and Boma (MRAC 48562) identified in Schelly and Stiassny (2004) as L. tigripictilis.
Subgenus (Chromaphyosemion).
The presence of Tilapia tholloni in Pool Malebo has to be confirmed. Difficulties arise due to the sympatric presence of Tilapia congica in Pool Malebo.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).

Laeviscutella dekimpei is closely related to Sierrathrissa leonensis. However, it is distinguished from that taxon by the presence of non-keeled prepelvic scutes with ascending arms, and keeled postpelvic scutes lacking ascending arms as well as by the dorsal fin insertion at midbody above the pelvic fins. Sierrathrissa leonensis has both pre- and postpelvic scutes without keels or ascending arms, and the dorsal fin is situated clearly behind the pelvic insertion.
According to the PhD thesis of Risch (1968, unpublished), Gephyroglanis congicus is a synonym of Chrysichthys congicus.
Subgenus (Diapteron).
Cited by Bishai and Khalil (1997) as Schilbe (Schilbe) uranoscopus Rüppell, 1829

There is very little information available about Synodontis centralis.
Rhadalestes rhodesiensis is possibly identical to Rhabdalestes maunensis.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
