Clariallabes heterocephalus Poll, 1976 is probably a synonym of Clariallabes variabilis Pellegrin, 1926 (Musschoot, T., 2002, unpub.)
The taxonomic status of this species needs to be verified. With exception of the humeral spot, Brycinus abeli resembles Brycinus imberi (Paugy 1986).
Taxonomic works is needed as the name is already preoccupied by Barbus tetraspilus Günther, 1868 known from Sri Lanka.
A synonym of Brachysynodontis barensoda (Rüppel, 1932). See the species Synodontis batensoda Rüppel, 1932.
Subgenus (Paludopanchax).

Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion): The nomenclature of this species is under discussion. Huber (1996) presented arguments that Aphyosemion escherichi could be a synonym of Aphyosemion striatum. The correct name of the species, here named Aphyosemion escherichi could then be Aphyosemion microphtalmum Lambert & Géry, 1968. No freshly collected material from the type locality of Aphyosemion escherichi is available; we prefer to follow the latest available revision (Seegers 1988).
Subgenus (Aphyosemion).
Taxonomy of haplochromine cichlids is in disarray. The species is often included in Ctenochromis. Further phylogenetic work is necessary to resolve generic placement.

Microsynodontis used to be one species Microsynodontis batesi. It has been split into nine species. According to Brummett, R. it is almost impossible to tell them apart and it is doubtful regarding their species status (pers. comm. Brummett, R. and Reid, G. McG.).

Malapterurus beninensis displays marked variation in pigmentation across its range. It is possible that Malapterurus beninensis is an amalgam of two or three species, but while extreme morphotypes and pigment variants can be quite distinct, there is extensive overlap. Attempts to assign taxonomic significance to this variation were unsuccessful. Cohesive, definable taxa could not be identified in either pattern of variation or geography.
Subgenus (Paludopanchax).
It is currently under revision. Teleogramma brichardi is possibly a complex.
Clariallabes heterocephalus Poll, 1976 is probably a synonym of Clariallabes variabilis Pellegrin, 1926 (Musschoot, T., 2002, unpub.)

Subgenus (Chromaphyosemion). Aphyosemion kouamense Legros, 1999, Aphyosemion melanogaster (Legros, Zentz & Agnèse, 2005), Aphyosemion malumbresi Legros & Zentz, 2006, Aphyosemion erythron (Sonnenberg, 2007) and Aphyosemion ecucuense (Sonnenberg, 2007) form a closely related southern group of species that were all formerly subsumed under Aphyosemion splendopleure (see Sonnenberg 2007a, 2007b) and all characterised by numerous red spots in the unpaired fins.
Subgenus (Paraphyosemion).
Taxonomy of this species is in need of clarification. The distinction between this species and T. tholleni in Pool Malebo is poorly defined.

Mastacembelus loennbergii Boulenger, 1898 was originally described on five specimens originating from “a muddy rivulet in Bongo, Cameroons” (Lönnberg 1895). Further, M. decorsei Pellegrin, 1919 was originally described on a single specimen originating from “Gribingui” (Chad). Travers (1992 a) considered M. decorsei a valid species and did not recognize the presence of M. loennbergii in the Nilo-Sudan ichthyofaunal province (Travers 1992 b). Indeed, in his list of synonyms and citations Travers (1992 b) seems to have transferred all specimens, except the type material of M. loennbergii, to either M. cryptacanthus or M. decorsei. Nevertheless, Travers never formally synonymized M. loennbergii with M. cryptacanthus (note that M. decorsei was described after M. loennbergii and as a result M. loennbergii cannot be placed in synonymy with M. decorsei). On the contrary, Travers (1992 a) referred to M. loennbergii as a West African member of the “cryptacanthus-complex”. As a result the status of M. loennbergii remained unclear. A detailed study of the meristic, morphometric and colour pattern data was undertaken. The type material of M. loennbergii and M. decorsei revealed to be meristically very similar. Further, the holotype of M. cryptacanthus is meristically somewhat different from the type material of both M. loennbergii and M. decorsei. Nevertheless, these meristic differences are here interpreted as geographical (river basin) intraspecific variation. In addition, morphometrically the type material of all three nominal species is very similar. Therefore, both M. loennbergii and M. decorsei are considered junior synonyms of M. cryptacanthus.

Brycinus kinsleyae is close to Brycinus taeniurus and Brycinus opisthotaenia. The body has a clearly wider band than the former. This dark band starts less far forward than in B. opisthotaenia, originating slightly posterior to vertical through dorsal fin origin in B. kinsleyae but originating at a vertical through the dorsal fin origin in B. opisthotaenia.
Cited by Bishai and Khalil (1997) as Raiamas loati. It may be recorded as Raiamas loati because these two are vicariant forms and may not be truly quite distinct.
Subgenus (Chromaphyosemion).
Belanoglanis nudipectus could be a valid species, known from the Lower Congo rapids (Stiassny, M., pers. obs.).
This species is under revision, and is possibly a species complex.

This species has long been known as Ctenopoma pellegrini (Boulenger) (or Anabas pellegrini). The holotype of that species is conspecific with the types of C. nigropannosum which has priority (and in the literature has most commonly been applied to the preceding species, correctly named C. gabonense).

Teugels et al. (1992) noted that specimens from the upper Cross River seemed to differ from other known specimens. Further investigations and a comparison with the type of Chiloglanis niger are necessary.

The identification of the specimens from the Kouilou must be regarded as tentative. There are clear differences between the specimens from the Kouilolu and those from the Congo. Additional collections and study are needed to make this determination with greater confidence. (Stiassny et al., 2007).

Two subspecies are currently recognized of Chromidotilapia guntheri (Trewavas, 1974) and in the absence of a thorough revisional study we maintain them both here but note that we are unable to discern any trenchant morphological differences between the two subspecies and future work may result in their synonymy.
The name ‘scheeli’ has frequently, and erroneously, been used for the species here identified as Poropanchax stigmatopygus.

Labeo weeksii most closely resembles Labeo lineatus and is only dubiously distinct from that species (Reid 1985). Three specimens of Labeo lineatus proved to be Labeo weeksii (Tshibwabwa and Teugels 1995).
Subgenus (Rheoglanis)
Sometimes misspelled as Malapterurus electricus.
Taxonomy of this group is in need of revision. Current species limits are poorly defined.
Subgenus (Diapteron).

Mastacembelus signatus Boulenger, 1905 was originally described on a single specimen originating from “Lake Bangwelo” (see Boulenger, 1911) (Upper Congo River basin, DRC). Further, both M. trispinosus Steindachner, 1911 and M. catchpolei Fowler, 1936 were originally described and are only known by their holotype, respectively originating from “aus dem Ituriflusse bei Mawambi” and “Tinda tributary of Shari-Ituri in Bunia region...” (both situated in the Middle Congo River basin, DRC).
A detailed study of the meristic, morphometric and colour pattern data of the holotype of these nominal species revealed that they fall well within the variation ranges observed for M. congicus. Therefore, these species are considered junior synonyms of M. congicus.
Easily confused with Distichodus niloticus except in the number of scales between the origin of dorsal fin and lateral line. It is 18-21 in D. niloticus while it is 15-17 in D. rostratus.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
Also reported as Barilius niloticus (old binomen) (Seegers et al., 2004),

authority: (Taverne, Thys van den Audenaerde, Heymer & Géry, 1977)

taxonomicNotes: All Polypterus are under revision.
It is possibly the same species as Nannocharax fasciatus.
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
The genus is currently undergoing taxonomic revision (Escobar and Stiassny).
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
The taxonomy of Labeo fulakariensis needs to be reviewed.

Lambert (1961) divided Epiplatys chevalieri into two subspecies, Epiplatys chevalieri chevalieri and Epiplatys chevalieri nigricans. The subspecies distinction was based mainly on relative body depth; the former being deeper than the latter. Based on observed variations in populations in eastern Congo, Huber (1979) regarded these two subspecies as a single taxon. Scheel (1990) considered them to be distinct species, but with some reservation. The present author prefers to regard them as subspecies, based on the common presence of a dark longitudinal band in all populations of the Congo River (=Epiplatys chevalieri nigricans) , which is absent in populations found west of the Congo River (=Epiplatys chevalieri chevalieri). The red lines on the sides of these subspecies also constitute a distinguishing feature. On Epiplatys chevalieri nigricans these comprise rows of distinct red spots, whereas on Epiplatys chevalieri chevalieri the lines consist of partially fused red spots. Populations on the west and north of the Congo River are here regarded as Epiplatys chevalieri chevalieri, while those found to the east of the Congo River represent Epiplatys chevalieri nigricans. It is realized that further research is needed before a final conclusion can be drawn. (Wildekamp 1996)
Subgenus (Mesoaphyosemion).
Subgenus (Pauciradius).

Subgenus (Chromaphyosemion): Aphysemion (Chromaphyosemion) melinoides (Sonnenberg, 2007) is distinguished from its close relative Aphysemion (Chromaphyosemion) lugens by the orange colour on the throat and belly, orange in basal half of anal and dorsal fins and orange fin streamer on dorsal fin in males and orange in ventral part of caudal fin in females; the anterior or complete dorsal fin orange, orange hue on flanks of females. A. melinoides is known from several collection localities along the road from Kribi to Ebolowa between the villages Akok and Akom II and on the road from Akom II to Bipindi in southwestern Cameroon.
Brienomyrus longianalis is related to Brienomyrus brachyistius, distinguished by longer anal fin in Brienomyrus longianalis and by lower peduncle height to SL ratio.
There is very little information available about Opsaridium engrauloides.
According to the PhD thesis of Risch (1968, unpublished), Gephyroglanis gymnorhynchus is a synonym of Chrysichthys congicus.

Microsynodontis used to be one species Microsynodontis batesi. It has been split into nine species. According to Brummett, R. it is almost impossible to tell them apart and it is doubtful regarding their species status (pers. comm. Brummett, R. and Reid, G. McG.).
Subgenus (Chromaphyosemion).

Microsynodontis used to be one species Microsynodontis batesi. It has been split into nine species. According to Brummett, R. it is almost impossible to tell them apart and it is doubtful regarding their species status (pers. comm. Brummett, R. and Reid, G. McG.).
Recent molecular analyses indicate that Pantodon buchholzi is heterospecific (Lavoué in lit.) and further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomy and distribution of this species complex.
Very similar to rare but earlier described P. aequatorialis: all records of latter should be reassessed.
P. bredoi and P. xanthus are synonyms (Dijkstra unpubl.). This species is very similar to P. cognatus (Rambur, 1842).
N. anaci and N. verschuereni, from north-east and west Congo-Kinshasa respectively, are synonyms (Dijkstra unpubl.).
Often considered a subspecies of T. africana.
L. erythra is synonymous (Parr 1974).
Confused with P. sophia by Gambles (1979).
Subspecies radix of C. glauca was raised to species level by Dijkstra (2003).
Might be confused with Elattoneura lliba (Dijkstra unpubl.).
Subspecies couturieri is based on a single female from Tai Forest in Cote d'Ivoire, and may be just a variation.
Formerly treated as A. biordinata, but pertains to a new species.
See Dijkstra (2003) about synonymy of Pseudagrion coeruleiceps.
This species is very similar to the more common but more recently described P. hervei: all records should be reassessed.
Isomecocnemis is a synonym of Chlorocnemis (Dijkstra unpubl.).
The validity of Z. occidentis and its generic placement is demonstrated by Dijkstra et al. (2006).
Possibly con-specific with N. uelensis.
Similar to P. cognatus and P. serrulatus, and the taxonomy is therefore confused.
Synonymy is discussed by Dijkstra et al. (2006).

Graf and Cummings (2006) pulled this species from the synonymy of Coelatura gabonensis without having seen the types of Zairia disciformis Rochebrune, 1886 and Pharaonia bourguignati Rochebrune, 1886 (both unfigured and in the MNHN). Those types have since been examined and found to be synonymous with C. rotula. P. bourguignati is a secondary junior homonym of Unio bourguignati Landrin, 1864, so the proper name for this species, following a complete revision, would be Coelatura disciformis.
Formerly placed in family Thiaridae, but this genus is now tentatively placed in Paludomidae along with Cleopatra until further genetic analysis can confirm the appropriate family for this genus.
Taxonomic status under revision.
This species is poorly known. Mandahl-Barth (1988) treated M. joubini as a synonym of M. rostrata, but it was recognized as valid by Daget (1998).

Species in the genus Burnipia are in need of taxonomic revision; the number of species is highly uncertain, with many founded on shell differences, but probably only a few are really distinct (Brown 1994).

Species in the genus Burnipia are in need of taxonomic revision; the number of species is highly uncertain, with many founded on shell differences, but probably only a few are really distinct (Brown 1994).
Originally placed in Cleopatra. Brown (1994) was uncertain of the genus.
Formerly placed in family Thiaridae, this genus is now placed in Paludomidae.
The genus is in need of revision.

The taxonomic history of this species is complicated. Haas (1936, 1969) consider Mutela mabilli to be a synonym of Mutela dubia, and Mandahl-Barth (1998) treated it as a synonym of Mutela rostrata. Daget (1998), however, recognized three separate species: M. rostrata, M. mabilli and M. iris Pilsbry and Bequaert, 1927. M. mabilli has also been listed as occurring the Okavango and Zambezi rivers, but those populations have been transferred to M. zambesiensis Mandahl-Barth 1988 (Appleton 1996). The species concept applied here is that of Graf and Cummings (2006), which synonymises M. mabilli and M. iris.

Species in the genus Burnupia are in need of taxonomic revision; the number of species is highly uncertain, with many founded on shell differences, but probably only a few are really distinct (Brown 1994).
Formerly placed in family Thiaridae, this genus is now placed in Paludomidae.
Although Vinundu are common species, they were not recognized until recently as historical sampling was largely with dredges and these are mostly found on rocks in deep water.
Formerly placed in family Thiaridae, this genus is now placed in Paludomidae.
Coelatura kipopoensis is poorly known, and its relationships to the other Coelatura of the upper Congo are not known.
This species may not be in the genus Hydrobria but anatomical material is not available.
Formerly placed in family Thiaridae, but this genus is now tentatively placed in Paludomidae along with Cleopatra until further genetic analysis can confirm the appropriate family for this genus.
Further taxonomic work is required on this species.
Both Mandahl-Barth (1988) and Daget (1998) regarded Mutela langi as a synonym of M. rostrata. However, Graf regards Mutela langi as morphologically distinct, but based on limited shell data.
The taxonomic view of Graf & Cummings (2019) is here followed, placing all references of Coelatura gabonensis from West Africa under C. aegyptiaca..
This species has also been referred to as Mutela carrei (Putzeys 1898) in recent literature. Both Mandahl-Barth (1988) and Daget (1998) regarded Mutela legumen as a synonym of M. rostrata.
Brown (1994) notes that these have not been studied anatomically and their generic status is solely on shell characters.

This is a poorly characterized species, known only from the original type material, described by Frierson (1913) from the Lobo (or Lobé) and Nyang (or Nyong) rivers in Cameroon. Haas (1936) created the new genus Afroparreysia for it. Recent studies (Whelan et al., 2011) indicate that the genus Coelatura is paraphyletic and that a revision, correcting the erroneous former lumping, is needed. It is possible that the genus name Afroparreysia will be reinstituted.
Formerly placed in family Thiaridae, this genus is now placed in Paludomidae.
The taxonomy of this species is questionable. Perhaps asexual reproduction (clonal lineages).
This species is possibly related to M. recticosta (Brown 1994), but Brown maintained it as a separate species.
Formerly placed in family Thiaridae, this genus is now placed in Paludomidae.
Aspatharia semicorrugata has been confused with both Aspatharia rugifera and A. pfeifferiana in the Congo Basin.
Further taxonomic work may be needed for this species; it may need to be re-transferred back to Cleopatra (Glaubrecht and Strong 2007).

Species in the genus Burnipia are in need of taxonomic revision; the number of species is highly uncertain, with many founded on shell differences, but probably only a few are really distinct (Brown 1994).
Galatea congica is often confused with Galatea paradoxa. A revision of the genus needs to establish if both species are distinctive or not.

Perhaps asexual reproduction (clonal lineages). For the purposes of this assessment, Melanoides kisangani and M. langi are both included as forms of M. nsendweensis, based on information from Jenner et al. (2004) and Sorensen et al. 2005. Further taxonomic work is required to confirm whether langi and kisangani are valid species or not.
Three Tomichia species are recorded in Central Africa, but these are of uncertain generic position (Brown 1994).

This brackish water species was described by Philippi in 1851 from an unknown locality. Pilsbry & Bequaert (1927) recorded G. tenuicula langi from the mouth of the Congo river.
The former IUCN  rationale that the species still was recorded around 1970 is incorrect. It is just listed by Richard & Old (1969) as being part of the Smithsonian collection, containing Pilsbry and Bequaert's material used in their 1927 publication. .

The taxonomy of the genus Galatea (Donacidae) is unresolved and such brackish water donacids are usually wide spread or very common where they occur, but there are no mentions anymore of this species after the early 20th Century.
Due to the minute differences in shell characteristics, the taxonomy of species of the genus Ceratophallus needs to be revised and to be based on molecular differences.
The spelling of the specific name was corrected from irridescens to iridescens.

This is a poorly characterized species, known for sure only from the types and scant other material of questionable quality. The only other species recognized in Nyassunio is N. nyassaensis (Lea 1864) from Lake Malawi (Daget 1998).
Herb annual or perennial aquatic. Roots usually flattened, thalloid or filiform. Leaves distichous scattered or imbricated ; Flower bisexual, solitary actinomorphic or zygomorphic.
Robust perennial grass growing in clumps, short rhizomes, attains a height of 200 cm.

Type: Mann 1847, Bates 511 (syn- K)

The common names are extracted from Flore du Gabon, Acanthaceae vol. 13, and the language is not mentioned.
Probably a synonym of X. angustifolia ( M. Lock pers. comm. 2008).
A simple or branched erect herb to 45 cm high of wet places.
Type: Ledermann 1185, Cameroon (holo- B)
Strongly suspected that I. spinulospora is a synonym of I. biafrana, included in Flora of Cameroon. This species also occurs in Equatorial Guinea and Cameroon.
Lectotype (Nicolson, 1962): Zenker 4182 Cameroon (B).
Type: Raynal J. & A. 10543, Cameroun (holo- P).

The African Plants Database (www.ville-ge.ch/musinfo/bd/cjb/africa/details.php?langue=an&id=109138) treat this taxon as being conspecific with Rotala capensis (Harv.) A.Fern. & Diniz. If this is correct, then this assessment will no longer be valid.
Type: Teuscz in von Mechow's Expedition 506, Zaire (holo- M, iso- G)

Type: Soyaux 454, Sibange-Farm, Gabon (holo- B†).
For B. debilis, type: Bates 350, Efulen, Cameroun (holo- K)
Type: Zenker 1050, Cameroun (holo- B, iso-G, K, L, M, U, Z)
Type: A. Bruneel s.n., Bolombo river near Loka, Congo (holo- BR)
Type: Mildbraed 7749a, dans le Nyong pres Mbalmayo, Cameroon (holo- B, iso- U)
Type: Seret 669, Zaire (holo- BR).
Type: G. Le Testu 6539, Gabon, Ndenga (holo- P).
An annual erect herb, branching from base, to 45 cm high
Lectotype (Nicolson, 1962): Staudt 32, Cameroon (B).
Type: Ledermann 440, Cameroon (holo- B)

Branched caulescent herb ; lower leaves scale-like, minute, needle-like or linear ; upper leaves linear -subulate, sheathing at the base, exstipulate, up to 14 mm long ; spathellae at the end of branches, ovoid, about 2.75 mm long ; pedicel 2 mm becoming up to 8 mm long ; tepals acicular, 0.6 mm longand 0.7 mm broad ; ovary ellipsoid or oboid, 1.75 mm long slightly 8-ribbed ; capsule ellipsoid, 1.75 mm long, valves equal 3-ribbed excepting the thin marginal commissural ribs.
Type: Mildbraed 5951, Cameroo (holo- B)
Type: Ledermann 221, Grand Batanga near Kribi, Lobe waterfall, Cameroon (holo-B, iso-U)
Type: Bates 494, Gabon, Mabam, Como river (holo- K, iso- P).
Syntypes: Zehnder 259, 260, 262, 266, 272, 273, 274, Sanaga Waterfalls, Edea, Cameroon. ZT
Type: Schmitz 935 (holo- )

Recent molecular phylogenetic analyses (Schmitz et al. 2005) clarify the evolutionary relationships of the skinks of the genus Panaspis and show that Panaspis togoensis is highly distinct from P. breviceps (of which it considered a subspecies in some accounts e.g. Loveridge 1952, Grandison 1965) .
There is some debate over whether the genus Musculium should in fact change to Sphaerium with Musculium becoming demoted to subgenus level (Lee and O'Foighil 2003).

This species has gone through several taxonomic changes:
Coelatura acuminata (Adams, 1866)
Nodularia acuminata (Simpson, 1900)
Unio acuminatus (Simpson, 1914)
Nitia acuminata (Haas 1969)
Note this name is not currently in use, however is likely to be resurrected in revision (West et al. 2003)

Quite recently it was proposed that all Gnetum species should be changed to Thoa, except two Asiatic species, mainly based on seedcoat structure. The Thoa species are now synonyms (Doweld 2000, Schippers 2004).
In 2000, Doweld proposed that all Gnetum species should be changed to Thoa, except two Asiatic species, mainly based on seedcoat structure.
The taxonomic status of the morphologically distinct Congo-Brazzaville population needs further investigation.

The genera Gynura and Crassocephalum have been confused in Africa, particularly by Bentham who believed them to be synonymous. This led to the Vienna Congress 1905 conserving Gynura over Crassocephalum, but Cassini’s original descriptions and observations are clear in delimiting the two genera. Crassocephalum style arms are similar to those of Gynura, but the appendages are shorter, asymmetrical and with a tuft of papillae at the junction of style-arm and appendage. Occasionally Gynura specimens appear to have this kind of style arm but this is a result of damage to the exposed organs and the style-arms remaining inside florets at the bud stage prove to be normal. The significant differences between the two editions of Flora of Tropical West Africa for these two genera highlight the problems that have occurred, including confusion concerning the determination and allocation of specimens to the appropriate species.

Note that West and Michel (2000) found very close relationship between Stanleya and Tanganyicia with genetic data, such that West (pers. comm.) proposed combining the two genera. This is under debate, with counter evidence from E. Strong and co-authors.

Only known and recorded from Lake Albert. It is considered endemic to this lake.
Note: the type locality for this species is not Lake Victoria as originally reported; which is rather misleading for a species only known from Lake Albert. (Mandahl-Barth 1954 and Verdcourt 1992)
Perhaps a lacustrine form of B. pfeifferi (Brown 1994). B. tchadiensis is marked as ' taxon inquirendum' in WoRMS, meaning that its taxonomic status is still uncertain and under investigation.
See Dijkstra (2003) about the synonymy of Pseudagrion angelicum.

Bulinus camerunensis from Cameroon is considered as a distinct species, but  Bulinus populations were recently discovered in Nigeria that were morphologically identified as B. camerunensis (Salawu & Odaibo, 2014) but appear genetically to belong to B. forskalii (Akinwale et al., 2015).
Better knowledge of the anatomy of snails from the type locality is needed for a better understanding of this taxon (Brown 1994).
Includes T. beguei Aubrev. & Pellegr. (previously listed as VU) and T. preussii Engl.

Subsequent to this assessment, D. Goyder (pers. comm.) has confirmed that this species does not occur in Tanzania. The collections from the Ulugurus are a different species. Hence this species needs to be reassessed with the Tanzania records excluded. Apparently, the FTEA account now has this as a synonym of T. anomala.

Closely related to M. tedliei (Oliv. & Hiern) C.D.Adams (also of Mt Cameroon, but extending to Upper Guinea, Kivu and Rwanda) and also closely related to M. paniculata Milne-Redh. of Ogoja and Sao Tome, this taxon was only segregated by Adams in 1957.
Synonym = Calancoba lophocarpa (Oliv) Gilg.
Synonym = Crudia sp. A. of FWTA (1: 467) 1958 pro parte.

Whilst several names in Ardisia of Gilg and Schellenberg have been reduced to synonymy, A. oligantha and A. schlechteri have not. They are accepted by both the latest reviewers of African Ardisia, i.e. de Wit in 1957, and more recently by Taton, and so must be accepted as good species, despite the fact that they are only known from the types, now presumed destroyed. The only specimen of this species known was Weberbauer 94. Detailed locality data is unavailable; in this respect, the protologue states only "am Kamerunberg (Weberbauer n 48...Bluh 1906)".

Taton rejects Hepper’s conjecture (FWTA 2: 31) that Olorunfemi in FHI 30692 might be considered of this species. This leaves of Ardisia schlechteri in the same position as A. oligantha, i.e. known only from the destroyed type, albeit with more locality data. Schlechter 12417 was collected at Bibundi.
Synonym = Embelia sp. aff. welwitschii (Hiern) K. Schum. of FWTA 2: 32.
Including P. vaccinifolia C.DC.

This species was erroneously identified as C. simensis A. Rich. by Clarke, and so overlooked by him as a new species, although Mann had collected it as early as Dec 1862 (Mann 2099). Schumann described C. preussii 35 years later.
Treated as a variety of B. resupinatum Ridl. by Vermeulen.
Treated as a variety of B. cochleatum Lindl. by Vermeulen.
Treated in synonymy of the widespread B. josephii by Vermeulen.

Leaves up to 2 mm long ; spathellae solitary at the end of short congested leafy shoots, about 2.5 mm long ; pedicel 2 mm (in fruit 3 mm) long ; filaments about 0.5 mm long ; andropodium about 0.5 mm long ; anthers 0.75 mm long ; ovary about 1.5 mm long ; gynophore about 0.5 mm long ; stigmas botuliform, about 0.5 mm long ; capsules 1.5 mm long.
An annual or perennial aquatic herb. Roots flattened, thalloid or filiform. Leaves distichous  scattered or imbricated. Flower bisexual solitary. Fruit a septicidal capsule seeds numerous.
Was in the 2000-2003 Red Lists incorrectly as Chassalia laikomemsis (note incorrect spelling of specific name).
Previously treated as a subspecies of Papio hamadryas, but now generally raised to specific level (Kingdon 1997; Groves 2001, 2005; Grubb et al. 2003).

Genetic analysis has identified C. grandiceps forms a sister complex with Crocidura buettikoferi and C. theresae (Jacquet et al. 2012). Genetic analysis of historic samples has indicated misidentification between this species and C. wimmeri (Vogel et al. 2014).
The specific name was incorrectly spelt as marungiensis in the 2004 Red List and in the Cycad Action Plan (Donaldson 2003).

Cercocebus chrysogaster is poorly known. There are no detailed studies of the species, which is documented by fewer than 20 specimens (Ehardt and Butynksi 2013). The species has alternately been assigned as a subspecies of Cercocebus agilis or Cercocebus galeritus but retained as a separate species by Groves (2005). The species range currently consists of two allopatric populations. The western population and eastern population are reported to have differences in pelage (Groves 1978). Photographs suggest that western animals are more brightly coloured than eastern animals (J. Hart unpublished data 2010). Occurrence of outliers in the original description of the species’ range may be attributed to records of captive animals that originated from other areas (Groves 1978, Gautier-Hion et al. 1999).
Grubb et al. (2003), Kingdon (2001) and Groves (2005) all recognize two subspecies: C. e. camerunensis (from between the Cross/Benue and Sanaga Rivers), and C. e. erythrotis (endemic to Bioko).
Monotypic species. It belongs to the Cercopithecus mona superspecies.
Synonym = Psychotria malchairi De Wild.

Bott (1955) treated this taxon as Potamonautes (Platythelphusa) armata armata. Coulter (1991) treated it as Potamonautes (Platythelphusa) armata. The revisions by Cumberlidge (1997, 1999) and Cumberlidge et al. (1999), revived the genus Platythelphusa, and referred this species to Platythelphusa armata. Cumberlidge (1999), Cumberlidge et al. (1999) and Marijnissen et al. (2004) recognised nine species in the genus, all of which are endemic to Lake Tanganyika. This genus was formerly assigned to the Platythelphusidae (Cumberlidge 1999, Cumberlidge et al. 1999, Marijnissen et al. 2004). It was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Potamonautinae by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).

Bott (1955) treated this taxon as Potamonautes (Platythelphusa) armata conculcata. Coulter (1991) treated this taxon as Potamonautes (Platythelphusa) conculcata. The revisions by Cumberlidge (1997, 1999) and Cumberlidge et al. (1999), revived the genus Platythelphusa, and referred this species to Platythelphusa conculcata. Cumberlidge(1999), Cumberlidge et al. (1999) and Marijnissen et al. (2004) recognised nine species in the genus, all of which are endemic to Lake Tanganyika. This genus was formerly assigned to the Platythelphusidae (Cumberlidge 1999, Cumberlidge et al. 1999, Marijnissen et al. 2004). It was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Potamonautinae by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).

Chambardia wissmanni has been frequently confused with Chambardia rubens and in certain treatments, the two species are considered synonymous (e.g. Leloup 1950, Mandahl-Barth 1968, Haas 1969). We follow the taxonomy of Graf & Cummings (2019) who consider the two species as distinct and with a different distribution, overlapping in western Africa.
Note potential for mis-ID with Burnupia caffra, as difference is shell sculpture is subtle.

The taxonomy of Lavigeria is currently under large-scale revision. Existing taxonomy (Brown 1994) recognizes only two species (L. grandis and L. nassa), however revision (Michel and Todd in prep) will include approximately 43 species. Included here are a few of the name-bearing taxa whose names (from older literature, but not always consistently applied) have been used in relatively recent literature and are included in West et al. (2003). West et al. 2003 includes 20 Lavigeria species, Michel et al. 2004 includes 28 species. Extensive ecological information is available on a number of Lavigeria species, especially in the Kigoma, Tanzania region. (E. Michel, pers. comm.) Lavigera paucicostata is not well defined and past uses of the name are likely to be in error according to current taxonomy.
The spelling of the generic name was corrected from Bridouxiana to Bridouxia.
The spelling of the generic name was corrected from Bridouxiana to Bridouxia.
Species taxonomic status is not very clear i.e. its differentiation from Broudouxia grandidieriana (Bourguignat 1885) is very difficult.
The spelling of the generic name was corrected from Bridouxiana to Bridouxia.
The spelling of the generic name was corrected from Bridouxiana to Bridouxia.

The taxonomy of Lavigera is currently under large-scale revision. Existing taxonomy (Brown 1994) recognizes only two species (L. grandis and L. nassa), however revision (Michel and Todd, in prep.) will include approximately 43 species. Included here are a few of the name-bearing taxa whose names (from older literature, but not always consistently applied) have been used in relatively recent literature and are included in West et al. (2003). West et al. 2003 includes 20 Lavigera species, Michel et al. 2004 includes 28 species. Extensive ecological information is available on a number of Lavigera species, especially in the Kigoma, Tanzania region. Lavigera coronata is the largest Lavigera, a very distinctive species and not likely to be confused with congeners (E. Michel, pers. comm.).

Coulter (1991) treated this taxon as Potamonautes (Platythelphusa) polita. This genus was formerly assigned (Cumberlidge 1999, Cumberlidge et al. 1999, Marijnissen et al. 2004) to the Platythelphusidae. It was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Potamonautinae by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Rotundopotamonautes) didieri. It is listed here as Potamonautes didieri.
Bott (1955) treated this taxon as Potamonautes (Lobopotamonautes) perparvus gonocristatus Bott, 1955. It is recognised here as the valid species Potamonautes gonocristatus.
Bott (1955) treated this species as a junior synonym of Potamon (Geothelphsua) granviki Colosi, 1924. It is recognised here as Potamonautes idjiwiensis.

Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Lirrangapotamonautes) johnstoni johnstoni. Cumberlidge (1997, 1998) and Reed and Cumberlidge (2006) referred to this species as Potamonautes johnstoni.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Tripotamonautes) loveridgei. Cumberlidge (1998) and Reed and Cumberlidge (2006) referred to this species as Potamonautes loveridgei.

Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Platypotamonautes) platynotus. Cumberlidge (1998) and Cumberlidge et al. (1999), and Reed & Cumberlidge (2006) referred to this species as Potamonautes platynotus.
Originally named as a subspecies of R. clivosus.
This taxon was initially included within Rhinolophus maclaudi by Koopman (1993), but has more recently been recognized as a valid species (see Fahr et al. 2002, Csorba et al. 2003 and Simmons 2005).
Taxonomy needs revision. Previously considered within Pipistrellus.
Synonym = Rhynchostigma racemosum Benth.
syn. Myrica arborea Hutch.

Treated by some authorities under Gomphia.

[[Note: probably needs to be sunk under C. oliveri]]
Type: Ledermann 6328a, Cameroon (lecto- B, iso- BM, U)

Recent molecular studies (Simpson et al. 2003) have cast doubt over the separation of the genus Hypolytrum from Mapania; future, more detailed, work may support their amalgamation into a single genus.
This taxon was originally published in error under the later homonym Habenaria praetermissa la Croix (Kew Bulletin 48(2): 371 (1993)) but was corrected in Kew Bulletin 51(2): 364 (1996).

The specimen of this species cited in the Flora of West Tropical Africa (Hepper 1968) from Mont Momi, Ivory Coast is now considered to be Bulbophyllum bidenticulatum subsp. bidenticulatum (Onana and Cheek 2011).

Grubb et al. (2003) and Groves (2001, 2005) recognize six subspecies (with one undescribed ssp from the Mahale Mountains in Tanzania): C. a. angolensis Sclater’s Angola Colobus; C. a. cordieri Cordier’s Angola Colobus; C. a. cottoni Powell-Cotton’s Angola Colobus; C. a. palliatus Peters’ Angola Colobus; C. a. prigoginei Prigogine’s Angola Colobus; and C. a. ruwenzorii Adolf Friedrichs’s Angola Colobus.

Grubb et al. (2003) list two subspecies: C. s. satanas from Bioko, and C. s. anthracinus from the mainland.

Groves (2001, 2007) listed Colobus satanas anthracinus from Gabon (see Gautier-Hion et al. 1999) as a junior synonym of Colobus satanas (which occurs on Bioko Island). Groves (2005) and Grubb et al. (2003), however, listed it as a valid subspecies. Oates et al. (2000) found that the loud calls (roar pulse rate) of the two forms were significantly distinct (lower in C. s. satanas).
Recent and ongoing phylogenetic work demonstrates that this taxon likely represents two species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. D. Blackburn pers.comm.).

Hylambates rufus aubryioides was elevated from the subspecies level of Leptopelis modestus and made a senior synonym of Leptopelis omissus by Köhler (2009), which has led to this species concept of Leptopelis aubryoides.

This species is referred to as Leptopelis sp. 1 in Amiet (1983) and as Leptopelis sp. aff. calcaratus in Largen and Dowsett-Lemaire (1991).

This name name probably covers more than one species (Schiøtz 1999). The population in western Kenya previously assigned to this species was recently described as a new species, Leptopelis mackayi (Köhler et al. 2006). It is possible that the populations in the east of the Democratic Republic of Congo refer to L. mackayi, or to an undescribed species.
Petropedetes newtoni was synonymised with this species (Barej et al. 2010), however it has now been resurrected from synonymy (Sánchez-Vialas et al. 2018).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and P. vulpiae (Barej et al. 2010). Also, this species was synonymized with P. johsntoni (Barej et al. 2010) until its revalidation as a distinct species by Sánchez-Vialas et al. (2018).

Channing and Howell (2006) and Pickersgill (2007) treated the East African X.l. victorianus as a species in its own right, and we follow that arrangement. However, this leaves the odd situation of X. laevis being a southern African species, but with an isolated subspecies, X.l. sudanensis, in north-central Africa (which probably also needs to be recognized as a full species). Populations of X. laevis from the Cape of South Africa are genetically differentiated from populations elsewhere across Africa.

Changed from Aethiothemis watulikii Pinhey, 1962 to A. basilewskyi Fraser, 1954 for 2005 Red List. A. watulikii was described on the basis of minor colour differences to A. basilewskyi, which do not support an own species status (Dijkstra 2007). Both basilewskyi and watulikii pertain to a slender, dark Aethiothemis species, known from limited material from the Congo basin.

Pseudagrion quadrioculatum is conspecific with P. superbum. The latter was regarded synonymous with P. serrulatum by (Pinhey 1964), from which it only differs in minor details of markings (Dijkstra in prep).
There is some confusion over recent taxonomic changes for this species.

Originally described as Disparoneura cellularis Grünberg, 1902. It was "referred with some doubt to Isomecocnemis" by Cowley (1936) (Dijkstra 2007). Pinhey (1962a) considered the species as belonging to Elattoneura. Dijkstra (2007) confirms that the species belongs to Elattoneura. The male holotype is held at ZMH, Berlin.
The dark form, P. impedita, occurs in the highlands of Mozambique, Malawi and Zimbabwe.
Synonyms = Phyllogomphus selysi sensu Fraser, 1957; P. dundomajoricus Fraser, 1957; P. dundominusculus Fraser, 1957.
Originally described as Micromacromia, but moved to Neodythemis (Dijkstra and Vick 2006). Synonymy and generic placement is discussed by Dijkstra and Vick (2006).
Previously placed in Allorrhizucha (Dijkstra and Vick 2006).
Possible synonym = Phyllomacromia onerata (Martin, 1907).
The taxonomy of Onychogomphus near O. supinus is extremely difficult and all records of similar taxa are combined here, including Legrand's (2003) O. quirkii.
Paragomphus bredoi (Schouteden, 1934) is most likely a synonym of P. serrulatus (Dijkstra unpub. data).
Some questions over the status of the species (very similar to Paragomphus elpidius).

Trithemis imitata Pinhey, 1961 and T. monardi Ris, 1931 are very similar species, with rather relative differences in markings. Their taxonomy needs to be resolved in a geographic perspective. Most T. imitata and T. monardi records appear to be from North and South of the Equator respectively (see also Dijkstra 2007). For the time being T. imitata is regarded as a synonym to T. monardi.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". P. assegaii is a B-group species.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". Pseudagrion coelestis is a B-group species.
B-group. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B".
A-group. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B".
Some records were misidentifications. The taxonomic confusion was recently solved by Dijkstra (in prep.).
The taxonomic status of the Kenyan subpopulations is uncertain and needs detailed study.
Similar to D. selysi of Congo Basin, but probably distinct (Dijkstra unpubl.).

This species has been commonly referred to as Schilbe (Eutropius) niloticus. As indicated above, morphological examination of the holotype of Silurus mystus Linneaus, 1758 (De Vos & Skelton, 1990) indicates that that specimen and S. (E.) niloticus (Rüppell, 1829) belong to the same species. As a result the older name, S. mystus is the correct replacement name for S. niloticus. Cited by Bishai and Khalil (1997) as Schilbe (Schilbe) mytus (Linnaeus, 1758).
Previously also reported as Hypsopanchax deprimozi Pellegrin, 1928, a junior synonym.
Vreven (accepted) placed the African genera Caecomastacembelus and Aethiomastacembelus in synonymy with Mastacembelus.
Vreven (accepted) placed the African genera Caecomastacembelus and Aethiomastacembelus in synonymy with Mastacembelus.
Vreven (accepted) placed the African genera Caecomastacembelus and Aethiomastacembelus in synonymy with Mastacembelus.
Vreven (accepted) placed the African genera Caecomastacembelus and Aethiomastacembelus in synonymy with Mastacembelus.
Vreven (accepted) placed the African genera Caecomastacembelus and Aethiomastacembelus in synonymy with Mastacembelus.
Vreven (accepted) placed the African genera Caecomastacembelus and Aethiomastacembelus in synonymy with Mastacembelus.
Vreven (accepted) placed the African genera Caecomastacembelus and Aethiomastacembelus in synonymy with Mastacembelus.
Vreven (accepted) placed the African genera Caecomastacembelus and Aethiomastacembelus in synonymy with Mastacembelus.
Vreven (accepted) placed the African genera Caecomastacembelus and Aethiomastacembelus in synonymy with Mastacembelus.
Vreven (accepted) placed the African genera Caecomastacembelus and Aethiomastacembelus in synonymy with Mastacembelus.
Genus Callochromis needs revision.

authority: Snoeks, De Vos & Thys Van Den Audenaerde, 1987

taxonomicNotes: Specimens identified as Haplochromis ishmaeli are from Lake Edward.

authority: Snoeks, Coenen & Thys van den Audenaerde, 1984
Snoeks, De Vos, Coenen & Thys Van Den Audenaerde, 1990
Snoeks, De Vos, Coenen & Thys van den Audenaerde, 1990

taxonomicNotes: The taxonomy of L. finalimus is unclear as it seems to be very similar to Neolamprologus caudopunctatus (Poll, 1978) and L. lemairri Boulenger, 1899.
Synonym = Microdontochromis tenuidentatus (Poll., 1951).

There is currently some discussion about the type locality of N. olivaceous. Konings (1998) also proposed that this species should be regarded as a synonym of N. pulcher. This has not been confirmed yet.
Synonym = Telotrematocara macrostoma (Poll, 1952).

Part of the distribution area of Oreochromis macrochir caused by introduction could be Oreochromis mweruensis due to wrong identifications.
Previously, O. macrochir and O. mweruensis were considered to be distinct subspecies of O. macrochir, but are now considered to be distinct at the specific level (De Vos et al. 2001).
Also reported as Tilapia leucosticta (antiquated name).

authority: De Vos, Nshombo & Thys van den Audenaerde, 1996

taxonomicNotes: T. moorri has many geographic varieties.

authority: De Vos, Risch & Thys van den Audenaerde, 1995

taxonomicNotes: Taxonomic uncertainty exists.
Taxonomic distinction probably not obvious when compared with Lates niloticus.
Vreven (accepted) placed the African genera Caecomastacembelus and Aethiomastacembelus in synonymy with Mastacembelus.

Three specimens of Labeo lineatus prove to be Labeo weeksii; another specimen considered by Reid (1985) as a paralectotype of L. lineatus, proves to be conspecific with Labeo degeni Boulenger, 1920 (Tshibwbwa and Teugels 1995).
This species occurs in three subspecies, the nominate, ssp. peuceda and ssp. penningtoni.
A-group. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B".
B-group. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B".
A-group. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B".
May be conspecific with C. apicalis.
Will become Aethiothemis coryndoni (Dijkstra unpubl.).

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". P. makabusiense is an A-group species. The taxonomy of the species is likely to requires reform.
B-group. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B".

Described from the Muza River (lower Zambezi system), central Mozambique. Numerous isolated populations exist across central African and their specific status needs to be determined. Specimens of Kneria auriculata from the Congo basin are probably not conspecific with Southern African populations. The southern populations in South Africa (Crocodile System) are clearly distinct are in the process of being described.

Species in the genus Burnupia are in need of taxonomic revision; the number of species is highly uncertain, with many founded on shell differences, but probably only a few are really distinct (Brown 1994).

Species in the genus Burnupia are in need of taxonomic revision; the number of species is highly uncertain, with many founded on shell differences, but probably only a few are really distinct (Brown 1994).
Segmentorbis planodiscus may be a synonym of S. angustus.
Formerly placed in family Thiaridae, this genus is now placed in Paludomidae.

Groves (2001) and Grubb et al. (2003) threat Erythrocebus patas as a monotypic species. Here we follow Butynski et al. (2013) and recognize three subspecies; E. p. patas, E. p. pyrrhonotus, and E. p. baumstarki.
Grubb et al. (2003) listed two subspecies of E. pallidus: E. p. pallidus from Bioko Island and E. p. talboti from Nigeria and Cameroon.

Groves (2005) lists this taxon as Galago alleni. Grubb et al. (2003) split the taxon into two subspecies: S. a. alleni from Bioko Island and S. a. cameronensis from the mainland. Groves (2001, 2005) treated these as two species.

This name applies to the former records of Trithemis donaldsoni from western Africa and Yemen (Dijkstra, 2007). The exact distributional ranges of the closely related species T. dejouxi and T. donaldsoni is unclear and needs further studies. Genetic analysis shows they are sister taxa with recent separation (Damm et al., 2010).

Aeshna ellioti is now placed in the genus Zosteraeschna (Peters and Theischinger 2011). Peters and Theischinger (2011) also proposed that the subspecies usambarica be retuned to species level as Z. usambarica.

In its wild form, Elaeis guineensis Jacq. is a primary wild relative of African Oil Palm, the cultivated form of the species. It is also a tertiary wild relative of American Oil Palm, E. oleifera (Kunth) Cortés (Vincent et al. 2013).

UAE Taxonomic Notes:
There are numerous synonyms for this species.

It is difficult to establish the relationship between plants referred to as Persicaria decipiens (mainly in Australia) and those referred to as P. salicifolia (or P. serrulata according to The Plant List). This assessment treats populations other than those in Australia as P. salicifolia and those in Australia as a different taxon.

authority: Evans, Greenbaum, Kusamba, Carter, Tobias, Mendel & Kelley, 2011
taxonomicNotes: It is considered to be the sister taxon to Xenopus vestitus (Evans et al. 2011).

Allen (1924) and Davis (1978) treated A. capensis and A. congicus as being conspecific, arguing that they represent clinal variations of the same species. However, mainly based on tooth size and skin differences, Rosevear (1974), Van Zyll de Jong (1987), Wozencraft (1993), and Larivière (2001) considered A. capensis and A. congicus as separate species, but this remains debated, and Wozencraft (2005) did not retain A. congicus as a valid species, contrary to the opinion of the IUCN SSC Otter Specialist Group (www.otterspecialistgroup.org) (Jacques et al. 2009). The name Aonyx congica is often found in the literature but A. congicus is the correct spelling as Aonyx, from the Greek onux, is masculine (Van Bree et al. 1999).
Chamaeleo laevigatus (Gray, 1863), from Central and East Africa, was previously considered to be a subspecies of C. senegalensis.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Subpopulations from Democratic Republic of the Congo, that were previously thought to belong to this species, have now been assigned to Sclerophrys channingi (Barej et al. 2011).

This is a monotypic species, believed to be closely related to the African endemic genus Nectophrynoides. This hypothesis is supported by the findings of Frost et al. (2006). Though the conclusions of relationship among those taxa closely related to D. sjostedti have come into question (compare Frost et al. 2006 to Van Bocxalaer et al. 2009), the identity and distinctiveness of this species is clear and uncontroversial.
This species is in the Arthroleptis poecilonotus species complex (Blackburn 2010).

Polystachya virginea as assessed here is taken sensu stricto; var. parva is probably a different species, and specimens of that taxon (including those cited in F.A.C.) have not been taken into account here.

Temminck originally described the African Wild Dog (hereafter Wild Dog) in 1820 from a specimen collected in coastal Mozambique, which was originally thought to be species of hyaena and was classified as Hyena picta (Creel & Creel 2002). Later, in 1930, it was placed in the subfamily Canidae (Creel & Creel 2002) and today, Wild Dogs belong to the family Canidae. DNA sequencing suggests that Wild Dogs are phylogenetically distinct from other wolf-like canids (such as wolves and jackals) (Creel & Creel 2002). Thus, they are considered to be a monotypic genus where they are the only remaining representatives of the genus Lycaon (Mills et al 1998; Creel & Creel 2002).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Hyperolius spatzi (Rödel et al. 2010).

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies (Laurent 1983; Schiøtz 1971, 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Wieczorek et al. (2000, 2001). It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this superspecies are still far from settled. Members of this superspecies, which consists of a large number of forms that are distributed, generally allopatrically, throughout the tropical African savanna, with a common morphology, voice and ecology, but with widely differing dorsal patterns. Laurent (1983) concluded that the concept of one species best expressed present knowledge, and A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) agrees with this. Wieczorek et al. (2001) carried out an analysis based on mtDNA, and separated the forms that they examined into 10 species. However, they examined only 22 out of 45 recognized "subspecies".

It is possible that Sclerophrys djohongensis is a synonym of this species (J.-L. Amiet pers. comm.). However, this synonymy is not universally accepted (D. Blackburn pers. comm. August 2012).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
Formerly placed in family Thiaridae, this genus is now placed in Paludomidae.

authority: Schick, Kielgast, Rödder, Muchai, Burger & Lötters, 2010

taxonomicNotes: Schick et al. (2010) have provided evidence that indicate this taxon is a complex of species; H. veithi has been split from the broader concept.
Records of this species from Tchabal Mbabo refer to Cardioglossa alsco.
Wolterstorffina parvipalmata is a species complex and, according to a forthcoming paper, will be split into three lineages (M. Barej and S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and P. jimzimkusi (Zimkus and Gvoždík 2013).
This species is a tetraploid species (Kobel et al. 1980).
The species was resurrected from synonymy with Afrixalus brachycnemis. This means that specimens listed under this name need to be examined.
Hyperolius constellatus was split from this species by Greenbaum et al. 2013.

There is some question as to the correct name for this species. Hyperolius alticola is usually considered to be a synonym of H. discodactylus, and the name discodactylus has priority over alticola. However, Schiøtz (1999) found the type of H. discodactylus to be indeterminable, and therefore preferred to use the name alticola. Here we use the older name, discodactylus, pending resolution of this problem. There appears to be some question as to whether or not this species is specifically distinct from Hyperolius frontalis (Schiøtz 1999). Taxonomic work on resolving this problem is ongoing (M. Menegon pers comm June 2012).

There appears to be some question as to whether or not this species is specifically distinct from Hyperolius discodactylus (Schiøtz 1999). However, there is no clear agreement on this (E. Greenbaum pers. comm. July 2014).

Uniquely among vertebrates (except Xenopus longipes), this is a dodecaploid species, and it is therefore of considerable conservation interest. It was probably formed by both hybridization and polyploidisation (Loumont and Kobel 1991).

This species is very poorly known and in need of taxonomic revision. Records from Faradje and Garamba in the savannah zone of north-eastern  Democratic Republic of Congo are probably in error, partly for  ecological reasons, and partly because Inger (1968) did not record this  species from Garamba National Park.

The systematic status of this species in relation to Crotaphatrema tchabalmbaboensis is uncertain as they could be the same species; more research is needed to clarify this relationship (T. Doherty-Bone pers. comm. October 2012).

The systematic status of this species in relation to Crotaphatrema lamottei is uncertain as they could be the same species; more research is needed to clarify this relationship (T. Doherty-Bone pers. comm. October 2012).
The taxonomy of this genus is in need of revision.
There are questions as to whether or not this is a single species (Taylor 1968).
It is not clear that the specimens from the two known localities refer to the same species.

The subspecies classification of C. guereza remains unresolved (Grubb et al. 2003). This species account provisionally follows the arrangement of Groves (2001), Grubb et al. (2003), and Fashing and Oates (2013) in recognising seven subspecies. C. caudatus is now treated as a species (Butynski and de Jong 2018).

This is a species in the Cercopithecus mona group, recognised by Gautier-Hion (2013), who followed Groves (2001, 2005).


Subspecies: C. pogonias pogonias, C. p. nigripes, C. p. grayi and a fourth, C. p. schwarzianus not recognised by Gautier-Hion (2013), but recognised by Groves (2001, 2005). Grubb et al. (2003) left the latter in synonymy. There may be a large hybrid area in the Atlantic coastal basin between the Sanaga River (Cameroon), the Ivindo River (Gabon) and the upstream tributaries of the Congo River in southeastern Cameroon (Gautier-Hion 2013). The Dja River may form part of these limits.

Cercopithecus hamlyni, along with the recently discovered Lesula (Cercopithecus lomamiensis), form a clade of highly terrestrial monkeys restricted to lowland and montane forests of eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. Outside of the DR Congo, only one small isolated population of C. hamlyni is known from western Rwanda (Easton et al 2011). Two subspecies have been named (see Grubb et al. 2003, Groves 2005, Hart et al. 2013): C. h. kahuziensis, characterized primarily by its lack of a prominent white nose stripe, is described from an area of the bamboo forest zone of Mount Kahuzi, Democratic Republic of the Congo. C. h. hamlyni, is the form found throughout the remainder of the species' range. The range of C. h. kahuziensis, purportedly limited to a very small area between 2000 and 3000 m in Kahuzi Biega National park, is poorly defined and adjoins, without evident barriers, the range of the nominate form (Maruhashi et al. 1989). Recent surveys in Kahuzi-Biega National Park identified C. h. hamlyni, with prominent white nose stripes, in areas reported to represent the range of C. h. kahuziensis (Hart and Kaleme, personal observation 2002). In addition, the nose stripe appears to be variably present in populations across the species’ range (Hart et al. 2013). The recent publication (Hart et al. 2012) of a photo of a young animal, kept as a pet, and collected east of Kisangani, about 350 km from the reported range of of C. h. kahuziensis, had no evidence of a nose stripe and resembles photographed animals described as C. h. kahuziensis in the publication of the taxon (Colyn and Rahm 1987). The subspecies, C. h. kahuziensis, is not treated further here, pending confirmation of its taxonomic status.

This account largely follows the taxonomic arrangement of Grubb et al. (2003) in recognition of subspecies. The two exceptions are the recognition of C. m. zammaranoi (following Groves 2001, 2005; Gippoliti 2006; Lawes et al. 2013).

The 2008 assessment of Cercopithecus nictitans followed the taxonomic arrangement of Grubb et al. (2003) in only recognizing two subspecies. The forms stampflii, insolitus and ludio were provisionally synonymized under the western populations of Cercopithecus nictitans martini (Grubb et al. 2003). However, it was also noted that the form on Bioko (martini) at least could have perhaps represented a distinct subspecies (J. Oates and P. Grubb pers. comm. 2008).

 

Oates (2011) recognised all the subspecies listed here: nictitans, martini, insolitus, ludio and stampflii and this treatment was followed in 2016. Gautier-Hion et al. (1999) recognized three subspecies: stampfli, martini and nictitans. Grubb et al. (2003) and Gautier-Hion (2013) recognised only C. n. nictitans and C. n. martini. Kingdon (2013) has recognised these subspecies as comprising Cluster II Cercopithecus nictitans cluster of the Nictitans Group. Cercopithecus n. insolitus and C. n. ludio were considered by Gautier-Hion (2013) and Kingdon (2013) to be synonyms of C. n. nictitans. Kingdon (2013) listed C. n. stampflii, but Gautier-Hion (2013) placed it as a synonym of C. n. martini.
Kingdon (1997), Grubb et al. (2003), Groves (2005), and Cords and Sarmiento (2013) recognise five subspecies: C. a. ascanius, C. a. atrinasus, C. a. katangae, C. a. schmidti and C. a. whitesidei.

Kingdon (1997) recognized two subspecies: C. c. cephus and C. c. cephodes. Subsequently, Colyn (1999) described the subspecies C. c. ngottoensis, which is included as a valid form in the classifications of Grubb et al. (2003) and Groves (2005). However, Grubb et al. (2003) remarked that the taxonomic status of ngottoensis needed more research because it appears to be both geographically and morphologically intermediate between C. cephus and C. ascanius. Gautier-Hion (2013) recognizes three subspecies C. c. cephus, C. c cephodes and C. c. ngottoensis.

Cercopithecus dryas is one of Africa’s least known and most enigmatic monkeys. Its nomenclature has been disputed, and its phylogenetic affinities are uncertain. The type specimen, the skull and skin of a captive juvenile male from the early 1930s, is from an unknown source population in central Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), most likely in the Lomela region in what is currently Sankuru Province (Schwarz 1932). The species was not reported again until 1977, when Kano and Kuroda acquired two hunter-killed animals in the Wamba research area 300 km north of Lomela town (Kuroda et al. 1985). One of these animals became the type specimen for a new species: Cercopithecus salongo Thys van den Audenaerde 1977. Subsequent re-examination of the C. dryas type and Wamba specimen indicated that these represented the same species with age-related differences in colouration, thus sinking salongo into dryas (Colyn et al. 1991). Sarmiento (2002) disputed this assessment. However, the current treatment follows Groves (2001, 2005), Grubb et al. (2003), Butynski (2013), and Healy (2013) in accepting the synonymy of the two forms. Following the collections by Kano and Kuroda, C. dryas was confirmed in the Kokolopori area to the east of Wamba (Lokasola 2008). Lokasola (2008) suggests that Kano and Kuroda’s 1977 specimen likely came from this same population.

In 2014, the species reappeared again, 400 km southeast of Kokolopori/Wamba near Bafundo, in Maniema Province, less than 15 km west of the Congo (Lualaba) River. Field staff from the Lukuru Foundation’s TL2 Project collected photos of a fresh hunter-killed adult female and later collected a hunter-killed adult male from this same area (Hart 2014). Subsequently, the species was seen at two sites ~31 km west of Bafundo near the Lomami River, and two sites ~75 km west of the city of Kindu (Alempijevic et al. 2018). Both sexes of the Lomami-Lualaba interfluve population are characterized by striking rufous cheeks and upper ventrum, a feature not mentioned in the published descriptions of C. dryas sensu lato, as all publications describe specimens with white- or cream-coloured facial hairs and ventrum (Schwarz 1932, Thys van den Audenaerde 1977, Kuroda et al. 1985). Nevertheless, a photo of a monkey taken in 2011 at Iyondji in the Kokolopori/Wamba region by R. Mittermeier clearly shows these animals have rufous cheeks. Subsequently, S. Kuroda (comment posted online in 2016 in Hart 2014) confirmed that his 1977 Wamba specimens looked like the Bafundo animals. Tail colouration, in particular the shape and location of the triangular dark grey ventral patch at the base of the tail, in both sexes, has also been a source of confusion (e.g. C. dryas illustration, Gautier-Hion et al. 1999). The prominent blue perineum and scrotum in adult males (Hart 2014) has not been mentioned in previous published accounts of the species, but this feature likely fades in death, as in C. lomamiensis, and may not be evident in all hunter-killed animals and dry museum skins (Hart et al. 2012). Additional field surveys and population genetics studies are needed to assess the level of variation present among known populations, as this monkey occurs in very small, widely-separated populations over a very large area, and with no evident contact between them.

Cercopithecus dryas is currently assigned to its own species group, the Cercopithecus dryas-group (Groves 2001, Butynski 2002), where it is the smallest species within the genus Cercopithecus (Butynski 2013). However, recent phylogenetic analyses based on the mitochondrial genome of the type specimen (finger tip) show C. dryas clustering within the genus Chlorocebus (Guschanski et al. 2013). Groves suggested possible affinities between C. dryas and Chlorocebus after initial assessment of the skin and skull of the type specimen (1972 pers. comm. cited in Thys van den Audenaerde 1977), however he later concluded that C. dryas is a distinct species within the genus Cercopithecus based on the cranial morphology of the type specimen and a photograph of an adult skull in Kuroda et al. (1985). Additional morphological and genetic (nuclear DNA) evidence is needed to resolve C. dryas’ position within the guenon radiation (tribe Cercopithecini).

While Grubb et al. (2003) did not list any subspecies of Lophocebus albigena, Groves (2001, 2005), building on his earlier work (Groves 1978) recognized three subspecies: L. a. albigena, L. a. johnstoni and L. a. osmani. After further studies of the cranial morphology of this group, Groves (2007) upgraded these three subspecies to species rank, and recognised a fourth, Lophocebus ugandae (Matschie 1912). This classification is followed by Mittermeier et al. (2013). However, at a Red List assessment workshop in 2016, experts from the IUCN SSC Primate Specialist Group were not in agreement about a four-species taxonomy and decided to retain a one-species, four-subspecies arrangement for the purposes of the current Red List.
Grubb et al. (2003) recognized two subspecies, L. a. aterrimus and L. a. opdenboschi, in contrast to Groves (2001, 2005) who considered the two as worthy of recognition as distinct species.

Mandrillus was regarded as a subgenus of Papio by Dandelot (in Meester and Setzer 1972) and Wolfheim (1983), but recent molecular and chromosomal analyses suggest that Mandrillus is closer to the terrestrial mangabeys Cercocebus spp. (Disotell 1993, Fleagle and McGraw 2002). Two genetically distinct populations have been noted, north and south of the Ogooué River (Telfer et al. 2003).

Machado (1969) revised the genus and clearly established the differences between Miopithecus talapoin and an unnamed species, later named by Kingdon (1997). The spelling ogouensis was used in the original description of the taxon and should therefore be retained, though it would have been preferable to have spelt it ogooueensis, because it is based on the River Ogooué (Grubb et al. 2003).
Grubb et al. (2003) treat this as a subspecies of Cercocebus galeritus, but Groves (2005) and Kingdon (2001) both treat it as a distinct taxon.

Grubb et al. (2003) treated this form as a subspecies of Cercopithecus aethiops, but it is here regarded as a distinct species, following Groves (2001, 2005) and it is now included in the genus Chlorocebus (Groves 2005, Groves and Kingdon 2013). However, because it appears to grade imperceptibly in the vervet (Chlorocebus pygerythrus) range in the northeastern, eastern and southeastern parts of its distribution, with no obvious barriers, the species’ classification is still considered problematic by some (Ansell 1978 in Sarmiento 2013 and see Sarmiento 2013 for full discussion). Generally considered monotypic, though this too requires further study.

Groves (2005) listed this taxon as Galago gabonensis, but it is retained here in Sciurocheirus following Grubb et al. (2003). The undescribed form located in the area of Foret des Abeilles near Makande, Gabon (Ambrose 2003) is now described as S. makandensis (Ambrose 2013) and assessed separately.

Grubb et al. (2003) state that there might be more than two subspecies of Euoticus elegantulus, of which the form south of the Ogooue River has not yet been named. Taxonomy reviewed in Ambrose (2013).

Grubb et al. (2003) concluded that the correct Latin name for Demidoff’s galago was demidovii, as referred to in Fischer (1808), which was written in Latin with, consequently, the latinised name of Demidoff. The epithet demidovii was used by Oates (2011), Ambrose and Butynski (2013) and Nekaris (2013). Groves (2001), however, argued that demidoff, as written by Fischer (1806), was in fact being used as a Latin binomial, and was as such the correct name for this species. This was also argued by Jenkins (1987) and Kingdon (1997), and Masters and Couette (2015) who used the name demidoff. Jenkins et al. (2018) confirmed the validity of the name demidoff Fischer. 1806.

Groves (2001, 2005) recognised six subspecies, evidently, as pointed out by Masters and Couette (2015), following the concept of geospecies proposed by Grubb (2006): the nominate subspecies in “West Africa”; the Calabar dwarf galago Galagoides demidoff murinus (Murray, 1859) in the Nigeria-Cameroon border region; the Bioko Dwarf Galago G. d. poensis (Thomas, 1904) from the island of Bioko; the Congo dwarf galago G. d. anomurus (de Pousargues, 1893) from between the Sanaga and Congo rivers; the Kasai dwarf galago G. d. phasma Cabrera and Ruxton, 1926, from the south of the Congo River; the Uele dwarf galago G. d. medius (Thomas, 1915) from the Uele-Ituri region; and an undescribed form from Lake Oku, Bamenda Highlands, Cameroon. Kingdon (1997, 2015) listed these subspecies, as did Ambrose and Butynski (2013), the latter authors considering them, however, to be “tentative and provisional” (p.460). Grubb et al. (2003) argued that Galagoides demidoff was best considered monotypic. Masters and Couette (2015) carried out a cranial and dental morphometric study of G. demidoff and G. thomasi. On the basis of this study, they found “slight but consistent morphological differences between G. demidoff and G. thomasi but could not validate the subspecies described for the former taxon” (p. 297). The Bioko form, G. d. poensis, is assessed as a separate subspecies, as is the nominate subspecies. The Bioko form, G. d. poensis, is assessed as a separate subspecies, as is the nominate subspecies.

Following its description by Elliot (1907) G. thomasi was regarded a subspecies of G. demidovii until 1979 when Olson (1979) resurrected G. thomasi to a full species based on larger body size and morphology. Masters and Couette (2015) confirm that G. thomasi and G. demidovii are different species with significant interspecific differences in the size and proportions of the skulls. G. thomasi and G. demidovii are sympatric through much of their range.
The subpopulation on the Itombwe Massif (Democratic Republic of the Congo) appears to be different and may represent a distinct taxon (Bearder 1999, Omari et al. 1999, T. Butynski pers. obs. 1996).
Grubb et al. (2003) listed four subspecies: Galago senegalensis senegalensis; G. s. braccatus; G. s. dunni, and G. s. sotikae.

Grubb et al. (2003) separated out the form O. monteiri as a distinct species. However, there is a wide area of overlap in the distribution of forms attributable to O. monteiri and O. crassicaudatus in Tanzania (Groves 2001). For the current assessment, O. monteiri is regarded as a subspecies of O. crassicaudatus based on information regarding its skull morphology (Masters and Lubinsky 1988) and karyotype (Masters 1986). Greater galago subspecies show minor differences in skull size but not in proportions, while skulls of the two recognized Otolemur species can readily be distinguished on the basis of skull proportions. O. crassicaudatus subspecies are defined mainly on pelage coloration, which is likely to be adapted to the foliage in which the animals rest during the day, rather than for specific-mate recognition. Hence, the subspecies that occupy dry forests in miombo woodlands (O. c. monteiri, O. c. argentatus) are pale in color, while those from the dune forests of KwaZulu-Natal and the montane forests of Limpopo Province (O. c. crassicaudatus) are darker.
Arctocebus aureus was originally considered a subspecies of A. calabarensis but described as a full species by Maier (1980).
Until the late 1980s, this species was commonly treated as one of two subspecies of Arctocebus calabarensis, with the other being A. c. aureus; aureus is now treated as a full species.

Recent taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either divide the red colobus and the Olive Colobus into two genera, Piliocolobus and  Procolobus respectively (e.g., Kingdon 1997, Groves 2005), or consider them to belong to one genus,  Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus  for the Olive Colobus and  Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Grubb et al. 2003 [followed in the 2008 IUCN Red List], Grubb et al. 2013). The arrangement of Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) using two separate genera is followed here.

The taxonomy of this form is complicated and is not fully resolved. Colyn (1991) suggested that P. langi and P. semlikiensis (which he referred to as subspecies of Colobus badius) of the eastern Congo Basin were major contributors to a population of polymorphic red colobus that he characterized as a large zone of intergradation between the ranges of the two taxa. Groves (2007) also recognised this, and assigned the name “ellioti” to this apparently hybrid population. Colyn (1991) and Groves (2007) both suggested that other taxa, including P. oustaleti, P. foai and P. lulindicus also contributed to this large “hybrid swarm” that is bounded in the north by the Aruwimi River (with populations of P. oustaleti ranging north of that) and to the west by P. langi and east by P. semlikiensis, without apparent barriers to dispersal separating them. Genetic surveys to determine the origins and composition of red colobus populations over this zone of intergradation, and their relation to the proposed parental forms, have not been conducted. Based on mitochondrial DNA analysis, Ting (2008) suggested that, P. langi should be considered a subspecies of P. rufomitratus, along with (among others) the forms tholloni, oustaleti, parmentieri, foai and ellioti (which he treats as the senior synonym for semlikiensis). This classification is also largely accepted by Struhsaker and Grubb (2013), who state that P. r. ellioti “probably represents a large hybrid swarm involving langi and semlikiensis”. While we use Groves’ (2007) nomenclature here, we recognise that the taxonomic status of this form is not well settled.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Oates 2011, Grubb et al. 2003). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Piliocolobus parmentieri is little known, and its classification is inconsistent due to the significant complexity and debate in the taxonomy of red colobus monkeys (Groves 2001, Grubb et al. 2003, Struhsaker 2010, Grubb et al. 2013). Colyn and Verheyen (1987) noted that parmentieri differed strongly from tholloni and placed it as a subspecies of the polytypic rufomitratus. Colyn (1991) considered the Lomami Red Colobus to have a stable phenotype, supporting a distinct taxonomic status for the population. Gautier-Hion et al. (1999) treated it as a subspecies of Procolobus pennanti [sic]. Struhsaker and Grubb (2013) on the other hand identified it as one of nine subspecies of rufomitratus: foai, langi, oustaleti, parmentieri, tephrosceles, lulindicus, ellioti (semlikiensis a synonym), and tholloni. Groves and Ting (2013) elevated seven of the nine rufomitratus subspecies to distinct species; the subspecies ellioti and lulindicus were not recognised as distinct taxa. Kingdon (2015) treated it as a subspecies of oustaleti, along with foai, langi, lulindicus, elliotiand tephrosceles. Groves (2001, 2005) treated it as a subspecies of foai, along with ellioti, oustaleti, and semlikiensis, but in his 2007 review of the taxonomy of the African colobines he classified it as a separate species. The current assessment follows Groves (2007) in recognising parmentieri as a distinct species.

Gautier-Hion et al. (1999), Groves (2001, 2005) and Kingdon (2015) altered the epithet to the plural—parmentierorum, but Groves (2007) argued that it was possible (and more expedient) to maintain parmentieri.

This species is believed to consist of at least two species (Bogart and Tandy 1981), with tetraploid populations known from the islands of Lake Victoria and from Liberia. These have not yet been formally distinguished.

Poynton (2003) placed this species in the genus Schoutedenella. There are major taxonomic problems with the genera Arthroleptis and Schoutedenella through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology. This form almost certainly includes more than one species. In addition, Arthroleptis discodactyla was recently listed as a synonym of Arthroleptis schubotzi (Frost 2013).

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology. It is possible that Arthroleptis bivittatus is a synonym of A. poecilinotus, but more field observations are needed to confirm this (Perret 1991). Populations assigned to this species clearly represent more than one species (Rödel and Bangoura 2004; Blackburn et al. 2010), with at least one found in countries ranging from eastern Nigeria and east, and the other from Ghana to the west (if not more than one species).
