This species is extremely closely related to Clarias werneri, but both should be considered as valid species (Teugels 1986). It is doubtfully distinguished from Clarias werneri according to Seegers et al. (2003).

This species is extremely closely related to Clarias alluaudi, but both should be considered as valid species (Teugels 1986). It is doubtfully distinguished from Clarias alluaudi according to Seegers et al. (2003).

A number of different spotted Barbus species have historically been misidentified as Barbus lineomaculatus. Until a thorough check has been made of the museum collections on which the distribution map is based, it must be recognised that the map contains inaccuracies. It must be noted that Enteromius lineomaculatus formerly belonged to the genus Barbus, but following the work of Yang et al. (2015) it has been changed to Enteromius (Skelton 2016).

Accepted as Trioceros ituriensis (Tilbury 2010). A new record from Kibale forest in Uganda shows that a population may exist on the eastern side of the high Rwenzori Mountains. This population should be investigated in a phylogenetic context.

authority: Verheyen, Hulsemans, Wendelen, Leirs, Corti, Backeljau & Verheyen, 2011
taxonomicNotes: This species forms part of the Acomys spinosissimus complex (Verheyen et al. 2011). Recent mtDNA analysis has resulted in A. muzei being split from A. spinosissimus, making it a distinct species within this complex, with A. ngurui being its closest relative (Verheyen et al. 2011, Monadjem et al. 2015). Acomys wilsoni is thought to co-occur with this species (Monadjem et al. 2015).

Hylomyscus anselli forms part of the Hylomyscus anselli species group which includes Hylomyscus arcimontensis, Hylomyscus kerbispeterhansi, and Hylomyscus heinrichorum (Demos et al. 2014, Carleton et al. 2015). Initially described as a subspecies of Praomys denniae by Ansell (1973), it was thought to be part of the same group as Hylomyscus denniae; it is now known to be separate (Carleton and Stanley 2005). According to current understanding each species of this group are endemic to a particular mountain system (Carleton et al. 2015).
This species previously was included within Hylomyscus alleni.

authority: W. Verheyen, Hulsemans, Dierckx, Mulungu, Leirs, Corti & E. Verheyen, 2007
taxonomicNotes: Lophuromys stanleyi is a newly described species within the L. flavopunctatus complex. It can be clearly differentiated from all other species in this genus, although it has morphological similarities with L. chrysopus. These two species form a pair with two other non-Ethiopian species in this genus: L. aquilus and L. zena (Verheyen et al. 2007).

Praomys coetzeei is a member of the P. tullbergi complex, belonging to the larger form of this which also includes, P. petteri and P. rostratus as sibling species with an allopatric distribution (Van der Straeten 2008). It is thought to occur sympatrically with Praomys jacksoni.
This species was removed from synonymy with Hyperolius nasutus by Channing et al. 2013.

Sylvisorex corbeti is another new species within the genus Sylvisorex, the composition of which is still largely unknown (Hutterer and Montermann 2009). It may be related to S. ollula, which is considerably smaller but otherwise similar (R. Hutterer pers. comm. 2017).

F. vandewoestijneae is placed with F. mechowii within the F. mechowii clade, alongside the F. bocagei clade (Van Daele et al. 2007). Historically it is thought this species is sympatric with F. mechowii, despite this no overlap in their current distribution has been established (Van Daele et al. 2013).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Cardioglossa inornata (elevated from subspecies level) (Hirschfeld et al. 2015).
Only the most relevant synonyms are listed. For a complete list of synonyms please see WCSP (2018).This species often hybridizes with Psidium guineense and is often confused with it (Landrum 2017).
Also reported as Tilapia nilotica (antiquated name).

Has been considered conspecific with Natal Red Duiker C. natalensis and also with Weyns’s Duiker C. weynsi but is separated by other authors, including Feer and Mockrin (2013), the approach followed here.

Two subspecies have been named: C. d. dorsalis in West Africa from Guinea-Bissau to Togo and C. d. castaneus from east of the Niger river in Nigeria through Central Africa to the Albertine Rift and south to northern Angola (Kingdon and Feer 2013). These forms are based on body size and pelage features, though Grubb and Groves (2001) note considerable variation in C. d. castaneus.
Two subspecies have been named, based on minor pelage and size characters: C. l. leucogaster in the western part of the distribution and C. l. arrhenii in the eastern (Hart 2013).

The recognition of Philantomba as a separate genus to Sylvicapra and Cephalophus is contentious, but recent molecular evidence supports the genus as a basal clade (van Vuuren & Robinson 2001; Johnston & Anthony 2012). Thirteen subspecies have been named (Hart & Kingdon 2013), where P. m. monticola is isolated from the others, occurring from northern KwaZulu-Natal (KZN) to the Eastern and Western Cape provinces of South Africa.

Five  subspecies have been named, the nominate form in the Congo Basin and four forms in the montane forests of eastern Africa (Grubb and Groves 2001, Plumptre 2013), including a distinctive subspecies, the Rwenzori Red Duiker (C. n. rubidus), sometimes regarded as a separate species, in the alpine and subalpine zones of the Rwenzori Mountains on the Uganda/DR Congo border.

This species probably represents a species complex of three allopatric species. Indeed, one recognized subspecies, Brooke's Duiker (C. o. brookei), from West Africa, is now often regarded as a distinct species (Grubb and Groves 2001, Grubb 2005). Treated provisionally as a single species here, following Wilson 2001 and Kingdon 2013).

Intergrades and possible hybrids with Peter's Duiker C. callipygus have been reported and further investigation is desirable.

Analysis of mtDNA found a close relationship with C. rubidus, despite differences in morphology, proportions and habitat, and a slightly closer relationship to C. harveyi and C. natalensis (Jansen van Vuuren and Robinson 2001). 

Two subspecies have been named, east and west of the Chari River, but these are not recognized by all authorities (Kingdon and Hoffmann 2013). Only the species is assessed here.
Four subspecies have been named (Kingdon and Lahm 2013).

Often treated as a subspecies of Peter’s Duiker Cephalophus callipygus (e.g. Kingdon 1982, East 1999, Wilson 2001) and has been previously lumped with Natal Red Duiker C. natalensis and Harvey's Red Duiker C. harveyi (Hart 2013).

Here it is considered a distinct species following Grubb and Groves (2001), Grubb (2005) and Hart (2013).

Three subspecies were named by Grubb and Groves (2001). Possible hybrids between C. weynsi and C. harveyi have been reported from the Mau escarpment in Kenya (Kingdon 1982).

The number of subspecies recognized has varied in the past depending on whether this species was treated as conspecific with related forms, namely Thomson’s Gazelle (Eudorcas thomsonii) and Mongalla Gazelle (E. albonotata) (Gentry 1972, Kingdon 1997, East 1999). Furthermore, the form tilonura, from east of the Nile River, is either considered a subspecies of E. rufifrons (e.g., Grubb 2005), or a distinct species (Groves 2013). The treatment here follows Groves (2013) in recognizing, at least provisionally, three species: E. rufifrons occurring from Senegal to Sudan, west of the White Nile; E. albonotata in the Sudd of South Sudan, and E. tilonura to the east of the Blue Nile. Genetic research to clarify the relationships between these three forms and E. thomsonii is highly desirable.

Six subspecies have been described, but the validity of most of these is still in doubt, and recent genetic studies have shown that only the western African subspecies (Hippotragus equinus koba) constitutes a genetically separate group from those in the rest of Africa (Alpers et al. 2004). Management authorities therefore work with Evolutionarily Significant Units (ESUs) and use H. e. equinus as the putative indigenous subspecies within the assessment region. Hippotragus e. cottoni should also be seen as an indigenous subspecies. The equinus/cottoni complex is treated as one by nature conservation authorities as there may be no significant genetic differences between the two. Many of the Roan Antelope in South Africa are H. e. cottoni or equinus x cottoni (especially on private properties).

Four subspecies are usually recognized: H. n. niger, H. n. kirkii, H. n. roosevelti and the isolated Giant Sable (H. n. variani) from Angola. As for many other antelope species, the validity and precise distribution of most of the described subspecies are uncertain. An extensive study of the geographical genetic structure of Hippotragus niger identified three genetic subdivisions representing a Kenya and east Tanzania clade (H. n. roosevelti), a west Tanzania clade (H. n. kirkii), and a southern African clade (H. n. niger) (Pitra et al. 2002), which corroborated the findings of Matthee and Robinson (1999) that delineated a genetic barrier between the east and southern African (Angola, Zambia and Malawi southwards) clades, thus cautioning against translocations between the two areas.
No subspecies have been recognised.

Four distinct lechwe populations are recognized as subspecies (Ansell and Banfield 1979, Birungi and Arctander 2001): Black Lechwe (K. l. smithemani); Kafue Lechwe (K. l. kafuensis); Red Lechwe (K. l. leche); and the extinct Robert's Lechwe (K. l. robertsi). A fifth taxon, the Upemba Lechwe from south-eastern DR Congo, which Cotterill (2005) described as a distinct species, is treated here as a subspecies, K. l. anselli.

Although previously regarded as separate species, the Defassa Waterbuck and the Common Waterbuck are now listed as the subspecies Kobus ellipsiprymnus defassa and K. e. ellipsiprymnus, respectively. These subspecies can be distinguished by differences in coat colouration, rump patterns, genetics (Lorenzen et al. 2006) and geographic range. Their distributions overlap somewhat in East Africa, where genetically intermediate populations exist, suggesting a high degree of hybridisation in the Nairobi National Park population in Kenya (Lorenzen et al. 2006).

Several subspecies have been named but three are usually recognized: White-eared Kob K. k. leucotis; Uganda Kob K. k. thomasi; and Buffon’s Kob K. k. kob (Kingdon 1997, East 1999, Fischer 2013). Lorenzen et al. (2007) question the taxonomic status of K. k. kob and K. k. thomasi as two separate subspecies due to the similarity of their mtDNA sequences (although they are phenotypically distinct). Birungi (1999) proposed that the Puku (Kobus vardonii) might be a subspecies of the Kob rather than a distinct species.
Molecular data (Birungi and Arctander 2000) provide evidence that the Puku may be a subspecies of the more widely distributed kob Kobus kob.

Two subspecies are recognized, based on contrasts in pelage and leg colour: N. batesi batesi in the west, and N. b. harrisoni in northeastern The Democratic Republic of the Congo (Feer 2013). These have not been confirmed by genetic evidence. Only the species is assessed here.

A polytypic species; several subspecies have been named, but only two are widely recognised (Kingdon & Hoffmann 2013): a northern (R. a. occidentalis) and a southern (R. a. arundinum) (Skinner & Chimimba 2005), the latter of which is found in the assessment region. Only the species is assessed here.

As many as fourteen subspecies of Sylvicapra grimmia have been recognised in Africa (Grubb & Groves 2001; Wilson 2013), however it is difficult to identify the precise geographic limits of each subspecies as the Common Duiker has a continuous distribution across sub-Saharan Africa (Wilson 2013). Some of these subspecies can be distinguished based on colouration and size characteristics (Wilson 2013). Within the assessment region, S. g. grimmia occurs in the extreme south of the species’ range (Western, Eastern and Northern Cape provinces; Skinner & Chimimba 2005), and is substantially greyer in colour compared to the other subspecies, hence the alternate name, Grey Duiker in the Cape (Wilson 2013). Sylvicapra g. caffa is found further north of S. g. grimmia within the KwaZulu-Natal, North West, Gauteng, Mpumalanga and Limpopo provinces (Skinner & Chimimba 2005), extending into southern Mozambique and eastern Zimbabwe (Wilson 2013). The sandy-coloured S. g. steinhardti ranges throughout Namibia into Angola, Botswana and marginally into the Northern Cape Province to Port Nolloth (Wilson 2013). While distribution is continuous, there are many cases of intergradation but geographical boundaries between forms have not been delineated accurately (IUCN SSC Antelope Specialist Group 2016). Hence only the species is assessed here.

The African Buffalo (Syncerus caffer) exhibits substantial morphological variability (Skinner and Chimimba 2005), resulting in controversies regarding the recognition of the various subspecies (Smitz et al. 2013). Recent evidence supports the separation of two distinct groups, corresponding to a West and Central African group and an East and Southern African group (Smitz et al. 2013). The East and Southern African group is comprised of a single subspecies (Syncerus caffer caffer), which is found in the assessment region. The West and Central African group is assigned to two or three subspecies (S. c. nanus, S. c. brachyceros and S. c. aequinoctialis), although the latter two of these subspecies are not recognised by all authorities (Le Roex et al. 2012, Smitz et al. 2013).

The West African Savannah Buffalo, S. c. brachyceros (from Senegal to Cameroon) and the Central African Savannah Buffalo, S. c. aequinoctialis (from Central Africa to Sudan) are morphologically intermediate between S. c. caffer (Southern Savannah Buffalo) and S. c. nanus (Forest Buffalo) (Skinner and Chimimba 2005). Forest Buffalo are adapted to forest life, having a smaller size, unobtrusive swept back horns and a red to reddish-brown colouration, and are restricted to West Africa (Skinner and Chimimba 2005). Southern Savannah Buffalo are about twice the size of Forest Buffalo, with large downward curved horns and a brownish to black colouration (Smitz et al. 2013). The taxonomic uncertainty in these four subspecies is corroborated by the observation of interbreeding and intermediate phenotypes in contact zones between all four subspecies (Prins 1996), and at least one reported cross between S. c. caffer and S. c. nanus (Smitz et al. 2013). Based on recent genetic results, S. c. brachyceros and S. c. aequinoctialis would be included in S. c. nanus following standard nomenclature rules (Smitz et al. 2013). Evidence suggests that buffalo populations in Uganda and the Central African Republic display the highest genetic diversity of all African Buffalo populations and this could be the region where the most overlap exists between the two main groups (S. c. nanus and S. c. caffer) (Smitz et al. 2013). Analysis of 766 mtDNA sequences from 43 localities indicates that S. c. caffer is found in Uganda, Kenya, Tanzania, Zimbabwe, Botswana, South Africa and Namibia (Smitz et al. 2013).

Based on the number of pale transverse stripes on the body (Haltenorth 1963), four African subspecies of Tragelaphus strepsiceros have been recorded (Ansell 1972); although only T. s. strepsiceros is present in southern Africa (Skinner & Chimimba 2005).

There are two recognized subspecies: Western Giant Eland (Tragelaphus derbianus derbianus) and Eastern Giant Eland (T. d. gigas) (East 1999). The species is referred to as Taurotragus derbianus by Grubb (2005).
Phylogenetic and craniometric results show that Cricetomys ansorgei is considered separate from C. gambianus (Olayemi et al. 2012).

There is currently no clear agreement on how to relate geographically linked variation in morphology and genetics to the taxonomy and systematics of the widely distributed Wildcat (Felis silvestris) (Kitchener and Rees 2009). The latest phylogeographical analyses (Driscoll et al. 2007, 2009; Macdonald et al. 2010) suggest that the Wildcat consists of five subspecific groups and three traditional subspecies (Nowell and Jackson 1996, Stuart et al. 2013): including the recent recognition of the Southern African Wildcat (F. s. cafra Desmarest, 1822).

Based on genetic, morphological and archaeological evidence, the familiar housecat was believed to have been domesticated from the Near Eastern Wildcat (F. s. lybica), probably 9,000–10,000 years ago in the Fertile Crescent region (Vigne et al. 2004, Driscoll et al. 2007), coinciding with the first agricultural settlements (Driscoll et al. 2007, Macdonald et al. 2010). Although the domestic cat derived relatively recently from the Wildcat, in terms of biological processes and phylogeny, it can be taxonomically classified either as a subspecies (F. s. catus) of F. silvestris or as a separate species (F. catus) (Macdonald et al. 2010). Recent evidence supports the classification of domestic cats as genetically distinct from Wildcats (Driscoll et al. 2007).

For the purposes of this assessment, although we recognise the potential validity of the Southern African Wildcat (F. s. cafra), we defer to the species level until further research can accurately delineate subspecific geographical boundaries.

Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group. This species has traditionally either been included in the genus Felis (Kral and Zima 1980) or Profelis (Pocock 1917, Wozencraft 2005). More recent molecular data unequivocally reveal that the Caracal Caracal caracal and the Serval Leptailurus serval are closely allied with the African Golden Cat (Johnson et al. 2006).

Meerts et al. (2017) have extended the concept of Monotes hypoleucus to include taxa previously treated as separate species e.g. M. carrissoanus and M. angolensis. These have been included as varieties and include var. angolensis, var. caloneurus, var. discolor, var. hypoleucus and var. loandensis. The variety caloneurus in turn is also the result of a merge of M. caloneurus, M. schmitzii and M. elegans into a single taxon. Data on all of these taxa is combined here for this species-level assessment.

Formerly Acisoma panorpoides was thought to occur in Africa, Madagascar and Asia. Recent taxonomic and genetic studies showed, that in Asia the true A. panorpoides occurs, while two different species each occur in Madagascar and continental Africa. The latter are separated in A. variegatum and in A. inflatum, both of them being described long ago and neglected since (Dijkstra and Clausnitzer 2014).

Formerly Acisoma panorpoides was thought to occur in Africa, Madagascar and Asia. Recent taxonomic and genetic studies showed, that in Asia the true A. panorpoides occurs, while two different species each occur in Madagascar and continental Africa. The latter are separated in A. variegatum and in A. inflatum, both of them being described long ago and neglected since (Dijkstra and Clausnitzer 2014).
Cyphomyrus cubangoensis (Pellegrin, 1935) was resurrected for specimens from above Victoria Falls, i.e. in the Kavango, Kwando and Upper Zambezi Rivers by Kramer and van der Bank (2011).
Nothobranchius symoensi was established as a species by Wildekamp in 1978, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.

Populations of this species originating from the upper Lufira system were first identified as N. brieni, which species was the first and, for 40 years, the only Nothobranchius species described from the Congo and upper Zambezi river drainages, and the populations were also referred to as N. aff. taeniopygus, based on the presence of broad light subdistal band in the caudal fin. Finally, Nothobranchius polli was established as a distinct species by Wildekamp in 1978, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.
Nothobranchius malaissei was established as a species by Wildekamp in 1978, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.
Nothobranchius hassoni was established as a species by Valdesalici and Wildekamp in 2004, and that status has since been accepted by all authors.

Records of the Tana and Athi systems are dubious and probably refer to a different species. The status of the North Ewaso Nyiro subpopulations is uncertain and also needs further study (Seegers et al. 2003).

Nothobranchius brieni was established as a species by Poll in 1938, and that status has since been accepted by all authors. It was the first Nothobranchius species described from the Congo and upper Zambezi river drainages. Despite the good impression of the specific colour pattern provided in the original description, the species name was also attributed to other Nothobranchius species collected in the Congo and upper Zambezi drainages, until Wildekamp published a redescription of N. brieni in 1978, together with the description of other species from the region, thereby clarifying the situation.
According to Mandahl-Barth (1988) it is possible that the specimens described by Jickeli (1874) as Cyclas capense from the Toccor River (Ethiopia) pertain to this species.

Resembles a juvenile Sphaerium, but smaller. Difficult to identify to species level, and therefore there are doubts concerning the validity of some of the Pisidium identifications reported from the southern African region.

Annickia chlorantha and Annickia affinis were distinguished as two different species by Versteegh and Sosef (2007). However some confusion still exist to identify the both species. A. chlorantha is less common than A. affinis, and many herbarium specimens have been misidentified as A. chlorantha instead of A. affinis.
There are two recognised varieties of this species Celtis philippensis var. wightii and var. philippensis.

Didelotia brevipaniculata J. Léonard was until recently thought to occur in West Africa (Liberia and Côte d’Ivoire) and Central Africa (Cameroon, Equatorial Guinea, Gabon and Congo - Brazzaville). The specimens in Côte d’Ivoire and Liberia, previously under D. brevipaniculata, were shown by Jongkind (2019) to be a distinct species and was thus described as D. gracillima Jongkind. Consequently, D. brevipaniculata is now restricted to central Africa.

Gilbertiodendron mayombense is believed to be a combination of at least two species, but this is currently unpublished. When the existing herbarium material has been studied and the results published, there could be one or more threatened species (X. van der Burgt pers. comm. 2019).
This species is often confused with Fimbristylis miliacea in Indian floristic works. Fimbristylis miliacea is mostly common in north India (Cook 1996).

Osmunda regalis is restricted to the Old World. In the New World it is replaced by O. spectabilis, which was formerly treated as a subspecies of O. regalis. However, this is now known to be more closely related to O. japonica (Metzgar et al. 2008) and is thus to be treated at the species level.

M. fontana has been taxonomically divided into a series of varieties, subspecies or even species. Recognition of these entities is very inconsistent and there appears to be no useful solution to sub-specific treatment of this taxon.

H. castaneus and H. constellatus were recognized as recently diverged and distinct species by Greenbaum et al. (2013). The subspecies H. c. submarginatus from the Kabobo Plateau was transferred to the synonymy of H. constellatus, but the status of the unsampled subspecies H. c. rhodogaster, described from mid-elevations of the western Itombwe Plateau, remains problematic (Greenbaum et al. 2013).

This species has three subspecies: Brachystephanus jaundensis Lindau subsp. jaundensis is restricted to Lower Guinea (east of the Dahomey interval), B. jaundensis Lindau subsp. nimbae (Heine) I.Darbysh. is restricted to Upper Guinea (west of the Dahomey interval), and B. jaundensis Lindau subsp. nemoralis (S.Moore) I.Darbysh. is a lowland subspecies restricted to the Congo Basin.
Subsp. jaundensis is reliably separated from the other two by the considerably longer corolla tube (the limb also usually being larger) but all other characters seem to overlap to some degree (Champluvier and Darbyshire 2009).

Hydrilla stems are slender, branched and up to 25 feet long. Hydrilla 's small leaves are strap-like and pointed. They grow in whorls or four to eight around the stem. The leaf margins are distinctly saw-toothed. It produces tiny white flowers on long stalks.

J. effusus hybridises with J. inflexus L. (Juncus ×diffusus Hoppe) but the hybrid is not abundant and is unlikely to influence interpretation of the distribution of the species. Two varieties are widely recognised but there is little information on differences in their distribution or ecology, for example the apparent differences shown by Tela Botanica show that recording to varietal level is inconsistent, while Preston et al. (2002) do not map the different subspecies even though they are widely recorded in the UK.

Brooks and Clemants (2000) in Flora of North America vol. 22 say "The Juncus effusus complex has been variously recognized as containing several species or a single species with numerous infraspecific taxa. Unfortunately, North American treatments have dealt primarily with taxa in either the eastern or western portions of the continent. In considering the continent as a whole, little sense can be made of these treatments. The North American J. effusus complex is one that is in obvious need of modern systematic scrutiny."

The genus Utricularia is taxonomically complex, partly due to the desire of botanists to establish methods of identifying non-flowering populations (particularly in the field), with the consequence that the literature is complicated by vast numbers of unreliable records. Many taxa rarely flower and some have apparently never been known to flower in some regions. The majority of the data presented here is derived from Taylor (1989) which is the most reliable source. Additional information has been used where it is felt that it is both useful and reliable.

Potamogeton nodosus is one of the most polymorphic Potamogeton species, showing several distinct morphotypes as well as an extreme phenotypic plasticity throughout its range. It seems likely that there has been some confusion about the distinction between this specie and others such as P. linguatus, P. ferrugineus, P. tepperi and P. sulcatus (Wiegleb and Kaplan 1998), to the extent that this evaluation could include information on some of all of those taxa.

Potamogeton nodosus has been shown to hybridise with P. natans (P. ×schreberi G. Fisch.), the hybrid is not common and is unlikely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain. Keay in FWTA 1: 238 lists this as 'an imperfectly known species'. In Engler's protologue, published in 1899, he gives only "Dusen 9" by way of specimen data and it is not certain that this derives from Mt Cameroon: research on Dusen's itinerary is needed. Keay gives credibility to this species by uniting with it E. hankeana Winkler as a later synonym, so adding a second specimen, Winkler 1110, collected between Debundscha and Bibundi. Both specimens are assumed destroyed at Berlin, and there are no duplicates at Kew. In the 1992-94 inventories, no specimens were attributed to this species, and it may be extinct.

Aeshna wittei Fraser, 1955 is a synonym to A. scotias (Peters and Theischinger 2011). The paraphyletic genus Aeshna was split by Peters and Theischinger (2011) and A. scotias assigned to the monotypic Afroaeschna.

The taxon, which is endemic to Democratic Republic of Congo, was collected by A. Michelson in 1948 and 1949, and found to have similar hemi-parasitic behavior as O. aubrevillei. It is differentiated from O. aubrevillei by its glabrous branchlets and disk, shorter inflorescence and smaller fruits (Leonard and Troupin, 1950).

First collected in Cote d’Ivoire in 1936, it was named Octoknema okoubaka Aubrév. & Pellegr and placed in the family Octoknemaceae (Aubrevillei and Pellegrin 1937). After further studies in the mid-20th century, it was renamed Okoubaka aubrevillei (Pelleg & Norman), and eventually placed in family Santalaceae (Normand 1944, Stauffer 1957, Halle 1987). Concluding from molecular phylogenetic studies, the taxon was suggested to be placed in the family Cervantesiaceae (Dar and Nickrent 2008).

Dioscorea schimperiana Hochst. ex Kunth is a secondary wild relative of the Guinea yams, D. rotundata Poir. and D. cayenensis Lam. (Magwé-Tindo 2018, Omosowon 2018). It has two published varieties: D. schimperiana var. vestita Pax, and D. schimperiana var. adamowense Jacq.-Fél. (POWO 2019, WCSP 2019).
This species, formerly included in the genus Hemianax, is increasingly included in the genus Anax. As no genetic investigation is available, this remains controversial.
Gynacantha flavipes and G. sevastopuloi are synonyms to G. nigeriensis (Dijkstra 2005).
Heliaeschna libyana is synonym to H. fuliginosa (Dijkstra 2004).
Discussed as H. longfieldae by Dijkstra (2005), but that name is predated by the synonymous H. sembe (Dijkstra, unpubl.)
Heliaeschna ukerewensis Pinhey, 1961 is a synonym of H. trinervulata.
Aeschnna meruensis is now placed in the genus Pinheyschna (Peters and Theischinger 2011).

Aeschna rileyi is now placed in the genus Pinheyschna (Peters and Theoschinger 2011). Pinheyschna moori (Pinhey, 1980), described from a single poorly preserved male from Zambia, is most likely a synonym of P. rileyi (Dijkstra and Clausnitzer in prep.).
This is a split from the broader concept of Phrynobatrachus steindachneri (Zimkus and Gvoždík 2013).
Taxonomic limits of Umma and Sapho must be reassessed, but this species is closer to Sapho (Dijkstra, unpubl.).
Includes Umma distincta (Djikstra in prep.).
The synonymy of A. greyi and A. ntaali with each other is indisputed, but that of both with A. lacuselephantum requires futher study (Dijkstra, unpubl.).
Chlorocypha hintzi (Grünberg, 1915) is a synonym of C. cancellata (Dijkstra unpubl.).
The taxonomic status of Chlorocypha dahli has not been fully resolved.
Previously mistaken for C. wittei; could be a form of C. curta with wholly red abdomen (Dijkstra 2007).

In the Lokutu area of central Congo (Kinshasa), Dijkstra (2007) found populations of a species with features intermediate between C. ghesquierei, C. trifaria and C. cyanifrons. C. trifaria is widespread east of Lokutu, while C. ghesquierei and C. cyanifrons are sympatric to the west at Eala. Because of the latter sympatry, the Lokutu populations can only represent a character gradient either from C. trifaria to C. ghesquierei or to C. cyanifrons, or a discrete species. Without material from intermittent area and with only slight differences in the configuration and (partly age-related) extent of markings their status must remain unsettled for now.
The closeness of the slender red Chlorocypha species is demonstrated by two hybrid males C. molindica x tenuis discovered in south west Uganda (Dijkstra, Kisakye unpubl.).
All records under this name require comparison with the type material.
Confused with C. dispar; taxonomy is discussed by Dijkstra (2003).
May include a second species with blue head markings in eastern Nigeria (Dijkstra, unpubl.).
Subspecies C. nigeriensis Gambles, 1975 is not more than a pale variety.
Dijkstra (2007) considers Chlorocypha basilewskyi as a junior synonym of C. tenuis.
A specimen from the shores of Lake Malawi may be a new species.
Separation of subspecies lucalaensis from Angola probably invalid (Dijkstra unpubl.).
Aciagrion congoense is a synonym to A. africanum (Dijkstra 2007).
Western Africa records of this and the similar A. hamoni must be reviewed.
Although this is a recognised species, it may belong in a different genus. The genus Aciagrion is in need of further taxonomic work.
A. balachowskyi, from northeastern Gabon, might be a synonym of this species. If this is the case, it will be widespread (Dijktra pers. comm.).
A dark form, abercornensis, occurs in northern Zambia.
Africallagma pseudelongatum was treated as a synonym of A. elongatum for a long time.

A. malawi specimen, described as Africallagma sinuatum f. fugax (Pinhey, 1962), differs significantly from A. sinuatum (Ris, 1921) and is expected to become a good species (May and Dijkstra in prep.).
This species is often confused with A. victoria.
D'Andrea and Carfi (1997) made Agriocnemis aligulae Pinhey, 1974 a synonym of A. maclachlani Selys, 1877.
This species is often confused with A. forcipata.
This species potentially requires further investigation as there are discontinuities in habitat and behaviour across its range.
Enallagma vansomereni is a synonym.
Previously listed as Argiocnemis umbargae Pinhey 1970, which is a synonym of the widespread Ceriagrion annulatum (Dijkstra unpublished).
Taxonomy is clarified by Dijkstra (2005).
Ceriagrion moorei and C. hamoni may be synonymous with C. suave (Dijkstra 2005) and are treated as such here.
A-group. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B".
This is the only member of this otherwise Neotropical family in Africa.

Examination of the holotype shows that Cornigomphus guineensis is probably a species of Tragogomphus, a taxonomically unresolved genus. However, listing of any Tragogomphus species is premature (Dijkstra unpublished).
The group requires taxonomic revision, as it may belong to the genus Tragogomphus.

From Dijkstra (2007): "Pinhey (1961b) noted that T. mamfei “has a remarkable superficial resemblance to a Uganda species of Gomphid, now under publication as an aberrant Onychogomphus”. This O. bwambae Pinhey, 1961 may indeed belong to the complex also, as could O. emiliae Legrand, 1992. The species differ only subtily in relative features of size, markings, dorsal profile of S10 and appendages. The T. mamfei holotype is rather teneral and belongs to a small species (Hw 24.7 mm), which has also recently been collected in southwest Cameroon (G.S. Vick in litt.). All species currently classified in Tragogomphus must be revised, including the possible distinction of additional genera in the complex (Cornigomphus, Libyogomphus)."
Further taxonomic studies are necessary, as this species might belong to P. bispina (Fraser, 1954) or another more widespread and variable taxon (Dijkstra 2007).
It was in the genus Porpacithemis and has recently been revised by Djikstra and Vick (2005).
Previously placed in its own genus Mesumbethemis Vick, 2000 (Dijkstra and Vick 2005).
Formerly placed in Porpacithemis.
The species is close to T. aurivilii, requiring further work.
This species has been split from Hyperolius cinereus by Conradie et al. (2013).

authority: Rödel, Doherty-Bone, Kouete, Janzen, Garrett, Browne, Gonwouo, Barej & Sandberger, 2012
taxonomicNotes: There has been some taxonomic confusion between this species and Phrynobatrachus horsti due to morphological similarities (Rödel et al. 2015).
This is a restricted concept of Hyperolius adspersus following the split of the broader concept into this and H. dartevellei (Channing et al. 2013).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Tandy and Keith (1972) tentatively assigned this species to the synonymy of Sclerophrys funereus. Tandy (pers. comm.) considers that it is almost certainly a synonym of S. funereus. Ruas (1996) considered it as a synonym of Sclerophrys funereus (as Amietophrynus).

This very widely distributed species is a complex of several species. A phylogeographic study by Vences et al. (2004) suggests that the populations of this species on the Seychelles and the Mascarene islands were introduced from Madagascar. However, the animals on Madagascar appear to have arrived on that island prior to its colonization by humans. Pickersgill (2007) treated Ptychadena hylaea as a separate species, but here we retain it within P. mascareniensis pending a more comprehensive resolution of this species complex. Records from Rwanda, Uganda, Kenya and Egypt were assigned to P. nilotica by Dehling and Sinsch (2013).
This complex has recently been separated into three species: B. lacertus, B. antilliensis, and B. soporator (Tornabene et al. 2010).

Heemstra and Heemstra (2004) describes the taxonomy of the Mugilidae family as confused and the genera as obscurely defined. 

Misidentification with Mugil gaimardianus, now an invalid species, has caused much confusion in the past.  

Currently, the most frequent misidentication is with Mugil rubrioculus (Harrison et al. 2007). Mugil curema and M. rubrioculus are very similar morphologically. They are clearly separated genetically both by karyotype and molecular analysis (Nirchio et al. 2005, Fraga et al. 2007, Gonzalez-Castro et al. 2009). 

Fraga et al. (2007) identified two species occurring along the Brazilian coast, Mugil curema type I (Mugil rubrioculus) and Mugil curema type II and showed that their distribution overlaps in most of their distribution. Therefore, species identification in landings and ecological studies may confuse the two species in Brazil.
This species is sometimes placed in Trapezostigma, which should be treated as a synonym of Tramea (Dijkstra et al. 2005).
The solitaria complex includes carpenteri, discrepans and mediofasciata. The taxonomy for this complex is not clear.
The species name is often misspelt as Diplacodes lefebvrei.
This species has been confused in the past with Lestes ochraceus and L. ictericus (Gambles 1976) and records must be revised carefully.
In Africa it is often confused with Orthetrum camerunense.
The paler subspecies falsum occurs in East Africa and parts of Southern Africa.
Subpopulations from Iraq and Kuwait have been ascribed to a poorly defined subspecies, Orthetrum trinacria igarashii Asahina, 1973. Its taxonomic status needs clarification.

Melanic insular subpopulations from the Anjouan island have been described as a distinct subspecies, Paragomphus genei ndzuaniensis Levasseur, 2007. As similar subpopulations are known in mainland Africa, more genetic research should be done before validating such subspecific division, which was done based on very weak criteria and without taking the variability of other subpopulations into account.
This widely distributed and abundant species is often misidentified and confused with similar taxa.

The small dark form, rusingae, occurs on the northern shores and islands of Lake Victoria.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species belongs to group B.

The nominal subspecies is distributed in Africa south of the Sahara, the Nile Valley and in Sinai. A paler subspecies, Pseudagrion torridum hulae Dumont, 1974, is said to be restricted to the upper Jordan Valley (Dumont 1974, Dumont 1979, Schneider 1986, Schneider 1987). The only difference to specimens from the Nile and Sinai is their paler colouration, a variation also found in sub-Saharan subpopulations. As there are also no morphological differences, the Levantine subpopulations are no longer regarded as a distinct subspecies.

The nominotypical subspecies is restricted to Mauritius Islands and is defined by small dark patches at the base of the forewings and the dark area of the hindwings reaching the nodus. The subspecies Rhyothemis semihyalina separata (Selys, 1849) extends over the whole continental African and Arabian range of the species and is defined by forewings lacking dark patches at base (totally hyaline) and the dark area of the hindwings not reaching the nodus.

Another subspecies, R. s. syriaca (Selys, 1849) was described from the Jordan Valley, where it was supposedly endemic (and is now extinct), and was defined by a dark area at the base of hindwings which do not reach the nodus and where the last row of cells on the posterior wing margin remains hyaline.

Such criteria used for subspecific separation are very weak and lack of true statistical basis, and there is some evidences that individuals from Gabon, Namibia and Madagascar may show a dark patch at the base of forewings and a dark area in hindwings reaching or not the nodus (i.e. <http://www.africa-dragonfly.net/pics/a488/P1010356.jpg>, Pinhey 1962, Suhling and Martens 2007). That suggests a stronger intraspecific variability than initially expected. 

Therefore, most researchers do not retain this subspecific splitting, which is unlikely in such nomadic species, and further genetic study throughout this species range is needed.
This species is sometimes placed in Trapezostigma, which is a synonym of Tramea.

Libellula haematina Rambur, 1842, described from Senegal and Madagascar, and claimed to be occurring in La Réunion, Mauritius and Sicily, represents the infraspecific variability and cannot be accepted as a valid taxon despite the treatment published by Ris (1912).
Trithemis jacksoni is a synonym (Dijkstra unpubl.).
The occurrence of Trithemis furva in west Africa is uncertain due to possible confusion with T. pruinata, which appears commoner in the west but rarer in the east and south Africa.

The former splitting into a nominotypical form and a subspecies Trithemis kirbyi ardens (Gerstäcker, 1891) is currently challenged because of different opinions on biogeographic interpretation in the distribution of phenotypes.

The subspecies Urothemis edwardsii hulae Dumont, 1975, described from the upper Jordan Valley, falls within the variation range of the African and Arabian subpopulations (Samraoui et al. 1993) and is no longer recognized as valid.

It is still often misspelt as Zygonyx torrida, from its former name, Pseudomacromia torrida.

Specimens from Mauritius have been described as a distinct subspecies, Zygonyx torridus insulanus (sub Z. torrida insulana) by Pinhey (1981), based on their smaller size and the occurrence of a yellow tinge on all wings in three males only. However, Jacquemin and Boudot (1999) specified that two males from Mauritius and a third from La Réunion islands agree perfectly in size and wing colour (fully hyaline) with the nominotypical subspecies. Similarly, specimens from India, which have been doubtfully ascribed to a distinct subspecies, Zygonyx torridus isis (sub Zygonyx isis, then Z. torrida isis) by Fraser (1924, 1926) on the basis of their faint yellow suffused wings in six males and without any comparison with the African subpopulations. This poorly defined taxon is in need of re-evaluation. Here Z. t. isis is tentatively treated as a synonym of Z. t. torridus.
Philonomon luminans is junior synonym to Diplacodes luminans (Dijkstra 2006).

Brachythemis leucosticta (Burmeister, 1839) was recently split in two distinct cryptic species (Dijkstra and Matushkina 2009), with B. impartita (Karsch, 1890) occurring from the south of Europe and northern Africa to central Africa, and the true B. leucosticta from the Sahel to South Africa. Both species overlap over a large part of central Africa.

There is some uncertainty over the taxonomy and distribution of Ceratopteris thalictroides and C. cornuta. Verdcourt (1999) includes the two as a single taxon, with justification. Al Khulaidi (in prep.) lists only C. cornuta from Yemen, while Hassler and Schmidt (2011) list them as separate species, with C. thalictroides absent from the Arabian Peninsula and C. cornuta occurring in Oman and Yemen (including Soqotra), as does The Plant List. For now, the two taxa are assessed separately for the IUCN Red List.

Boden et al. (1997) reported Bagrus bajad from the Sanaga River basin and also in museum collections several Lower Guinea Bagrus were labelled as B. bajad. However, based on our findings B. bajad is not present in Lower Guinea. The species may be easily distinguished from Bagrus docmak by its generally higher gill raker number (15-19) and its relatively narrower head [47.5-63.0 (mean: 55.2) % HL]. At present B. bajad has not been collected from the Lower Guinea province although it is known from adjacent West African river basins as the Benue River, the major eastern tributary of the Niger River basin, and the Logone River, one of the major southern tributaries of the Chad River basin.
Western subpopulations of "Ctenopoma" muriei are considered as "Ctenopoma" houyi by Paugy et al. (2003) based on an unpublished revision of Anabantidae by Norris.

There has been confusion in the literature between G. dembeensis, G. johnstonii and G. hindii. G. johnstonii is a junior synonym of G. dembeensis (Getahun 2000), but G. hindii differs in having a fully scaled predorsum, belly and chest (Stiassny and Getahun 2007). It does however share two important meristic and morphometric features with G. dembeensis: a high number of scales in the lateral line and a vent located away from the anal fin. This species is also recorded as Garra sp., Discognathus johnstonii Boulenger, 1901 and D. hindii Boulenger, 1905 (two junior synonyms also included in Garra) and D. dembeensis (antiquated binomen) (Seegers et al. 2003).

Reported as Mastacembelus victoriae Boulenger, 1903, a junior synonym (Matthes 1962). Also reported as Mastacembelus moeruensis Boulenger, 1914 and Mastacembelus stappersii Boulenger, 1914, both junior synonyms (Van Steenberge et al. 2014).

The taxonomic status of mastacembelids from the Athi River drainage needs investigation (Seegers et al. 2003).

Also reported under the generic names Caecomastacembelus and Afromastacembelus; here included in Mastacembelus (Vreven 2005).

Schilbe intermedius Ruppell, 1832 was described from the lower Nile River in Egypt. As presently recognised, this species has a wide African distribution from the Phongolo River in KwaZulu-Natal north to the Nile and across into parts of west Africa. Taxonomic examination of isolated subpopulations using new techniques, e.g. DNA sequencing, is needed. Schilbe intermedius seems closely related to S. uranoscopus and these species are sympatric in several hydrographic basins.

Skelton (1993), Seegers (1996) and Roberts (2003) mentioned that Z. rotundiceps is a species complex, representing several closely related species. Indeed, Eccles et al. (2011) demonstrated that material from parts of the Zambezi and Congo basins in Zambia, and from Zimbabwe, Malawi, Mozambique and Angola actually comprises several species. Additionally, Eccles et al. (2011) retained Zaireichthys wamiensis (Seegers, 1989) and Zaireichthys brevis (Boulenger, 1915), previously regarded as junior synonyms of Z. rotundiceps, as valid species.
Type: Congo-Kinshasa, Ruwenzori, Lanuri Valley, Bequaert 4677 (BR, holo.)
Type: Zambia, Mweru Wantipa: H.M.Richards 9175 (K holo-).

Type: Bequaert 1826, Avakubi, DRC

Vern. names:
- Limbila (turumbu)
- Itoko (turumbu)
There are two (generally accepted) subspecies: subsp. albomaculata (widespread in tropical and South Africa) and subsp. macrocarpa, restricted to South Africa.

S. talbotii is brought into synonymy here, as the differences between that taxon and S. steetzii are almost nonexistent. The type of S. gomphrenoides has very long spinulose apices to the glomerule bracts, but there is a continuous range of variation from these to the shorter apices of S. steetzii s.s. and BEENTJE has failed to find any associated characters. The type of S. keniensis is a typical intermediate. In Uganda only short and intermediate length apices are found, and in the south (T 7) only long ones, but over most of the range all types are present. Mortimer states the inflorescences are much visited by bees. Wingfield 3162 from 9km WNW of Dar es Salaam could be a young plant of this species, but is from T 6 at 5 m altitude.
Type: Bioko (Fernando Po), Clarence Peak, Mann 599 (K, holo.)
Type: Malawi, Mt Malosa, Whyte (K, lecto.)
Type: Congo-Kinshasa, Ruwenzori, Butahu Valley, Stuhlmann 2454 (B†, holo.; K, iso.)
Type: Kenya, North Nyeri District: Aberdare Mts, Nyeri side, Haines 1969 (EA, holo.; K, iso.)
Type: Ethiopia, Simien, Mt Buahit, Schimper II: 1180 (P, holo.; BM, K, S, UPS, iso.)
Type: Ethiopia, Simien, Enchetcap, Schimper II 576 (P, holo.; BM, K, S, UPS, iso.)
Type: Ethiopia, Simien, Mt Bachit, near Demerki and Debreski, Schimper 170, 170B (B†, holo.; K, syn.)
Type: Congo-Kinshasa, Kahuzi Massif, W of Lake Kivu, Humbert 7722 (BR, P, syn.) and Karisimbi Volcano, NE of Lake Kivu, Humbert 8586 (P, syn.)
There are some endemic subspecies of importance: Juncus dregeanus subsp. bachitii and Juncus dregeanus subsp. dregeanus
According to Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew WCSPF (World Checklist of Selected Plant Families), this genus belongs to the Araceae Family.

N. E. Brown maintained that this plant is quite distinct from the Asiatic M. vaginalis (Burm. f.) Kunth, but Backer (Fl. Malesiana, ser. 1, 4: 258 (1951)) has again suggested that the African plant is a race of M. vaginalis. The rather striking differences in inflorescence lead me to believe that N. E. Brown was correct in separating the two, but very little material is to hand. In West Africa a further member of the genus occurs which Hutchinson & Dalziel (F.W.T.A. 2: 354 (1936)) referred to M. vaginalis (Burm. f.) Kunth var. plantaginea (Roxb.) Solms.

Although there is some uncertainty regarding the taxonomy of populations close to A. plantago-aquatica in Asia, these do not affect evaluation of the species in Europe.

Plants with the leaves similar to that of A. plantago-aquatica, styles as in A. gramineum and 0.2-0.3 mm long undeveloped anthers are known from Orenburg Region (basin of the Ural and Samara Rivers). Apparently this is the result of hybridization of A. plantago-aquatica × A. gramineum and possibly sterile. These are known as A. ×bjorkqvistii Tzvel. (Tzvelev 2001). This hybridisation is not sufficiently frequent to affect evaluation of the species.

A. plantago-aquatica is reported to hybridise occasionally with A. lanceolatum (A. ×rhicnocarpum Schotsm.) but this is not sufficiently frequent to affect evaluation of the species in Europe.
Hygrophila schulli has been put under various genera in the past. The name was published by M.R. Almeida and S.M. Almeida in the Journal of Bombay Natural History Society in 1987.

There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name. However, there is a degree of confusion over separation of L. gibba from L. minor when the former is not expanded and this may obscure differences in the distribution of the two species.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

Some authors regard this genus as being monotypic and the rest of the described species as variants of it. However, Susan Carter reporting two species from East Tropical Africa (Carter 1960) remarks the difference between them are constant, and too diverse to be the variations of the same species. She regards the genus as consisting of three species.

There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name. Potamogeton trichoides has been shown to hybridise with P. crispus (P. ×bennettii Fryer) and P. pusillus (P. ×grovesii Dandy et G. Taylor), both hybrids are rare and unlikely to affect either the survival of the species or this evaluation.

The West African subpopulations are placed under C. rubens rubens while the Nile subpopulations are referred to as C. rubens arcuta (later emended to arcuata), though the differences between the two subspecies seem very small.

Biomphalaria sudanica (Martens, 1870) is a distinct species, (supposedly) widely spread in Africa, but recent molecular research has established that the B. sudanica subpopulations of Lake Victoria are an ecophenotypic variant of B. choanomphala, occurring at the lake's fringe (Standley et al. 2011). These authors have proposed the name B. choanomphala sudanica for this form, but that seems, from a taxonomist point of view, not an acceptable proposal. In any case, 'true' B. sudanica probably does not occur in the Lake Victoria drainage.

The genus Bulinus is generally divided into four groups (Brown 1994), one of which is the B. africanus group. In the Lake Victoria region five species of this group occur, namely B. africanus, B. globosus, B. ugandae, B. productus and B. nasutus. Confusion between these species, particularly in trematode studies, often occurs.

Molecular research has shown that the family Ancilydae, in which all the Patella-like freshwater genera had been placed, is actually paraphyletic, with the genus Burnupia a case of convergence (Albrecht et al. 2004). Albrecht (in Bouchet et al. 2017) established the new family-group name Burnupiidae. Not only the taxonomic placement of Burnupia needed re-examination, the species are also in dire need of revision; many of those described in the early 20th century being hardly distinctive, with no reliable diagnostic characters. It is generally assumed that only a few species are really distinct, B. caffra being one of them (Brown 1994).

Brown (2001) has shown that the populations of the Afrotropical widespread species Ceratophallus natalensis actually belong to three different species, namely C. natalensis (Krauss, 1848), C. gibbonsi (Nelson, 1878) and C. yesimit. The first two occur in the Lake Victoria Basin. The Ceratophallus population that was discovered on Anjouan (Comoros) was referred to as Ceratophallus sp. by Stahrmühlner (1983). Brown (1994) who did study this material, referred to it as C. natalensis. This was however prior to his study on the cryptic species complex (Brown 2001). Since the Anjouan material was not revised in this study, the taxonomic identification remains uncertain.
This is the new taxonomic concept of Bellamya unicolor, which excludes subpopulations native to Lake Victoria. These subpopulations are now considered part of the Bellamya constricta species complex.
Pinhey (1969) made superba Schmidt, 1951 a subspecies of marshalli Ris, 1921. Recently Dijkstra and Clausnitzer (in prep.) treat superba as a valid species again.
H. okarkarri was synonymized under this species by Channing and Howell (2006).
H. reesi has been synonymized under this species by Channing and Howell (2006).
We follow African Chiroptera Report (2014) and Bergmans (1988) by treating Epomophorus minor as a species separate from E. labiatus.

The former Brachythemis leucosticta (Burmeister, 1839) was split in two distinct cryptic species (Dijkstra and Matushkina 2009), with B. impartita (Karsch, 1890) occurring from the south of Europe and northern Africa to central Africa, and the true B. leucosticta from the Sahel to South Africa. Both species overlap over a large part of central Africa.
Synonym = Pentas pubiflora S.Moore subsp. bamendensis Verdc. in part.
Previously confused with numerous Platycnemis species.
Platycnemis nyansana Förster, 1916 and P. xanthopus Navás, 1924 are possible synonyms.
This species has been resurrected from synonymy with Sclerophrys maculatus by Poynton et al. (2016).
Gomphidia balii Fraser, 1949 is possibly a synonym.

Crocothemis sanguinolenta was first recorded from the Dead Sea by Morton (1924), based on three males in Ris' collection. Based on these specimens and new records, Schneider (1982) described the subspecies arabica. With more material at hand Dijkstra and Dingemanse (2000) found out that characters used to separate Levantine subpopulations fall within the variation of the nominal (African) form and concluded that arabica is not a valid subspecies.
Diplacodes okavangoensis is a synonym to D. deminuta (Dijkstra 2007).
This species was previously often confused with G. villosa (see Dijkstra 2005).
The name of this species is often misspelt as P. subfurcatum.

Former records of Kenya correspond to P. niloticum. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species belongs to group B.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species is part of group A.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species is part of group B.
The holotype of P. glaucum pertains to the species known as P. basicornu (Dijkstra unpubl.).

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species is part of group B.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species is part of group A.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species is part of group B.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species is part of group A.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species is part of group B.
Pseudagrion risi rufocinctum is a synonym.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species is part of group A.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". P. sjoetedti is a B-group species.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species belongs to group A.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". Pseudagrion sudanicum is a B group species.
Gomphidia madi is considered as a pale variation of G. bredoi (Dijkstra unpubl.).
This species has been confused in the past with Lestes ochraceus and L. pallidus (Gambles 1976) and records must be revised carefully.
Confused in the past with L. ictericus and L. pallidus (Gambles 1976) and records must be revised carefully.
This species is often mixed up with L. africanus, of which the systematic status remains unclear.

The whole genus Microgomphus is very elusive and this is why only a few specimens have ever been collected. The taxonomy is still not settled and Microgomphus schoutedeni might pertain to M. nyassicus, which will become the nominate species.
Notogomphus speciosus (Sjöstedt, 1909) is a possible synonym.
Type: South Africa, Drège 4389 (B, holo., not found; K, P, iso.)

Molecular research has shown that populations considered as Biomphalaria.pfeifferi on morphological characteristics differ from those that are genetically identified as B. pfeifferi (Jørgensen et al. 2007). There is hence a severe identification problem since shell diagnostics appear to be useless for identification of this species. In particular, specimens collected from Uganda which were identified as morphologically B. pfeifferi were found to be genetically different (Jørgensen et al., 2007). The present assessment is based on the morphotype of this species, but future reassessments need to take into account that what was previously known as B. pfeifferi may be split into a number of new species.

Lymnaea (Galba) truncatula. As Bargues et al. (2001) in their genetic study of the Lymnaeidae state: 'The present knowledge on the genetics of lymnaeids and on their parasite-host inter-relationships is far from being sufficient. The family is immersed in a systematic-taxonomic confusion.' This means that some authors consider the names between brackets as distinct genera and others as subgenera. The assessor followed Brown (1994) and Appleton (1996) who use Lymnaea as the generic name but considers that the taxonomic issue has not yet been satisfactorily resolved.

According to Le Thomas (1969) this species is comprised of four varieties: var. gabonensis Pellegr. ex Le Thomas, var. glabra (Keay) Evrard, var. elliotianum and var. sericeum Keay. The African Plants Database, however, cites var. sericeum as a synonym of var. elliotianum. The type of var. gabonensis was collected in Gabon in 1914 and it is known from only two other collections, both collected on Bioko Island in 2012.

Two subspecies are recognized by Thorn et al. (2007): Pipistrellus grandidieri grandidieri from East Africa and Pipistrellus grandidieri angolensis from Angola, Malawi and Cameroon. Thorn et al. (2007) also proposed a new subgenus Afropipistellus, which was also used by Monadjem et al. (2010). Taxonomy and range extent are still controversial. West African specimens recently assigned to P. cf. grandidieri may be a separate species.

Owing to its poor description, the true identity of Paragomphus alluaudi (Martin, 1915) has remained unclear. Dijkstra & Clausnitzer (in prep.) consider a species occurring in the border region of Kenya and Tanzania as the true P. alluaudi.
A dark form, P. nguelicus, occurs in southern Africa. The taxonomy of the cognatus group of Paragomphus is unresolved and in urgent need of a throughout revision.
Phyllogomphus orientalis Fraser, 1957 is a possible synonym.
The name is often misspelt as H. albipuncta.

Malgassophlebia bispina is in central, eastern and southern Africa, and subspecies M. longistipes is in north Zambia. In western Africa it is widespread, somewhat variable and rarely collected. Therefore, several synonyms exist and no subspecies should be recognised (Dijkstra unpubl.).
This species is seriously confused with O. stemmale.
This species is often confused with O. caffrum.
This species is seriously confused with O. brachiale.
The Ugandan specimen seems to be a new species.
Palpopleura portia, often considered a form of P. lucia, was proven to be a good species (Mitchell and Samways 2005).
Palpopleura portia, often considered a form or subspecies of P. lucia, was proven to be a good species (Mitchell and Samways 2005).
Dijkstra (2003) discusses the synonymy.

The confusing taxonomy is discussed by Dijkstra (2005). Phyllomacromia nyanzana (Grünberg, 1911); ?P. bifasciata Martin, 1912. The female holotype seems to be miss-matched to the male holotype contumax, so melania may be something distinct (funicularia-like), while "contumax" takes priority over the whole nyanzana-bifasciata-complex.
The complex synonymy is discussed by Dijkstra (2005).
Spatula querquedula (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Anas.
Mareca strepera (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Anas.
This is often treated as a subspecies of Rhyothemis notata, but the two occur alongside each other in western Africa.
Rhyothemis fenestrina is a good species and not a subspecies of R. notata (Dijkstra unpubl.).
The shape of the epiproct varies and this species therefore has two synonyms (Dijkstra 2007).

Lieftinck (1969) reported Thermochoria jeanneli disjunctly from Katanga, and Ris (1919) recorded “form b” of T. equivocata, which clearly refers to latter population. Under T. equivocata (Pinhey 1984) called “Ris forma “b” […] locally common in Malawi, Zambia and Shaba”. These records must refer to T. jeanneli. Specimens from West Tanzania in RMNH published by Pinhey and Pinhey (1984) as T. equivocata indeed pertain to T. jeanneli.

The records of Trithemis donaldsoni from western Africa and Yemen have been recently ascribed to T. dejouxi Pinhey, 1978 (Dijkstra 2007), which is its sister species (Dijkstra et al. 2010). Both species may be easily confounded and their respective range is still unclear and needs further studies.

The subspecies T. grouti atra is from central Africa. Trithemis grouti has priority over T. atra by two months (Pinhey 1984). This correction has sometimes been overlooked (e.g., Legrand 2003). All records of T. nuptialis in western Africa probably pertain to this species.

Trithemis imitata Pinhey, 1961 and T. monardi Ris, 1931 are very similar species, with rather relative differences in markings. Their taxonomy needs to be resolved in a geographic perspective. Most T. imitata and T. monardi records appear to be from north and south of the equator, respectively.
Records from western Africa probably follow confusion with T. grouti. This has been confirmed by V. Clausnitzer for the records from Sierra Leone.
This species is easily confused with T. furva, which appears more common in the east and south but rarer in the west of Africa.
Subpopulations in the northern Kalahari basin that have been formerly identified as T. stictica are now known as a separate species.
This genus was recently revised: Sympetrum navasi is junior synonym to Tritherum navasi (Dijkstra and Pilgrimm 2007).

Egretta gularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) contains the taxon dimorpha, which was previously included within E. garzetta following Kushlan and Hancock (2005). Prior to that, all three taxa were treated as separate species following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

We follow Poynton and Broadley (1987) and Schiøtz and van Daele (2003) in regarding this to be a species distinct from, and sympatric with, Hyperolius nasutus and H. acuticeps, and in this respect we do not follow the taxonomic re-arrangement of this Group proposed by Channing, Moyer and Burger (2002). A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) believes that Channing, Moyer and Burger might have confused H. benguellensis and H. viridis.
This species was removed from synonymy of Hyperolius nasutus (or Hyperolius acuticeps sensu Channing et al. (2002)) by Amiet (2005).
Calidris pugnax (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Philomachus.
This genus has been object of taxonomic changes: Olpogastra fuelleborni is junior synonym to Zygonoides fuelleborni (Dijkstra et al. 2006).

The taxonomy of Zygonyx fallax (Schouteden, 1934) and Z. flavicosta (Sjöstedt, 1900) is problematic, in part because the Z. fallax holotype (MRAC) is a female. Specimens from west Uganda differ slightly from typical Z. flavicosta, most clearly by the relative length of the epiproct, and have traditionally been identified as Z. fallax. Zygonyx fallax is treated as synonym to Z. flavicosta (not yet published).
Zygonyx ikomae is a synonym (Dijkstra unpubl.).
Zygonyx pretentiosus Fraser, 1957 and Z. chrysobaphes umbrosus Fraser, 1957 are possible synonyms.
This is a restricted concept of P. edulis following the split of the broader concept into this and P. angusticeps (Scott et al. 2013).

Phylloscopus bonelli and P. orientalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. bonelli following Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
This is a restricted concept of Phrynobatrachus dendrobates following the revalidation of P. petropedetoides which was previously placed in synonymy with this species.
Genus Lokia is most likely a synonym to Aethiothemis (Dijkstra unpublished).
Ceriagrioni platystigma was removed from synonymy with C. varians by Dijkstra et al. (2015).
Dijkstra et al. (2015) revalidated Gynacantha victoriae as a separate species, removing it from synonymy with G. bullata.
Systematists have long suggested that easternmost populations of this taxon likely correspond to a valid species (D. Blackburn pers. comm. 2012).
This species probably comprises more than one species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.).

A full list of synonyms are available at the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (WCSP 2016). Eragrostis domingensis (Pers.) Steud is an accepted species in some African floras, for example in the Flora of West Tropical Africa (Hutchinson and Dalziel 1972) but is listed as a synonym of E. prolifera in WCSP (2016).

authority: Evans, Carter, Greenbaum, Gvoždík, Kelley, McLaughlin, Pauwels, Portik, Stanley, Tinsley, Tobias, & Blackburn, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Xenopus fraseri prior to its description (Evans et al. 2015).

authority: Evans, Carter, Greenbaum, Gvoždík, Kelley, McLaughlin, Pauwels, Portik, Stanley, Tinsley, Tobias, & Blackburn, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Xenopus fraseri prior to its description (Evans et al. 2015).
Elattoneura tsiamae was previously considered a synonym of Elattoneura vrijdaghi and only recently regained full species status (Dijkstra & Clausnitzer, 2014).
Taylor (2003) has transferred Physella acuta to the genus Haitia Clench & Aguayo, 1932. This affiliation is consequently used by Fauna Europea (Bank et al. 2006).

Classified by Groves (2001) as a subspecies of Perodicticus potto and assessed in 2008 as a subspecies, but genetic studies show it to be a distinct species (Mittermeier et al. 2013, Pozzi et al. 2015). There appears to be significant variation among individuals collected from Cameroon and elsewhere, and it is believed that subspecies of P. edwardsi may be found with further research. One of these may be the smaller form P. faustus, described by Thomas (1910) from the Congo Basin and treated here as a synonym.

Previously, Perodicticus ibeanus was treated by Groves (2001), Grubb et al. (2003), Butynski and De Jong (2007), and Pimley and Bearder (2013) as a subspecies of  Perodicticus potto  and assessed in 2008 as P. p. ibeanus. It is treated here as a species based on new morphological and molecular information (Stump 2005, Oates 2011, Mittermeier 2013). Two subspecies are recognised here: the East African potto Perodicticus ibeanus ibeanus and the Mount Kenya potto P. i. stockleyi (Butynski and De Jong 2007, 2017).

Papio kindae has previously been considered a subspecies of P. cyanocephalus (Grubb et al. 2003; Groves 2001, 2005) and was assessed as such in 2008. It is now recognized as a full species because it is morphologically and genetically distinctive as the five other baboon species (Mittermeier et al. 2013). Preliminary behavioural observations also suggest significance differences compared with P. cyanocepahalus (Mittermeier et al. 2013).

This species was treated in previous Red List assessments (1986 to 2008) under the genus Cercopithecus, but is now placed under Allochrocebus following Mittermeier et al. (2013). The genus name Allochrocebus was first used by Elliot in 1913 and later referred to as a geospecies by Grubb et al. (2003). The species is more terrestrial than any of the Cercopithecus taxa (Tosi et al. 2004, Oates 2011).

Lernould (1988) and Gautier-Hion et al. (1999) considered denti to be a subspecies of wolfi. Grubb et al. (2003) listed the forms denti and wolfi as subspecies of Cercopithecus pogonias (the treatment followed for the 2008 Red List assessments). Kingdon (2015), Groves (2001, 2005), Sarmiento and Kingdon (2013), and Healy (2013) elevated denti to the species level, and this approach is followed here. C. denti is monotypic.

Guschanski et al.’s recent (2013) mitochondrial DNA analysis shows C. denti clustering within a clade representing the C. mona species group, but not most closely related to C. wolfi elegans, as suggested by Sarmiento and Kingdon (2013). In addition, a preliminary Y-DNA phylogenetic analysis suggests C. denti has an evolutionary history distinct from wolfi and elegans, supporting its elevated species status (Detwiler and Hart, unpublished data 2016).

Grubb et al. (2003) treated Cercopithecus wolfi as one of seven subspecies of C. pogonias: pogonias, nigripes, grayi, denti, wolfi, elegans and pyrogaster. The 2008 IUCN Red List followed this taxonomy and assessed C. wolfi as the subspecies C. pogonias wolfi. Gautier-Hion et al. (1999) considered C. wolfi as a distinct species and included denti, elegans and pyrogaster as subspecies of C. wolfi. Groves (2001, 2005), Gautier-Hion (2013), Healy (2013) and Kingdon (2015) treated C. denti and C. wolfi as distinct species with wolfi, elegans and pyrogaster as subspecies of the latter.

In Guschanski et al.’s (2013) phylogenetic study of mitochondrial DNA, wolfi and elegans were most closely related with minimal divergence, and pyrogaster was the sister taxon to the elegans and wolfi clade. Likewise, in a recent phylogenetic study of the Y-chromosome’s TSPY gene (~900 base pair fragment) elegans and wolfi had the same Y-DNA haplotype, suggesting a common, recent ancestry (Leroy 2016). Thus, the genetic evidence supports elegans as a subspecies of wolfi and not a sister taxon to denti, as suggested by Sarmiento and Kingdon (2013).

Recent fieldwork indicates that C. w. elegans forms a cline in pelage coloration, with the palest forms occurring at the southern limits of the range in the forest-savanna ecotone, and the more brightly coloured forms, approaching colouration of the nominate subspecies, to the north and west (Colyn 1988, Niehoff 2016).

The 2016 assessment follows the recent consensus to elevate wolfi to species level and to recognise the three subspecies C. wolfi wolfi, C. w. elegans and C. w. pyrogaster.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Oates 2011, Grubb et al. 2003, Butynski et al. 2013). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Preuss’s Red Colobus was treated as a subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) pennantii by Grubb et al. (2003), but as a distinct species by Kingdon (1997, 2015), Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) and Butynski and Kingdon (2013).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Oates 2011, Grubb et al. 2003). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

This taxon was formerly the nominate subspecies of a wider concept of P. pennantii that also included as subspecies parmentierorum, bouvieri, tholloni, powelli Matschie, nigrimanus Trouessart, lulindicus, langi, foai and semlikiensis (Gautier-Hion et al. 1999). Kingdon (1997), Groves (2001, 2005) and Butynski et al. (2013) considered bouvieri and epieni to be subspecies of pennantii; Grubb et al. (2003) likewise, but also including preussi. Kingdon (2015) considered epieni to be a distinct species but maintained bouvieri as a subspecies of P. pennantii. Piliocolobus pennantii is here treated as a distinct monotypic species following Groves (2007).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Oates 2011, Grubb et al. 2003). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

This taxon was formerly a subspecies of a wider concept of P. pennantii which included as subspecies parmentierorum, bouvieri, tholloni, powelli Matschie, nigrimanus Trouessart, lulindicus, langi, foai and semlikiensis (Gautier-Hion et al. 1999). Kingdon (1997), Groves (2001, 2005) and Butynski et al. (2013) considered bouvieri and epieni to be subspecies of pennantii; Grubb et al. (2003) likewise and also including preussi.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Oates 2011, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Colyn (1991) and Groves (2007) suggested that oustaleti is one of between three (Groves 2007) and five (Colyn 1991) forms contributing to what is commonly regarded as a hybrid population of red colobus that occurs immediately to the south of the range of P. oustaleti and extends to the southern forest – savanna ecotone in eastern DRC, at about 4°S. Groves (2007) referred this intergraded taxon as “ellioti”.

As its synonyms indicate, this population of red colobus monkeys has been classified under a number of different names, sometimes regarded as a species, a subspecies, or just as a local population of a subspecies. In the last edition of the Red List, it was treated as a subspecies of P. rufomitratus, which included the subspecies rufomitratus, semlikiensis, foai, langi, oustaleti, parmentieri, tephrosceles and tholloni. Struhsaker and Grubb (2013) continue to place it as a subspecies of rufomitratus, along with ellioti, foai. langi, lulindicus, parmentieri, tephrosceles and tholloni.

Kingdon (1997), following Colyn (1991), treated oustaleti as the Central African Red Colobus, with parmentieri, foai, langi, lulindicus, ellioti, semlikiensis and tephrosceles as subspecies. Kingdon (2015) maintained the same classification, expect that he placed semilikiensis as a synonym of ellioti.

Gautier-Hion et al.
