(1999) regarded P. oustaleti as a complex of six forms, three west of the Ubangui (P. oustaleti sensu stricto with synonyms umbrinus Matschie, and nigrimanus Trouessart, and an undescribed form from the vicinity of the Lobaye River, a tributary of the lower Ubangui, Central African Republic) and three to the east (shubotzi Matschie, powelli Matschie, and brunneus Lönnberg with synonym multicolor Lorenz). Piliocolobus oustaleti is known to be highly variable in coat colour (Colyn 1993, Struhsaker 2010, Struhsaker and Grubb 2013). Ting (2008) found considerable mitochondrial genetic diversity among populations included within P. oustaleti sensu lato and suggested that either oustaleti might consist of numerous taxa, or that there have been past introgressions of mitochondrial lineages between neighbouring forms.

Grubb et al. (2003) considered oustaleti as a subspecies but did not assign it to species. Its synonyms included brunneus Lönnberg, powelli Matschie, nigrimanus Trouessart, and schubotzi Matschie. 

Groves (2007) treated oustaleti as a monotypic species, but with four “types”: 1) a dark brown type (oustaleti, powelli and, most extreme, umbrinus and schubotzi); 2) a raw sienna type in the Ubangui/Lobaye basins in the Central African Republic (unnamed and possibly the unnamed form mentioned by Gautier-Hion et al. 1999); 3) a brownish-fawn type from the Uele gallery forest region in DRC (brunneus) in the east; and 4) a red type (nigrimanus in the west. Groves (2001) placed oustaleti as a subspecies of foai, but also mentioning the four types as described in his 2007 revision.

For the purpose of this assessment, we follow Groves (2007) in treating this evidently diverse taxon as a single taxonomic entity. However, we recognise that the taxonomic status of this form remains fluid (Struhsaker 2010).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Oates 2011, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Kingdon (1997, 2015), following Colyn (1991), treated oustaleti as the Central African Red Colobus, with parmentieri, foai, langi, lulindicus, ellioti, semlikiensis and tephrosceles as subspecies. Grubb et al. (2003) considered tephrosceles be a subspecies but did not assign it to a species. Considering vocalizations and pelage colour patterns, Grubb et al. (2013) placed tephrosceles as a subspecies of rufomitratus, along with ellioti, foai. langi, lulindicus, parmentieri, oustaleti and tholloni.

Groves (2007) treated tephrosceles as a monotypic species, with gudoviusi Matschie as a junior synonym. For the purpose of this assessment, we follow Groves (2007) in treating tephrosceles as a monotypic species.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Oates 2011, Grubb et al. 2003, Butynski et al. 2013). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Piliocolobus tholloni was treated as a subspecies of Procolobus pennanti [sic] by Gautier-Hion et al. (1999). Grubb et al. (2013) and Struhsaker and Grubb (2013), on the other hand, considered it a subspecies of P. rufomitratus. Groves (2001, 2005, 2007), Groves and Ting (2013) and Kingdon (2015) treated tholloni, as a distinct species.

Formerly considered Triaenops persicus or T. persicus afer. Taxonomic revision by Benda and Vallo (2009) determined that T. afer is a distinct species within its African range from T. persicus, which is restricted to the Middle East and South Asia.
J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.) considers this to be a high-altitude savanna form of Hylarana albolbris, since there is a gradual transition between the two forms, and there are no call differences.
It is possible that animals resembling this species on Mount Manenguba and at Buea on Mount Cameroon belong to as yet undescribed forms (Amiet 1977).

There is a specimen that has been collected in central Democratic Republic of the Congo, which has been assigned to Cardioglossa gratiosa, that possibly belongs to this species (Hirschfeld et al. 2015). However, it is far from this species' type locality (>850 km) and there is currently a lack of genetic data to verify this (Hirschfeld et al. 2015).
This is a split from the broader concept of Cardioglossa nigromaculata (elevated from subspecies level) (Hirschfeld et al. 2015).
Records of Cardioglossa pulchra from Tchabal Mbabo (Amiet 1972) now refer to this species (Herrmann et al. 2004).

authority: Rödel, Burger, Zassi-Boulou, Emmrich, Penner, & Barej, 2015

taxonomicNotes:
Fu and Les (2001) recognise C. muricatum ssp. kossinskyi Chamisso which is probably the source of C. submersum cited from China, although Tzvelev (1996) describes C. kossinskyi as a “Very rare species which was for a long time known only from the type specimen and only in 1977 found again near the village of Tri Protoki. Possibly evolved through hybridization of C. tanaiticum × C. platyacanthum”. Jalas and Suominen (1989) however treat C. kossinskye as a synonym of C. tanaiticum Sapjegin.

The World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (RBG Kew 2010) lists C. submersum as occurring in Florida and the Windward Islands, however this disagrees with the reasoned conclusions reached by Les (1997) and this evaluation follows the latter.

As with other members of the genus, there is a need for taxonomic clarification and this confusion could obscure the actual distribution and status of taxa.

Studies are needed to determine whether or not specimens from Cameroon and Togo belong to the same species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.). It is currently unclear whether there are any Werneria species in Togo, but it has been suggested that if there is one, it could be either W. preussi or alternatively a different, distinct species, Werneria africanus, which would be an endemic species to Togo (see Segniagbeto et al. 2007).

Following Amiet and Dowsett-Lemaire (2000), Leptodactylodon bueanus is here considered a separate species from L. albiventris (as opposed to a subspecies of L. albiventris following Amiet (1987)). Rödel and Pauwels (2003) provisionally assigned records of L. albiventris from Equatorial Guinea (De la Riva 1994) to L. stevarti.
Following Amiet and Dowsett-Lemaire (2000), Leptodactylodon bueanus is here treated as a separate species from L. albiventris (as opposed to a subspecies of L. albiventris following Amiet (1987)).
We follow Rödel and Pauwels (2003) in provisionally assigning records of Leptodactylodon albiventris from Equatorial Guinea (De la Riva 1994) to this newly described species.

authority: Evans, Carter, Tobias, Kelley, Hanner & Tinsley, 2008
taxonomicNotes: This species is considered to be the sister taxon of Xenopus wittei (Evans et al. 2008).

Trionyx triunguis has been considered a single widespread, relatively uniform species for decades, with no subspecies or other taxonomic units recognized or proposed in recent years. Phylogeographic studies of regional variation have demonstrated different, partly conflicting results, but were based on generally limited sets of specimens and genetic markers (Gidis et al., 2011; Guclu et al., 2011, 2015; Shanas et al., 2012). However, there is still uncertainty as to whether Mediterranean and African populations may in fact represent genetically definable separate Management Units (O. Türkozan unpubl. data).
Xenopus calcaratus has been revalidated and removed from synonymy of X. tropicalis (Evans et al. 2015).

authority: Evans, Carter, Greenbaum, Gvoždík, Kelley, McLaughlin, Pauwels, Portik, Stanley, Tinsley, Tobias, & Blackburn, 2015
Evans, Carter, Greenbaum, Gvoždík, Kelley, McLaughlin, Pauwels, Portik, Stanley, Tinsley, Tobias, & Blackburn, 2015
Evans, Carter, Greenbaum, Gvoždík, Kelley, McLaughlin, Pauwels, Portik, Stanley, Tinsley, Tobias, & Blackburn, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of H. muelleri (Evans et al. 2015).

authority: Evans, Carter, Greenbaum, Gvoždík, Kelley, McLaughlin, Pauwels, Portik, Stanley, Tinsley, Tobias, & Blackburn, 2015

taxonomicNotes: Following Taylor (2013) this assessment does not include the subspecies Bdeogale crassicauda omnivora (Sale and Taylor 1970, Wozencraft 1993, Wozencraft 2005), which is now considered a separate species, namely Sokoke Bushy-tailed Moongose (B. omnivora).

This species does not include the Crested Genet (Genetta cristata), which has been considered by some authors to be conspecific (e.g., Coetzee 1977, Wozencraft 1993) but is now considered to represent a distinct species. Five subspecies are recognised, including Lowe's Servaline Genet (G. s. lowei) which is geographically isolated in several Eastern Arc Mountain blocks (Tanzania).

There are no recognized Trichechus senegalensis subspecies and limited genetic information indicates high genetic diversity (Vianna et al. 2006, Keith Diagne 2014). Anecdotal assertions of morphological differences between isolated inland populations and coastal populations persist, but there is no genetic or morphological evidence (Domning and Hayek 1986, Vianna et al. 2006, Keith Diagne 2014).

While Amiet (2012) considers Hyperolius dintelmanni as a synonym of this species which is followed by Frost (2016), we are following Rayna Bell and Stefan Lötters (pers. comm. November 2016) that it should be maintained as a separate species pending further taxonomic study.

The genus Nesolestes may be a synonym of Neurolestes (Gambles 1970). Similar specimens from adjacent Cameroon may pertain to another species (Vick unpubl). The original 2009 Red List assessment included this species in Nesolestes. In 2017, it was moved to genus Neurolestes.

authority: Rödel, Burger, Zassi-Boufou, Emmrich, Penner, & Barej, 2015
taxonomicNotes: There has been some taxonomic confusion between this species and Phrynobatrachus ruthbeateae due to morphological similarities (Rödel et al. 2015).
Coelatura bakeri may sometimes be difficult to distinguish from C. aegyptiaca using morphology, but anatomy of C. bakeri does differ.

Clams of the genus Corbicula Megerle von Mühlfeld, 1811 are native to Africa, Australia, Asia, and the Middle East; however, as invasive species, they are nowadays distributed worldwide (Araujo et al. 1993).

The status of this species around the world has become confused, as the species range has been expanding rapidly, and it has also been interbreeding with other native species throughout the world.

In Japan Okawa et al. (2016) noted androgenetic Corbicula species including C. leana and C. fluminea, show a phenomenon called “egg parasitism” in which the DNA content of spermatozoa is identical to that of somatic cells, but mtDNA is maternal (Houki et al. 2011). Because C. fluminea releases larger amount of sperm than C. leana, a C. leana population could potentially be replaced with a population possessing nuclear DNA of C. fluminea via unilateral hybridization caused by certation (Sonohara 2005). However due to limits of their methodology they could not evaluate the species hybridization between C. fluminea and C. leana.
The taxonomic validity of this species requires review (Gourène and Teugels 1993).

Brycinus imberi is under revision. It is a species complex found from south east Africa up into west Africa, with marked species-level differences between populations over the range of the complex. Scale counts in particular vary considerably over the range of this species complex. Even within Malawi there are recognisable differences between populations in Lake Malawi, Lakes Chilwa and Chiuta and the Lower Shire River.
There are several colour forms over the species' wide range, possibly representing distinct species.
Assessed by our group as Pseudosabicea arborea subsp. bequaertii

The main area of occupancy for this species are the large floodplains (e.g., Okavango Delta and panhandle, Barotse) of the upper Zambezi and Okavango Ecoregions systems. There are several isolated east coast and southern subpopulations of Clarias ngamensis and their taxonomic status requires examination.

Recorded from the Zambian Congo and northern Mozambique. The status of populations outside of the Zambezi needs to be determined. Specimens from the Lower Buzi River have extremely high dorsal fins compared to adjacent Lower Zambezi fishes.

Previously reported as Mormyrops deliciosus (Leach, 1818), a junior synonym of M. anguilloides (see Bigorne, 1987). The taxonomic position of the kenyan population is uncertain: the species might be identical to M. citernii Vinciguerra, 1913 described from the Juba system in Somalia (Seegers et al. 2003).

Taxonomic studies are needed on this species. Specimens from the Mwekera tributary of the Kafue may represent a different species with more lateral line scales (Tweddle et al. 2004).

This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Aplocheilichthys Bleeker, 1863 but is now valid in the genus Micropanchax Myers, 1924.

This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Aplocheilichthys Bleeker, 1863 but is now valid in the genus Micropanchax Myers, 1924. This species is described from Katanga province, Democratic Republic of Congo in the Congo System. It is unlikely that it is the same species throughout the currently recognised range. Taxonomic work is currently underway. The species has a fragmented population and occurs across numerous river systems. Full resolution of taxonomic issues is needed before a meaningful conservation analysis can be made.

Following Grubb (1993, 2005) and d'Huart and Kingdon (2013), three subspecies are provisionally recognized: Hylochoerus. m. ivoriensis, which occurs as isolated populations from Guinea to southern Ghana; H. m. rimator, which ranges from southeast Nigeria to eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo; and the nominate race H. m. meinertzhageni (the true Giant Forest Hog), which occurs as scattered populations from the Albertine Rift Highlands of eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo to the eastern (Gregory) Rift Valley in Ethiopia and Kenya. Groves and Grubb (2011) supported by Gongora et al. (in prep.) reviewed this classification and suggested that a species-level status be assigned to these three subspecies. However, further genetic and morphometric studies are required in order to fully understand the taxonomy of the Forest Hog, particularly because the taxonomic status of the Ethiopian race is still indefinite.

The Bonobo is also known as the Gracile Chimpanzee; formerly it was known as Pygmy Chimpanzee and Dwarf Chimpanzee. Population genetics suggest that Bonobos have a stable population history (Eriksson et al. 2004, Schubert et al. 2013), and that gene flow between populations is constrained by the larger riverine barriers (although Bonobos regularly enter water, they do not swim).

The Caracal has been classified variously with Lynx and Felis in the past, but molecular evidence supports a monophyletic genus. It is closely allied with the African Golden Cat (Caracal aurata) and the Serval (Leptailurus serval), having diverged around 8.5 mya (Janczewski et al. 1995, Johnson and O’Brien 1997, Johnson et al. 2006).

Seven subspecies have been recognised in Africa (Smithers 1975), of which two occur in southern Africa: C. c. damarensis from Namibia, the Northern Cape, southern Botswana and southern and central Angola; and the nominate C. c. caracal from the remainder of the species’ range in southern Africa (Meester et al. 1986). According to Stuart and Stuart (2013), however, these subspecies should best be considered as geographical variants.

While Amiet (2012) considers this species to be a synonym of Hyperolius tuberculatus which is followed by Frost (2016), we are following expert consensus (R. Bell and S. Lötters pers. comm. November 2016) that it should be maintained as a separate species pending further taxonomic study.

Tomooka et al. (2002) recognizes two varieties: var. radiata (the cultivated form) and var. sublobata (Roxb.) Verdcourt (the wild form). In this assessment, only the wild populations, i.e. var. sublobata, will be considered. Vigna radiata (L.) R.Wilczek is a genepool tertiary relative of Adzuki Bean [V. angularis (Willd.) Ohwi & H.Ohashi] and of Cowpea [V. unguiculata (L.) Walp.] (Vincent et al. 2013). The species is also classified in Taxon Group 2 of Black Gram [V. mungo (L.) Hepper], and in Taxon Group 3 of Rice Bean [V. umbellata (Thunb.) Ohwi & H.Ohashi] (Vincent et al. 2013), following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).

According to USDA, ARS, GRIN (2017) Leptospron adenthum (G.Mey.) A.Delgado is the accepted name for this taxon. Vigna adenantha (G.Mey.) Maréchal, Mascherpa & Stainier and Phaseolus adenanthus G.Mey. are listed as synonyms of Leptospron adenthum (G.Mey.) A.Delgado.

Vigna adenantha (G.Mey.) Maréchal, Mascherpa & Stainier is a wild relative (in Taxon Group 4) of Bambara Groundnut, V. subterranea (L.) Verdc., and of Cowpea, V. unguiculata (L). Walp. (Maxted et al. 2004).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

M.-O. Rödel (pers. comm.) considers that populations from Togo westwards belong to Sclerophrys togoensis. M. Tandy (pers comm.) considers that both Sclerophrys camerunensis and s. togoensis might occur sypatrically in West Africa. In this account we follow the former view, and restrict S. camerunensis to Central Africa.

authority: (Barej, Schmitz, Menegon, Hillers, Hinkel, Böhme & Rödel, 2011)
taxonomicNotes:
Formerly considered under the Amietophrynus superciliaris species complex, Amietophrynus channingi has been elevated to full species status (Barej et al. 2011). The biological populations that had been formerly assigned to A. superciliaris in eastern Lower Guinea now correspond to A. channingi (Barej et al. 2011).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Amietophrynus has been synonymised with Sclerophrys, and as a result all species that were previously in the former genus are now known under Sclerophrys (Ohler and Dubois 2016).

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain. It was described as a subspecies of Amietophrynus funereus (Hulselmans 1977), and was considered a distinct species by Joger (1982) and Böhme and Schneider (1987). J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.) considers that it is a junior synonym of Amietophrynus villiersi, an opinion not shared by U. Joger (pers. comm.).

Amietophrynus chudeaui (Chabanaud, 1919), which is known only from inadequate postmetamorphic material (rendering it a nomen dubium) from Mali could belong to this species (Tandy and Feener 1985). The taxon is likely comprised of a complex of species (V. Gvozdik pers.comm. November 2012).
