A proper taxonomic revision of the African Nemobiinae is needed. It is likely that there are many undescribed species occurring in Africa.

Amphilius uranoscopus was described from the Wami River basin in eastern Tanzania and was previously considered to be a widespread and extremely variable species (Skelton 2001). However, a recent taxonomic revision of this species in Kenya and Tanzania resulted in the resurrection of two species, A. grandis and A. krefftii, which were both previously considered to be synonyms of A. uranoscopus, as well as the description of a new species, A. athiensis (Thomson & Page 2010). Occurrence of three distinct species in such a small geographic area which represents only a very small portion of A. uranoscopus’ distribution raises the possibility that this complex may contain many undescribed species across its current wide geographic range in southern Africa, and that none of these actually are A. uranoscopus. For the IUCN Red List, the name A. uranoscopus will be retained for the southern African populations pending results from the ongoing taxonomic investigation of this complex (Chakona et al. in prep).
The taxonomic status of this species needs to be studied when males become available (Otte 1985).

Specimens from the Sahel differ morphologically slightly from those from the Congo. A DNA analysis is thus recommended to clarify the taxonomic status of these subpopulations (H. Devriese pers. comm. 2018).

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies (Laurent 1983, Schiøtz 1971, 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Wieczorek et al. (2000, 2001). It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this superspecies are still far from settled. Members of this superspecies, which consists of a large number of forms that are distributed, generally allopatrically, throughout the tropical African savanna, have a common morphology, voice and ecology, but with widely differing dorsal patterns. Laurent (1983) concluded that the concept of one species best expressed present knowledge, and A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) agrees with this. Wieczorek et al. (2001) carried out an analysis based on mtDNA, and separated the forms that they examined into 10 species. However, they examined only 22 out of 45 recognized "subspecies". The following distinct forms were not treated in the analysis by Wieczorek et al. (2001) and therefore cannot be allocated to any of their 10 species: spatzi, pallidus, pachydermus, destefanii, variabilis, coerulescens, karissimbiensis, francoisi, sheldricki, rubripes, mwanzae, reesi, bitaeniatus, rhodoscelis, nyassae, taeniatus, insignis, alborufus, epheboides, aposematicus and broadleyi. An un-named form from Marsabit in northern Kenya also cannot be allocated within the Wieczorek et al. (2001) arrangement of species. The arrangement currently followed by the Global Amphibian Assessment is provisional, pending a more complete analysis of the relationships within the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies. A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) considers that it would have been preferable for the Global Amphibian Assessment to treat the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies as a single species, because under this arrangement, all the described forms are covered unambiguously. Pickersgill (2007) treated mwanzae, variabilis and bayoni as separate species, but we follow Frost (2007) in including them under H. viridiflavus. 
The name Hyperolius viridiflavus pachydermus was wrongly associated with H. viridiflavus (as a subspecies pachydermus) by Laurent (M. Dehling pers. comm. April 2017).

During the 18th and 19th centuries two species of warthog were recognised: Phacochoerus aethiopicus (Pallas 1766) from the Cape Province of South Africa and Phacochoerus africanus (Gmelin 1788) from West Africa. In the early 20th century, mammalian taxonomists lumped the two species under P. aethiopicus. Palaeontologists, however, continued to recognise two distinct species based on the absence of incisors in P. aethiopicus and differences between the two species in the structure of the third molar. The Cape Warthog (P. aethiopicus aethiopicus) was extinct by the 1870s, but it was not until the rediscovery of the Somali Warthog (P. aethiopicus delamerei) in the horn of Africa (Grubb 2013) that the 20th century confusion over the classification of the two species of warthog was resolved. The history of the classification of warthogs is fully described by Grubb and D’Huart (2010). All southern African forms are referred to P. africanus.

The taxonomic status of Dracaena bueana Engl. is not yet resolved. J. J. Bos, the authority on the genus, had no knowledge of this plant until 1984, when Leeuwenburg brought a specimen from Ghana, which at that time was judged to be be either D. fragrans or D. arborea: they cannot be distinguished when sterile. Eventually it flowered and Bos identified it as D. bueana Engl.  Its reproductive characters are intermediate between the two tree species mentioned above, and it may be of hybrid origin, however, the plant is fertile, and produces fruits.

A collection in 2009 from Republic of the Congo has been identified as this taxon, but this needs to be checked, particularly because of the geographical dis-junction. This record has been excluded from the assessment until the identification has been confirmed.
The African species of Calycobolus were recently revised by Breteler (2013).
Identifications of Gabonese specimens of Ardisia as this taxon are regarded by M. Cheek as dubious, and have been excluded from this assessment.
F. J. Breteler described this remarkable species in 2007 (Breteler 2007).
This taxon was elevated to species level by Raynal (1973), and compared morphologically and biogeographically with Sudano-Zambesian sister species Nemum atracuminatum by Larridon et al. (2008).

Specimens of Psychotria from southern Cameroon, Gabon, Nigeria and Equatorial Guinea have been identified by others as Psychotria njumei Cheek (available via GBIF). However, these need to be checked; until then they have been excluded from this assessment (as suggested by M. Cheek 2017). If they are confirmed this taxon will be downgraded to a lower extinction risk category.
The specimen from Korup National Park (Thomas 3354) identified by Gereau (MO data) as this taxon consists of leaves only, so we treat it with caution, until verified with fertile material.
When sterile, Cola cecidiifolia closely resembles C. flavo-velutina K. Schum. in leaf-blade shape, venation, colour and stipules
Synonym = Cola philipi-jonesii Brenan & Keay pro parte.
Synonym = Cola philipi-jonesii Brenan & Keay pro parte.
The identification of a specimen of Synsepalum from Lopé Forest Reserve in Gabon (Leal 158) as this species is uncertain and it has been excluded from this assessment.

The Mefou specimens were confirmed in their identification by Dr A. Paton at Kew.  In view of the geographical disjunction perhaps the identity of the Cameroon material should be revisited.  The tribe was analysed by Press (1982) in Bull. Brit. Mus. Nat. Hist. 10(1): 71–74 but species limits were not covered.

This taxon is probably closely related to Dovyalis spinosissima Gilg from similar habitat (montane lake margins) in Kivu, Congo (Kinshasa) to Malawi. It differs by the glabrous fruits (not hairy), flowers with 14-21 styles (not 8-12) and much larger flowers.

This species was discovered in 2002 (Afrothismia saingei Franke) and 2006 (Afrothismia gabonensis Dauby & Stévart), respectively. A. gabonensis was put into synonymy with A. saingei in the Flore du Gabon (Maas-van de Kamer and Maas 2010).
Zemagho et al. 2017 place this species of Pseudosabicea into Sabicea, as S. sthenula (N. Hallé) Razafimandimbison, B. Bremer, Liede & S.A. Khan.
Clanga clanga (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Aquila.

Cenchrus trachyphyllus (Pilg.) Morrone is a wild relative of pearl millet C. americanus (L.) Morrone (syn. Pennisetum glaucum (L.) Br.). This species is classified in Taxon Group 4, following the definition of Maxted et al (2006).

Cenchrus unisetus is a wild relative of Pearl Millet C. americanus (L.) Morrone (syn. Pennisetum glaucum (L.) Br.). This species is classified in Taxon Group 4, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).
Ipomoea ochracea (Lindl.) Sweet is a wild relative of sweet potato Ipomoea batatas (L.) Poir. This species is classified in Taxon Group 4, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).

Laccosperma cristalensis has been described in 2016 by Couvreur and Niangadouma (2016).

It closely resembles Laccosperma korupensis by the absence (or near absence) of acanthophylls on the cirrus (extension of the leaf rachis). These are the only two species of African rattans to share this character. However, L. cristalensis is easily distinguished from L. korupensis by having fewer pinnae (5-8 versus 10-18) which are sigmoid versus lanceolate, lacking spines along the margin versus presence of spines along the margin and an ocrea that is 3-5 mm long and truncated versus 7-10 cm long and tapering to a point (Sunderland 2012).
Etheria ellipica populations in Africa can be split into two groups with divergent MT DNA (D. Graf pers. comm). The synonyms here listed only pertain to Madagascar material.

Biomphalaria smithi is considered as a distinct species, confined to Lake Edward (the mention of this species from Lake Chad is probably erroneous). It is analogous to B. choanomphala choanomphala of L Victoria and B. stanleyi of Lake Albert. It does not occur in the Lake Victoria Basin.

The Afrotropical genus Ceratophallus consists of 12 small planorbid snails, most of which are restricted to rift lakes (Brown 1994). The generic position of three of these Ceratophallus species remains uncertain. The highest species diversity is found in the Victoria Basin and Lake Victoria proper. In addition to four species that are endemic to the lake and lake shore, namely C. kisumiensis, C. subtilis, C. concavus and C. crassus, the widespread C. natalensis and C. kigeziensis also occur in the Lake Victoria basin.

The distribution of the Ceratophallus subpopulations that have been identified as C. kigeziensis is highly disjunct which may suggest that the species also occurs in other areas in-between but has been overlooked or that, as is the case of C. natalensis, there is a species complex. 

.

Mandahl-Barth (1968) recognized in the region of the Great Lakes a single widespread Gabbiella species, namely Gabbiella humerosa, which he divided in six subspecies (or geographical races) according to the lake in which they were found , namely Gabbiella humerosa humerosa (L. Victoria), G. h. kyogae (L. Kyoga and Victoria Nile), G. h. alberti (L. Albert), G. h. edwardi ( L. Edward), G. h. kivuensis (L. Kivu and Upper Ruzizi) and G. h. tanganyicensis (marshes and tributaries bordering L. Tanganyika). Since Gabbiella species are easily spread by birds, the genetic difference between these subspecies may be negligible or inversely G. humerosa  may represent a group of cryptic species. Further taxonomic study is needed.

Pila ovata is a widespread afrotropical species, of which several endemic forms have been described from Lake Victoria, based on morphological differences such as size and weight, namely:

  • Pila gordoni (E.A. Smith, 1892)
  • Pila gordoni bukobae (Martens, 1897)
  • Pila ovata var. emini Martens, 1897
  • Pila ovata eleanorae Mandahl-Barth, 1954
  • Pila nyanzae (E.A. Smith, 1892)
Mandah-Barth (1954) and Brown (1994) regarded these forms all belong to the same species, namely Pila ovata (Olivier, 1804). However, the nominate subspecies, P. o. ovata, does not occur in Lake Victoria and, as Mandahl-Barth (1954) states, it is unclear 'whether these (lake) forms are geographical races, ecological forms or perhaps both'.

The unique ecological characteristics of the subpopulations of P. ovata of Lake Victoria  constitute an argument to consider it as a separate race, adapted to lacustrine conditions, namely Pila ovata gordoni. Pila ovata gordoni is smaller in size than the nominate subspecies and as such it is evaluated under a subspecies name.

Biomphalaria stanleyi is considered a distinct species (Plam et al. 2008). It is a broad and high-shelled lacustrine morphotype endemic to Lake Albert, and thus homologous to B. smithi from Lake Edward and B. choanomphala choanomphala from Lake Victoria.
The difference between Gabbiella senaariensis and Gabbiella schweinfurti has not yet been fully elucidated.
Three Tomichia species are recorded in Central Africa, but these are of uncertain generic position (Brown 1994).
Sheppardia polioptera (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cossypha polioptera.
Cecropis abyssinica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hirundo abyssinica.
Arizelocichla masukuensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Andropadus masukuensis.
Lagonosticta rubricata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously split as L. rubricata and L. landanae following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Sheppardia bocagei and S. poensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. bocagei following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993).

Calamonastides gracilirostris and C. bensoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Chloropeta gracilirostris following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Acrocephalus arundinaceus and A. orientalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. arundinaceus following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Spermestes bicolor (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Lonchura and was previously split as L. bicolor and L. nigriceps following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Apalis porphyrolaema and A. kaboboensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. porphyrolaema following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993).
Cecropis daurica and C. hyperythra (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Hirundo daurica (BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group).

Breteler (2014) proposed Cola cauliflora be applied to a different taxon, restricted to southern Cameroon, based on a supposed lectotypification in Flore du Gabon. However a proposal to conserve the name to maintain its traditional application has been submitted.
Robyns (1963) mentions a second variety of this species, var. puberula. This needs further taxonomic investigation.
Peliperdix coqui (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Francolinus.
This species is included in the Hylomyscus denniae species group and is a member of a polytomy that includes H. denniae and H. vulcanorum (Demos et al. 2014a, 2014b, 2015).
Aquila africana (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as A. africanus.
Vidua interjecta and V. orientalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as V. interjecta following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Oriolus oriolus and O. kundoo (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as O. oriolus following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Amaurornis marginalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Aenigmatolimnas.
Caprimulgus vexillarius (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Macrodipteryx.
Ardea intermedia, A. brachyrhyncha and A. plumifera (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously placed in the genus Mesophoyx and lumped as M. intermedia following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Mareca penelope (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Anas.
C. lwiroensis is distinguishable from other members of the genus both externally and cranio-dentally (Kerbis Peterhans et al. 2013).

This species is known only in fruit. The seedlings, foliage and pods are clearly those of Berlinia and molecular evidence confirms the taxon’s position within Berlinia (Mackinder and Peninngton 2011).
When sterile, Berlinia phenacoa can be difficult to distinguish from B. bruneelii, see Mackinder and Peninngton (2011) for detail of the defining characteristics of the species.
Occasionally Berlinia viridicans has been confused with B. craibiana when sterile (Mackinder and Pennington 2011).
Berlinia sapinii is a poorly known species and may be conspecific with B. lundensis, however, Mackinder and Pennington treat it as a separate species in their monograph of the genus (2011).
When sterile, Berlinia tomentella can be confused with B. confusa, see Mackinder and Peninngton (2011) for detail of the defining characteristics of the species.
Some Zambian collections of Berlinia giorgii have been misdetermined as B. craibiana although B. craibiana is not known from Zambia (Mackinder and Peninngton 2011).

Collections of Berlinia bruneelii are often misidentified as B. craibiana and also occasionally as B. giorgii, see Mackinder and Peninngton (2011) for detail of the defining characteristics of the species.
When sterile, Berlinia auriculata has been misidentified as B. congolensis and B. confusa (Mackinder and Pennington 2011).

Collections of Berlinia bruneelii are often misidentified as B. craibiana and also occasionally as B. giorgii, see Mackinder and Peninngton (2011) for detail of the defining characteristics of the species.
When sterile Berlinia auriculata has been misidentified as B. congolensis and B. confusa (Mackinder and Pennington 2011).

Collections of Berlinia occidentalis have been mis-identified as B. bracteosa. Berlinia bracteosa can be distinguished from B. occidentalis in flower through its bracteoles, which are glabrous (hairless) or sparsely puberulous (with few hairs) on the inner surface and at least 52 mm long. In addition no part of their distribution overlaps (Mackinder and Pennington 2011).
Berlinia delevoyi is a poorly known species and may be conspecific with B. sapinii, however, Mackinder and Pennington treat it as a separate species in their monograph of the genus (2011).

This species was previously documented as a subspecies of Cricetomys gambianus however phylogenetic and craniometric results show that C. ansorgei is separate from C. gambianus and even more distantly related to it than expected, forming a monophyletic clade instead with C. emini from the forest zone of Central Africa (Olayemi et al. 2012). This species cannot be distinguished from other Cricetomys species based on morphological characteristics, but is dissimilar on a molecular level (Olayemi et al. 2012)
Prionops caniceps and P. rufiventris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. caniceps following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993).
Prionops caniceps and P. rufiventris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. caniceps following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993).
Dyaphorophyia concreta and D. ansorgei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Platysteira concreta following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Terpsiphone rufocinerea and T. batesi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. rufocinerea following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

The relationship of this species with others in this genus is unknown (Holden and Levine 2009, Holden et al. 2016, Monadjem et al. 2015). The allopatric West African endemic Graphiurus crassicaudatus is currently hypothesised to be its closest relative based upon morphology (Holden and Levine 2009, Holden et al. 2016). The geographic range of G. walterverheyeni may overlap with that of G. lorraineus and/or G. surdus, although neither species has been documented to occur at or even close to the two localities from which G. walterverheyeni is known (Holden and Levine 2009, Holden et al. 2016).
This species is recognised as the second species of the Scutisorex genus (Stanley et al. 2013). Genetic analysis of this species supports a sister relationship with S. somereni (Stanley et al. 2013).
Apalis rufogularis and A. argentea (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. rufogularis following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993).
Apalis cinerea and A. alticola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. cinerea following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993).
Cisticola chubbi and C. discolor (Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]) have been lumped into C. chubbi following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).
Bleda notatus and B. ugandae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as B. notatus following Chappuis and Erard (1993).

Phyllastrephus icterinus and P. lorenzi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. icterinus following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Fishpool and Tobias (2005).
Sylvia abyssinica and S. atriceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Pseudoalcippe abyssinica following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993).
This species was resurrected from synonymy with Amietia angolensis by Channing et al. (2016) and now also includes the name Amietia amieti.
This name was resurrected from synonymy with Amietia angolensis by Channing et al. (2016) and includes A. lubrica.
This species has been split from Hyperolius adspersus (Channing et al. 2013).

This species is part of the C. olivieri complex, which is composed of C. olivieri, C. fulvastra, C. viaria and C. goliath (Jacquet et al. 2015). C. goliath was previously considered a large forest variant of C. olivieri (Heim de Balsac 1970) until it was found to live in sympatry with C. olivieri, within Minkébé Forest in NE Gabon (Goodman et al. 2001) and Monte Alen National Park in Equatorial Guinea (Lasso et al. 1996).

Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Lirrangopotamonautes) lirrangensis lirrangensis. Cumberlidge (1998) referred to this species as Potamonautes lirrangensis.

The name Malawi Blue Crab is used only for the subpopulations of this species found in Lake Malawi, and not for subpopulations from other parts of the range of this species.
Anomalurus derbianus probably represents a complex of several similar species. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of populations currently allocated to this species.
Colomys goslingi possibly represents a complex of several similar species. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of populations currently allocated to this species.

Nowak (1999) considered Congosorex to be a subgenus of Myosorex and that Congosorex polli is therefore valid as Myosorex polli. Rainer Hutterer notes that the status of Congosorex, Myosorex, and Surdisorex as separate genera is confirmed and defined (in litt. 2002).
This species is most likely a species complex (E. van der Straaten pers. comm.). We follow Happold (in press) by including Cricetomys kivuensis in C. emini.

There are at least 14 Dasymys species recognised based on morphological evidence (Monadjem et al. 2015). Mullin et al. (2005) provided a biogeographical framework for 11 of these morphological species, showing that many of the range-restricted endemics were associated with endemic hotspots for other species of mammals. Of relevance to the assessment region, two species have been split from D. incomtus: D. capensis has been elevated to full species status based on cranial morphology and its isolated distribution in the Cape region (Mullin et al. 2004). Similarly, D. robertsii (from northern South Africa) was previously known as D. incomtus but is chromosomally, genetically and morphologically distinct (Mullin et al. 2002, 2004). Finally, D. incomtus now refers only to the population restricted to eastern South Africa (from where the type locality originates), leaving the populations outside of this region without a name and are referred to as D. cf incomtus for now (Monadjem et al. 2015). This genus is in urgent need of a continent-wide review.
According to Mullin 2003, the range is much expanded to inlcude west-central and parts of East Africa but probably a species complex, includes D. longipilosus Eisentraut, 1963.

Previously included under Dendromus melanotis, this species was subsequently recognised as
distinct (Musser & Carleton 2005). However, the taxonomic status of the species within the assessment region, and its relationship to D. melanotis, remain in question. Further molecular work is required to confirm species status (Monadjem et al. 2015).
The West African population present in Benin and Nigeria might represent a distinct species, with further taxonomic studies needed to resolve this question.
Likely represents at least two sympatric species (P. Grubb pers. comm.).
A specimen from Mont du Chaillu, Gabon, probably represents a distinct species (P. Grubb pers. comm.) We follow Happold (in press) in recognizing Funisciurus duchaillui as a valid species.

This is a species complex as populations in the northern parts of the distribution may correspond to a distinct species, namely Grammomys surdaster (Musser & Carleton 1993). The characteristics delineating G. dolichurus from G. cometes and G. ibeanus appear unreliable, especially where these species occur sympatrically (Skinner & Chimimba 2005) and therefore they are easily confused (Happold 2013). However, on average G. dolichurus is smaller (skull length < 31 mm) and does not have a white postauricular patch (present on G. cometes and G. ibeanus). In spite of their close genetic and morphological proximity, G. cometes and G. dolichurus tend toward ecological segregation and behave as distinct biological species (Kryštufek et al. 2008).
We include Grammomys poensis within G. kuru, following Happold (in press).
Will be transferred to family Gliridae.
We follow Holden (2005, 2013) by including Graphiurus olga and G. parvus within G. kelleni.
Will be transferred to family Gliridae.

Taylor et al. (1994) reported that specimens from Mkhuze in KwaZulu-Natal, Simunye in Swaziland and Waterpoort in Limpopo differed morphologically (reduced upper molar, inflated bullae) from other specimens of Graphiurus murinus and from the Stone Dormouse (G. platyops). Similarly, recent evidence reported differences in the morphology of two populations of G. murinus in the Eastern Cape (Kryštufek et al. 2004). Although karyotypes were the same for both populations, they differed from previously recorded karyotypes for this genus in Africa (Kryštufek et al. 2004). Additionally, a high degree of chromosomal diversity has been recorded in this species (Dippenaar et al. 1983; Holden 1993). Taxonomic research and DNA analysis is therefore necessary to carry out a systematic revision of this species complex (Skinner & Chimimba 2005; Holden 2013).
This is almost certainly a complex of several similar species. The form occurring east of the Nile River (multicolor) is likely to be distinct (P. Grubb pers. comm.).
This is probably a complex of several similar species (P. Grubb pers. comm.).
Hybomys univittatus possibly represents a complex of several similar species. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of populations currently allocated to this species.
This may be a species complex. Further taxonomic study is needed.
This is probably a species complex.
Further taxonomic studies are needed to resolve the status of the Lake Kivu taxon, which may be a different species.

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain (see Monadjem 2013). Although previously considered a species complex with Mus musculoides, molecular markers and chromosomal data unambiguously discriminate M. musculoides from Mus minutoides (Veyrunes et al. 2004, 2005). However, they are closely related phylogenetically, i.e., sister species. Phylogeographical surveys using mitochondrial sequences (Cytb) have uncovered four distinctive clades throughout sub-Saharan Africa (but possibly more, see Bryja et al. 2014): West Africa, western Central Africa, East Africa and southern Africa. The latter two clades occur within the assessment region where they can be further subdivided into chromosomal groups. Pygmy Mice from the East African clade have a diploid number of 33 < 2n < 35, while the southern African clade harbours two subclades: one with 2n = 34 and the other 2n = 18. The 2n = 18 subclade is endemic to South Africa (Veyrunes et al. 2004, 2005, 2010, 2014; Kouassi et al. 2008; Mboumba et al. 2011; McDonough et al. 2013; Chevret et al. 2014; Lamb et al. 2014).

The latest published phylogeographical study of Lions shows that the traditional split between Asian and African Lions as distinct subspecies is untenable (Barnett et al. 2014). Based on these results, the Cat Classification Task Force of the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group has provisionally proposed a different split into two subspecies, P. l. leo of Asia and West, Central and North Africa; and P. l. melanochaita from South and East Africa, with several regional management units identified as well (Haas et al. 2005; Bertola et al. 2011, 2015; Bauer et al. 2015).
One specimen, never collected again. Certainly a distinct species. There have been no surveys in the area since the early 1900s.
The form P. b. vulcanorum has been regarded as a separate species by some authorities (e.g., Schouteden 1946).
A taxonomic revision resulted in this species being split into Praomys hartwigi (endemic to Cameroon) and P. obscurus (endemic to Nigeria) (E. van der Straeten pers. comm. 2002).
The identity of Praomys jacksoni is currently unclear as the type collection is of a young animal and the skull is in bad condition (E. van der Straeten pers. comm.).
The forms occurring west and east of the Dahomey Gap may represent separate species (P. Grubb pers. comm.).

The single species, R. suncoides, is known by five specimens from the Ruwenzori region of east-central Zaire and Rwanda. This species formerly was assigned to Sylvisorex, but Hutterer (1986) considered it to represent a distinct genus.
is a valid species (R. Hutterer pers. comm).
No subspecies are currently recognised (Monadjem et al. 2015).

Two subspecies are currently recognized: Mountain or Eastern Bongo (T. e. isaaci) and the Lowland or Western Bongo (T. e. eurycerus), although the validity of these forms has not been confirmed by genetic analysis. Furthermore, the two populations of Lowland Bongo, in West and Central Africa respectively, have been geographically separated for an unknown - but long - period of time. Carrying out a detailed phylogenetic anlysis across the species' entire range is highly desirable. Until then, the three disjunct populations should be treated as separate conservation units.

Numerous subspecies have been recognized, usually based on morphological variation - coat patterns vary greatly across the range. Several recent studies of mitochondrial DNA indicate that there are two divergent lineages, one in the north and west and another in the south and east and that these may represent two distinct species (see Plumptre and Wronski 2013 for details and discussion). The traditional treatment as a single species is followed here provisionally, in line with Plumptre and Wronski (2013), and awaiting results of analysis of nuclear DNA data. There are some isolated populations, such as Menelik's Bushbuck in the Bale Mountains of Ethiopia, which has a very distinctive phenotype.

Mitochondrial DNA (Essop et al. 1997; Gatesy et al. 1997; Matthee & Robinson 1999) and allozyme (Georgiadis et al. 1990) data, as well as evidence of hybridisation between the Common Eland and the Greater Kudu, Tragelaphus strepsiceros (Boulineau 1933; Jorge et al. 1976; Van Gelder 1977a, 1977b), has led to the classification of this species within the genus Tragelaphus rather than Taurotragus (IUCN SSC Antelope Specialist Group 2016). Additionally, Lorenzen et al. (2010) report a significant difference between the mtDNA lineages of Common Eland in East and Southern Africa. Three subspecies of Common Eland have been recognised, though their validity has been in dispute (Thouless 2013):

  • Tragelaphus o. livingstonii (Sclater 1864; Livingstone's Eland): also called kaufmanni, niediecki, selousi and triangularis. It is found in the Central Zambezian Miombo woodlands i.e. south-central Africa (Angola, Zambia, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Zimbabwe, Mozambique and Malawi). Livingstone's Eland has a brown pelt with up to twelve stripes.

  • Tragelaphus o. oryx (Pallas 1766; Cape Eland): also called alces, barbatus, canna and oreas. This subspecies is found south of the Zambezi river (South Africa, Botswana and Namibia). The fur is tawny, and adults lose their stripes.

  • Tragelaphus o. pattersonianus (Lydekker 1906; East African Eland or Patterson's Eland): also called billingae. It is found in east Africa extending into the Somali arid areas, hence its common name. Its coat can have up to 12 stripes.

Tragelaphus o. oryx occurs throughout the larger part of South Africa, but the far northern Limpopo Province bordering Zimbabwe is regarded as a transitional zone between T. o. oryx and T. o. livingstonii or an area where they overlap. This argues the case that they should rather be described as ecotypes (in ecotypes, it is common for continuous, gradual geographic variation to impose analogous phenotypic and/or genetic variation; this situation is called cline.).
Formerly included Crocidura jouvenetae, see notes on these two species in Hutterer (2005).

There are nine subspecies recognised (Heim de Balsac & Meester 1977), of which two occur within the assessment region: C. c. cyanea from northern Namibia to the Western Cape and Free State provinces and Lesotho, and C. c. infumata from parts of the Western and Eastern Cape provinces northwards to KwaZulu-Natal, North West, Gauteng, Limpopo, Mpumalanga provinces, as well as Zimbabwe, northern Botswana and Mozambique. Further research is needed to resolve the taxonomy of this species complex.
Populations formerly allocated to Crocidura hildegardeae from Cameroon through to Nigeria are now attributed to C. virgata.

Four subspecies are listed (Heim de Balsac & Meester 1977), of which two occur in southern Africa: C. c. hirta, found in the wetter eastern areas of the country with annual rainfall over 500 mm, occurring in KwaZulu-Natal, Free State, North West, Mpumalanga and Limpopo provinces, as well as Zimbabwe and Mozambique; while C. h. deserti (the arid variant) occurs in the drier western regions in northern Northern Cape, northern Botswana and north-eastern Namibia (Meester et al. 1986) Further research should resolve the taxonomy of these variants as there may be more than one species across the range
This species was previously included within Crocidura denti. All records east of Rift Valley are allocated to C. denti.
Crocidura luna possibly represents a complex of several similar species. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of populations currently allocated to this species

Meester et al. (1986) recognised two subspecies in southern Africa: C. m. mariquensis occurring in KwaZulu-Natal, northern Free State, North West, Limpopo, Gauteng and Mpumalanga provinces and Mozambique; and C. m. shortridgei, occurring from north-eastern Namibia to northwestern Zimbabwe. Additionally, morphometric data reveal the KwaZulu-Natal population to be distinct from all others (Dippenaar 1979; Taylor 1998). Thus, this species may represent a species complex, but until new research provides further evidence, we retain the species status.
The taxonomy of this species is uncertain and it might be a synonym of Crocidura olivieri (Hutterer 2005).
Crocidura nigrofusca possibly represents a complex of several similar species. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of populations currently allocated to this species.
Crocidura olivieri is the valid name for large African shrews previously known as C. flavescens (now restricted to South Africa) (Hutterer 2005).
Crocidura parvipes possibly represents a complex of four or five similar species. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of populations currently allocated to this species.
This species is closely related to Crocidura fuscomurina and may be found to be conspecific.

Here considered separate from G. hueti, which is a nomen nudum (see Grubb 2004).

Will be transferred to family Gliridae.

Treated by Musser and Carelton (2005) under T. venustus Thomas, 1907. However, they recognise T. major Hatt, 1934 as being a distict species. Clarity is required from Fritz Diterlen on whether or not these two taxa are conspecific?
We follow Happold (2013) in recognizing this as distinct from Funisciurus isabella. Reinstated as a full species by Brugière et al. (2005).

This is a species complex, the specimens from southern Democratic Republic of the Congo and northwestern Angola are probably a new species which is not yet described, while the specimens from north central Angola represent another new species which is currently in press (E. van der Straeten pers. comm.).

This species appeared in the 1996 Red List as a subspecies of Gorilla gorilla. Since 2001, the Eastern Gorilla has been considered a separate species (Gorilla beringei) with two subspecies: Grauer’s Gorilla (Gorilla beringei graueri) and the Mountain Gorilla (Gorilla beringei beringei) following Groves (2001).

Whitehead and Greenwood (1959) synonymised P. degeni Boulenger, 1906 from Lake Victoria, Victoria Nile and Lake Nabugabo with P. catostoma catostoma (Günther, 1866). Kramer et al. (2012) revalidated P. degeni Boulenger, 1906, but only examined the holotype from the Katonga River (Lake Victoria, Uganda). The specimens from Victoria Nile, Lake Nabugabo and Lake Victoria should consequently still be considered as P. catostoma catostoma (D. Geelhand pers. comm. 2014).

The distribution of P. catostoma in southern Africa is now more restricted after the description of five new Petrocephalus species from the region (P. okavangensis, P. magnitrunci, P. magnoculis, P. petersi and P. longicapitis) by Kramer et al. (2012).

Further revision is needed as new collecting has revealed greater diversity than previously recognised. For instance, only one species of Petrocephalus has been listed in the Upper Zambezi River, but there are at least three species, all of which live sympatrically in the Katima Mulilo rapids in Namibia.
Taxonomic research is required to clarify whether the northern (Tanzanian) and southern (Zambian) subpopulations indeed belong to the same species.
Cenchrus ramosus (Hochst.) Morrone is a tertiary wild relative of pearl millet, C. americanus (L.) Morrone (syn. Pennisetum glaucum (L.) Br.) (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).

Also reported as Haplochilichthys pelagicus and Aplocheilichthys pelagicus (antiquated binomina).

The generic name was subsequently disclosed as feminine. Ref. Eschmeyer, W.N. 1998. Catalog of Fishes. California Academy of Sciences Publication, vol. 1: 1-958 (species A-L), vol. 2: 959-1820 (species M-Z), vol. 3: 1821-2805 (genera, species and genera in classification, bibliography). Laciris: Sys/genus as feminine gender. This has meant that the species name has changed from Laciris pelagicus to Laciris pelagica.
Cenchrus purpureum Schumach. belongs to Gene Pool two of Pearl Millet Cenchrus americanus (L.) Morrone [=Pennissetum. glaucum (L.) R.Br.]
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List as Tilapia kottae. It is now valid in the genus Coptodon as Coptodon kottae (Lönnberg 1904).

According to Yang et al. (2015) the valid name for this species is Enteromius kerstenii (Peters 1868). This group needs revision: several populations are currently included in this species. They might represent distinct taxa (Seegers et al. 2003). 

Previous subspecific distinction (B. kerstenii kerstenii and B. kerstenii luhondo Pappenheim & Boulenger, 1914) is not maintained (De Vos and Thys van den Audenaerde 1990). Indeed,  B. luhondo Pappenheim & Boulenger, 1914 and B. kerstenii luhondo are considered junior synonyms of B. neumayeri Fischer, 1884 (De Vos and Thys van den Audenaerde 1990).

According to Yang et al. (2015) the valid name for this species is Enteromius paludinosus (Peters, 1852). The species has a wide distribution throughout eastern and southern Africa, with some differences between populations that may result in some populations being regarded as distinct species in future.

This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Barbus but is now considered valid in the genus Enteromius (Yang et al. 2015).
This is now considered to be a species complex, but until further studies are done it is treated here as a single species.
Fraseria tessmanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Muscicapa tessmanni.
Ptilopachus nahani (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Francolinus.
Cinnyris ursulae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Nectarinia following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Psophocichla litsitsirupa and P. simensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. litsitsirupa following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Melaniparus leucomelas and M. guineensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. leucomelas following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Melaniparus leucomelas and M. guineensis (del Hoyo and Collar   2016) were previously lumped as M. leucomelas following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Eremomela pusilla and E. canescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumedp as E. pusilla following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Apalis cinerea and A. alticola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. cinerea following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993).

Cisticola galactotes, C. luapula, C. haematocephalus, C. lugubris and C. marginatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. galactotes following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Cisticola galactotes, C. luapula, C. haematocephalus, C. lugubris and C. marginatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. galactotes following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Bradypterus baboecala and B. centralis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as B. baboecala following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Bradypterus baboecala and B. centralis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as B. baboecala following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Delichon urbicum and D. lagopodum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. urbicum following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 & supplements), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Dyaphorophyia blissetti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Platysteira blissetti.

Forest Swallow has been reassigned to a new genus, Atronanus, by de Silva et al. (2018) based on a combination of molecular genetic results and distinct morphological characters. The BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group accepts this treatment and recognises Atronanus fuliginosus (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2019). 

Previously, Petrochelidon fuliginosa (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hirundo fuliginosa.
Bocagia minuta (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Tchagra minutus.
Chlorophoneus multicolor (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Telophorus multicolor.
Cecropis semirufa (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hirundo semirufa.
Chlorophoneus nigrifrons (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Telophorus nigrifrons.
Dicrurus adsimilis and D. modestus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. adsimilis following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Geokichla guttata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Zoothera guttata.
Phedinopsis brazzae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Phedina brazzae.

Phyllastrephus icterinus (HBW and BirdLife International 2017) was previously split as P. icterinus and P. leucolepis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016), but P. leucolepis is now considered a junior synonym of P. icterinus. This follows analysis by Collinson et al. (2017) who showed that leucolepis falls within the range of intraspecific genetic variation observed in icterinus and most likely represents a plumage variant of it.

Phyllastrephus icterinus (HBW and BirdLife International 2017) and P. lorenzi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. icterinus following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Fishpool (2005).

Poicephalus robustus and P. fuscicollis (HBW and BirdLife International 2017) were previously lumped as P. robustus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014), but have been split following work by Collar and Fishpool (2017) who showed that the form robustus reached species rank under the Tobias criteria on morphological scoring alone, with the difference augmented by voice (7+3 = 10). The newly-defined P. robustus is monotypic, while P. fuscicollis is polytypic, including the races fuscicollis and suahelicus.
Buteo buteo, B. japonicus and B. refectus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as B. buteo following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Onychognathus morio and O. neumanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as O. morio following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Ploceus nigricollis and P. brachypterus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. nigricollis following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Ploceus nigricollis and P. brachypterus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. nigricollis following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Anaplectes rubriceps, A. leuconotos and A. jubaensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. rubriceps following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Merops orientalis, M. viridissimus and M. cyanophrys (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as M. orientalis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Clams of the genus Corbicula Megerle von Mühlfeld, 1811 are native to Africa, Australia, Asia, and the Middle East; however, as invasive species, they are nowadays distributed worldwide (Araujo et al. 1993).
 
In the past the African species was treated as a susbpecies of Corbicula fluminea, and past accounts were treated under this taxonomic name. Kornuishin (2004) suggests that the smaller shell form and anatomical differences could be used to distinguish this taxa from Corbicula fluminea.

There have been papers suggesting this species has also been interbreeding with other native species throughout the world.

Mandahl-Barth (1888) and Daget (1998) distinguish six recent geographical forms of Chambardia walhlbergi while Graf and Cummings (2017) only retain four modern subspecies, considering C. bourguignati and C. welwitschii not as subspecies of C. wahlbergi but as distinct species. The opinion of Graf and Cummings is here followed, and the four C. wahlbergi subspecies are: C. w. guillaini; C. w. hartmanni; C. w. wahlbergi; and C. w. tabula.
The whole genus Eupera needs to be revised.
This species is difficult to identify to species level, and therefore there are doubts over the validity of some the Pisidium species reported from the southern African region.

This species might belong to a cryptic species complex and taxonomic revision is needed. Schultheiß et al.(2009) suggest that the population of Lanistes ellipticus in the Malawi rift is actually a morphologically similar but endemic species that has an indistinguishable shell morph due to parallel evolution in shell morphology. A molecular based taxonomic revision of this genus is needed to resolve these issues.

The question if the species Lymnaea natalensis should be placed in the genus Lymnaea or in the genus Radix, formerly considered a subgenus of the first, remained unresolved for a long time (Bargues et al. 2001). Thus for example Brown (1994) and Appleton (1996) refer to Lymnaea natalensis, but the molecular study of Correa et al. (2010) provides definite arguments for the use of Radix natalensis. This species appeared on the IUCN Red List as Lymnaea natalensis until 2016.

The identification of large Radix specimens from the Arabian Peninsula as Lymnaea (Radix) natalensis remains doubtful. It may be that this is a separate species, i.e. Lymnaea (Radix) arabica Smith, 1894 (E. Neubert pers. comm. 2012).

Lymnaea mauritiana Morelet, 1875 is in recent literature also considered as a synonym of Radix natalensis.
The genus name Afrogyrus is occupied (Coleoptera, Gyrinidae) and altered in Africanogyrus (Özdikmen and Darilmaz 2007).
The B. forskalii group is one of the four groups in which the representatives of the genus Bulinus are subdivided. In Madagascar the species was known under the name B. mariei.

This Red List assessment is of the Bulinus globosus/ugandae complex, named here as Bulinus globosus. Bulinus globosus and B. ugandae were formerly recognised as distinct on the basis of morphological characteristics. However, they have been shown by means of genetic analysis to genetically overlap and hence may cross-breed. Therefore, here they are assessed as a complex.

This Red List assessment is of the Bulinus truncatus complex including the species B. truncatus, B. tropicus, B. transversalis, B. natalensis and B. trigonus. It is named Bulinus truncatus on the Red List as this is the oldest name. The difficulty to genetically separate the former Bulinus species within this group from each other has led to the use of species-complexes in the Bulinus taxonomy.

There is some confusion about the taxonomy of Gyraulus costulatus , but considered as a separate species (Van Damme pers. comm.). However has been synonymised with G. ehrenbergi and Armiger crista, but this is not correct, as these species have different distributions and morphologies.
The Afrotropical genus Lentorbis consists of three species only. The taxonomical differentiation is mainly based on anatomical characteristics.
The Afrotropical genus Segmentorbis consists of five species, which conchyologically can rather easily be distinguished from other planorbid genera.

The species name is sometimes spelled Melanoides tuberculatus (see Madhyastha 2012), but this is incorrect because Melanoides Olivier, 1804 was clearly intended to be feminine as it was combined with the feminine specific epithet fasciolata in the original description.

The species Bellamya capillata, as presently defined on conchyological, anatomical and embryological characters, is clearly polyphyletic in genetic trees. The large genetic diversity  in 'B. capillata' specimens from for example Malawi, Zambia and Zimbabwe suggests that they constitute three different species (Sengupta et al. 2009). A  taxonomic revision of the African representatives of the genus Bellamya is therefore needed (see Schultheiß et al. 2011 for a discussion).

The taxonomy of the genus Caldesia is far from clear and this may obscure the conservation requirements of some taxa. Most African authors have recognized Caldesia reniformis as a independent species but on a world-wide scale it seems to merge with Caldesia parnassiifolia var major (Micheli) Buchenau.
In the Flora of tropical East Africa treated as a synonym of L. perpusilla, but now generally accepted as a species in its own right.

There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name. However, there is a degree of confusion over separation of L. gibba from L. minor when the former is not expanded and this may obscure differences in the distribution of the two species.
There are three subordinate taxa of Azolla pinnata depending on the range of occurrence. Azolla pinnata africana is found Africa, A pinnata asiatica in Asia and A pinnata pinnata in Oceania.

Ceratophyllum is a complicated genus with a range of taxa named but inconsistently recognized. Cook (1970) states that the genus includes four polymorphic species, but in parts of Europe some of the morphological variants are recognised as species or at a subordinate level. Whilst at least in the west, C. demersum s.s. is so widespread and abundant that it is unlikely that taxonomic issues will affect its conservation or Red List assessment, inconsistent recording within the C. demersum complex is likely to affect the Red List assessments of any subordinate taxa assessed.

A polymorphic species that should repay more detailed study in the field. The habit varies considerably with environment - plants growing in water are very much larger than those growing out of water. Material from northern Ethiopia was separated from C. granvikii as C. hedbergii (Wickens and Bywater 1980) on the basis of having shorter, stouter pedicels and follicles with up to 7 seeds in contrast to the slender pedicels and 1-2 seeded follicles of East African plants. The collections now available from Ethiopia show that both forms occur and that there does not seem to be any discontinuity between them (Gilbert 1989).

This species appeared on the IUCN Red List until 2016 as Carex conferta var. lycurus. It is now considered valid as Carex lycurus. An updated Red List assessment has been created to reflect this change.

The e-Monocot website states this is a nomen illegitimum and a synonym of Cyperus exaltatus var. exaltatus. As the African Plant Database still upholds the species (as do the African Floras) this assessment follows the African tradition.

A perennial herb, briefly rhizomatuous giving very long stolon with erect stems numerous tight ; 30-120 cm high, 0,6- 2 mm thick ; Leaves reduced, inflorescence is a glomerule of 3-20 spikelets sessile.
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Pycreus but is now considered valid in the genus Cyperus.
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Pycreus but is now considered valid in the genus Cyperus.
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Pycreus but is now considered valid in the genus Cyperus.
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Pycreus but is now considered valid in the genus Cyperus.
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Pycreus but is now considered valid in the genus Cyperus.
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Pycreus but is now considered valid in the genus Cyperus.
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Pycreus but is now considered valid in the genus Cyperus.
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Pycreus but is now considered valid in the genus Cyperus.
A forma apetala (Wingfield) K.Lye is recognized which occurs in coastal Tanzania.
In northern Africa the synonym Scirpus inclinatus (Delile) Asch. & Schweinf. is frequently used.
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List with the incorrect spelling of Scleria griegifolia but is valid with the spelling Scleria greigiifolia.

This species is incorrectly listed as a synonym of Scleria pulchella by WCSP (2018). Scleria pulchella is known only from Angola, whereas Scleria suaveolens is relatively widespread in Sub-Saharan African (Bauters et al. 2018).

Equisetum ramosissimum was previously erroneously treated as a synonym of the Neotropical species E. giganteum, due to confusion of the specimens. However E. ramosissimum is a separate species (Christenhusz and Raab-Straube 2013) found in the Old World.
Numerous subspecies have been described within this species (Triest 1988) but these are not consistently recognised.

The taxonomy of Vallisneria is not yet satisfactorily clarified and there is confusion over the true distribution of some species, which is further confounded by establishment of populations of various taxa derived from horticulture.

This species, confined to the African continent, is very closely allied to J. fontanesii Laharpe from the Mediterranean region, a smaller, more slender plant with fewer flowers in its capitula and long-beaked capsules. Some tropical African specimens of J. oxycarpus, notably from Kenya, Ethiopia and Eritrea, differ from the majority of South African specimens by having slightly larger flowers. This form was described as subsp. sparganioïdes by Weimarck. However, the extensive material examined from the countries cited above shows the existence of a complete range of intermediate forms, so the subspecies is here reduced to synonymy.

This is a very wide ranging and variable species that has similar morphological characteristics to closely related Elaphoglossum species, such as E. erinaceum, so some records may be misidentified. With additional study some populations with unique characteristics may also be described as distinct species, for example in Madagascar and South America in Argentina, Bolivia and southern Brazil (de Matos 2015). Until new information becomes available, these populations are assessed under E. hybridum.

Marsilea minuta is quite close to M. quadrifolia, and in fact specimens of Marsilea from China seem intermediate between the two species in sporocarp size and peduncle attachment. Study of a wide range of Old World material of Marsilea would be required, however, to resolve the question of whether M. quadrifolia and M. minuta represent distinct species (Johnson 1986).
Verdcourt (1989) accepts five varieties for East Africa, and states that the Indian plants of this species belong to a different variety.

UAE Taxonomic Notes
The species is placed in genus Diplachne by Plants of the World online as Diplachne fusca (L.) P. Beauv. ex Roem. & Schult.

P. pusillus is a taxonomically difficult species. Difficulties of identification (particularly in the field) mean that distribution data are likely to include records that refer to the concept of P. berchtoldii employed here, as well as records of P. pusillus.

Wiegleb and Kaplan (1998) included P. berchtoldii within their concept of P. pusillus, although they have since accepted the separation of these two taxa. They state that "P. pusillus is regarded [..] as a highly polymorphic species with numerous regional forms and ecomorphoses. More detailed classification seems to be impossible because of the highly reticular variation. No correlated set of characters which would make discrimination of taxa possible have been confirmed". They also state that "Some of the plants called P. groenlandicus show certain characters deviant from the present concept of P. pusillus. They are characterized especially by the leaves with up 8 additional sclerenchymatous strands. These plants are known only from a geographically limited area in Western Greenland. Further research, such as experimental cultivation, is necessary in order to clarify its status."

The Flora of North America recognises three subspecies (Haynes and Barre-Hellquist 2000), while the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2010) recognises only one at a global level.

Two hybrid combinations have been reported involving P. pusillus; P. perfoliatus × P. pusillus (P. × mysticus Morong) and P. pusillus × P. trichoides (P. × grovesii Dandy et G. Taylor), both are extremely rare and unlikely to affect either the survival of the species or this evaluation.
Potamogeton schweinfurthii is closely related to P. lucens and P. illinoensis.

UAE Taxonomic Notes
Numerous synonyms have been described for this widespread species.

Potamogeton richardii has often been confused with P. nodosus. It may be distinguished from this species by its submerged leaves promptly decaying, by its floating leaves with often discoloured petiole at the junction with the lamina and lamina mostly rounded at base, by its mature spikes more densely fructified and by its larger fruits (3.2– 5.5 ≈ 2.1– 3.3 mm in P. richardii, 2.7– 4 ≈ 1.7– 2.7 mm in P. nodosus). The best diagnostic characters reside in the stem anatomy: P. richardii has endodermis cells with U-thickenings, interlacunar bundles are present; in P. nodosus, the endodermis cells have O-thickenings and there are no interlacunar bundles.

There is some uncertainty over the taxonomy and distribution of Ceratopteris thalictroides and C. cornuta. Verdcourt (1999) includes the two as a single taxon, with justification. Al Khulaidi (in prep.) lists only C. cornuta from Yemen, while Hassler and Schmidt (2011) list them as separate species, with C. thalictroides absent from the Arabian Peninsula and C. cornuta occurring in Oman and Yemen (including Socotra), as does The Plant List. For now, the two taxa are assessed separately for the IUCN Red List.

The taxonomy of the genus Trapa appears to be complex. The distribution of T. natans sensu stricto is obscured by variation in the degree to which other taxa are recognised. It is likely that the information employed here will include information on other taxa and will therefore present a more positive idea of the status of the species than is actually the case.
Type Specimen: Halle N. & Le Thomas A. 206, Gabon (holo - Paris).
Type specimen: Bos 3592, Cameroon (holo - WAG; iso - K, P, YA).
Type specimen: Le Testu 6536, Gabon (holo - Paris).
Type specimen: Ledermann 1173, Cameroon (lecto -B; iso - U).

This has been treated at times as a monospecific genus or a number of different species within the genus. It is extremely variable and many subordinate taxa have been described (e.g. TROPICOS lists 199 synonyms for this name). TROPICOS lists this taxon as P. communis Trin. by which name it was formerly known in the UK.


There is a degree of uncertainty over the taxonomic status of this species, some authorities consider that there is only species worldwide (e.g. T.A. Cope pers. comm.), however, a number of taxa are generally recognized (e.g. The Plant List). As a consequence of this uncertainty, it is very difficult to establish the true distribution of the various taxa. This assessment uses a combination of the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families and the Invasive Species Compendium (CABI International) to derive a country list, however, it is not certain that this list is comprehensive.

The two populations in Zambezi and East Africa are different according to molecular studies but the shells are the same. Schultheiß et al.(2009) suggest that the population of Lanistes ellipticus in the Malawi rift is actually a morphologically similar but endemic species that has an indistinguishable shell morph due to parallel evolution in shell morphology. A molecular based taxonomic revision of this genus is needed to resolve these issues.

Included in Manis by several authors (with Smutsia sometimes considered a subgenus) and referred to Phataginus by Grubb et al. (1998), but here included in the genus Smutsia, along with Temminck's Pangolin, S. temminckii, following Gaudin et al. (2009).

Included in Manis by most authors (with Smutsia usually considered a subgenus) and referred to Phataginus by Grubb et al. (1998), but here included in the genus Smutsia, along with the Giant Pangolin (S. gigantea) following Gaudin et al. (2009). The preferred common name (as accepted by the African Pangolin Working Group and the IUCN Species Survival Commission Pangolin Specialist Group) is Temminck’s Pangolin. No subspecies are recognised.

Included in the genus Manis by some authors (with Uromanis usually considered a subgenus) and referred to as Uromanis by McKenna and Bell (1997). The most recent review of the family Pholidota was done by Gaudin et al. (2009), who proposed treating the genus Uromanis as a junior synonym of Phataginus. and this has been supported by subsequent genetic evidence (du Toit et al., 2017; Gaubert et al., 2017; Hassanin et al., 2015).

Included in Manis by many authors (with Phataginus sometimes considered a subgenus), but here placed in the genus Phataginus following Gaudin et al. (2009). Meester and Setzer (1972) recognized two distinct subspecies, Manis t. tricuspis and M. t. mabirae (Uganda), with the latter considered distinct. No subspecies are considered here in line with Kingdon and Hoffmann (2013).
Dioscorea minutiflora Engl. is a secondary wild relative of the Guinea yams, D. rotundata Poir. and D. cayenensis Lam. (Omosowon 2018, Magwé-Tindo 2018).

Dioscorea baya De Wild. is a primary wild relative of the Guinea yams, D. rotundata Poir. and D. cayenensis Lam. (Magwé-Tindo et al. 2018, Omosowon 2018). It has two varieties: D. baya var. kimpundi De Wild. and D. baya var. subcordata De Wild.

Dioscorea claessensii De Wild. is a wild relative of the guinea yams, D. rotundata Poir. and D. cayenensis Lam., under Taxon Group 2, according to the taxon group definition by Maxted et al. (2006). Further research into the species phylogeny is required to better establish its taxonomic positioning within the Enantiophyllum clade.

Dioscorea hirtiflora Benth. is a secondary wild relative of the Guinea yams, D. rotundata Poir. and D. cayenensis Lam. (Magwé-Tindo 2018, Omosowon 2018). It has three accepted subspecies: D. hirtiflora subsp. hirtiflora; D. hirtiflora subsp. orientalis Milne-Redh. and D. hirtiflora subsp. pedicellata Milne-Redh (POWO 2019, WCSP 2019).

Dioscorea pynaertii De Wild. is a wild relative of the guinea yams, D. rotundata Poir. and D. cayenensis Lam., under Taxon Group 2, according to the taxon group definition by Maxted et al. (2006). It is considered to be very similar morphologically to D. minutiflora Engl. (Burkill 1939). Further research into the species phylogeny is required to better establish its taxonomic positioning within the Enantiophyllum clade.

Dioscorea semperflorens Uline is a wild relative of the guinea yams, D. rotundata Poir. and D. cayenensis Lam., under Taxon Group 2, according to the taxon group definition by Maxted et al. (2006). Further research into the species phylogeny is required to better establish its taxonomic positioning within the Enantiophyllum clade.

Two subspecies, including the nominate Otomops martiensseni martiensseni and O. m. icarus (from South Africa, Zimbabwe and Angola) were recognised by Meester et al. (1986). However, recent ecological, morphometric and molecular data indicate that there is ongoing gene flow between widely scattered populations across locations of southern, western and eastern Africa (Lamb et al. 2006, 2008; Richards et al. 2012; Ralph et al. 2015). In light of a newly described northeastern species, O. harrisoni, the distribution of O. martiensseni in sub-Saharan Africa has been revised to exclude the Arabian Peninsula, Djibouti, Eritrea, Ethiopia, and Kenya (Ralph et al. 2015). Although previously included within O. martiensseni (Simmons 2005), populations from Madagascar are now considered a distinct species (O. madagascariensis) following genetic and morphometric studies (Dorst 1953; Lamb et al. 2008; Richards et al. 2012; Ralph et al. 2015).

The Sousa teuszii holotype (a skull) was recovered in the “Bucht des Kameruner Kriegsshiffhafens,” (“Bay of Warships” or ‘Man O’War Bay’), in Cameroon by the German agronomist Eduard Tëusz. The German zoologist Willy Kükenthal examined it at Jena and described it as the new species Sotalia teuszii in honour of its discoverer (Kükenthal 1891, Kükenthal 1892, Van Beneden 1892, Ayissi et al. 2014). The species was originally placed in the genus Sotalia; the genus name Sousa came into general use only in the 1960s (Fraser and Purves 1960, Fraser 1966). Thorough reviews of the species taxonomy are provided by Van Waerebeek et al. (2004) and Jefferson and Rosenbaum (2014). Photographs of the holotype are provided by Kükenthal (Table 21, Kükenthal 1892), Pilleri and Gihr (1972) and Jefferson and Van Waerebeek (2004). Illustrations of the holotype were provided by Van Beneden (1892). The holotype is now held by the British Museum (catalogue number 1893.8.1.1).

The collection details for the holotype are unclear but were of consequence. The dolphin skull and a shark-mauled carcass of a West African manatee were apparently recovered by Tëusz following a heavy rain storm and were subsequently confused (Van Waerebeek et al. 2004). The stomach of the manatee contained vegetable matter, leading Kükenthal to hypothesize that the species was perhaps riparian and vegetarian, an impression reinforced by the dolphin’s rounded (worn) teeth. The Belgian zoologist Pierre Joseph Van Beneden (with whom Kükenthal corresponded) compounded the misunderstanding in a separate publication (Kükenthal 1891, Kükenthal 1892, Van Beneden 1892, Van Waerebeek et al. 2004). Necropsies of fresh animals in the 1950s confirmed that they were piscivorous and marine (Cadenat 1956, Cadenat and Paraiso 1957).

Recent genetic and morphometric work has served to clarify the taxonomy of the genus Sousa (Jefferson and Rosenbaum 2014, Jefferson and Van Waerebeek 2004, Mendez et al. 2013). The available data indicate that there is “strong and significant genetic and morphologic differentiation between S. teuszii and all other sampling units…with no evidence of exchange or contact” (Mendez et al. 2013). Principal components analysis demonstrated that S. teuszii have significantly shorter rostra, wider skulls and lower tooth counts (an average of about 30 teeth per row vs. about 33-37 for other species) when compared with Southeast African, Arabian/Persian Gulf and Indian Sousa specimens (Jefferson and Rosenbaum 2014, Jefferson and Van Waerebeek 2004). There are no shared mtDNA haplotypes with other species in the genus, but a phylogenetic assessment of combined nuclear and mtDNA datasets indicates that S. teuszii is most closely related to Indian Ocean Humpback Dolphins (Sousa plumbea) from South East Africa (Mendez et al. 2013). The most plausible mechanism for their isolation is the Benguela upwelling system, an area dominated by cold upwelling that is located within the ~2,000 km distribution gap between S. teuszii and S. plumbea (Jefferson and Van Waerebeek 2004, Mendez et al. 2013).

Recent systematic revisions and species descriptions have drastically changed the status of H. denniae since its last assessment. Carleton and Stanley (2005) split H. denniae into three separate species: H. denniae, H. anselli and H. arcimontensis, Subsequent molecular phylogenetic and morphological analyses of the Hylomyscus denniae species complex, have revealed additional new species within the complex, with 7 species now recognised from the H. denniae and H. anselli species groups within the H. denniae species complex (Carleton and Stanley 2005; Carleton et al. 2006; Demos et al. 2014a, 2014b, Carleton et al. 2015). The H. denniae group is distributed in East Central African mountains while the H. anselli group is distributed across more southern mountains. This species is part of the H. denniae group, along with H. endorobae and H. vulcanorum both formerly described as H. denniae (Carleton et al. 2006, Demos et al. 2014b, 2015).
Nicolas et al. (2008) reviewed the taxonomy of H. stella, resulting in this species being split into H. stella and H. walterverheyeni.
This is a very variable species which is most likely to be confused with Aframomum albiflorum, at least in the herbarium (Harris and Wortley 2018).
The name was first published as “Aframomum makandensis,” but this has been corrected to “A. makendense” to reflect the neuter gender of the genus (Harris and Wortley 2018).
The authority for the species is K.Schum. not (Roscoe) K.Schum. as indicated in Haris and Wortley (2018) because the name Amomum melegueta Roscoe was not validly published (M. Newman pers. comm.).

According to the molecular (DNA) data of Maurin et al. (2007) and Davis et al. (2011), this species is closely related to Coffea canephora. There have been some taxonomic issues with this species, with a collection (not from Cameroon) erroneously identified as C. heterocalyx, which was found to be (Maurin et al. 2007) the hybrid C. eugenioides × C. liberica var. dewevrei.

The taxonomic status of the Lake Victoria subpopulations is uncertain. Lates was introduced to Lake Victoria in the late 1950s and early 1960s (Coulter et al. 1986) from the shallow waters of Lake Albert and Lake Turkana (Gee 1969). Although not necessarily conspecific with L. niloticus, the Lake Victoria Lates have always been referred to as L. niloticus.

Otus senegalensis, O. feae, O. pamelae and O. socotranus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as O. senegalensis. Before then, O. senegalensis, plus O. scops, O. sunia and O. alius (the latter three sensu del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were split following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993), AOU (1998) and Rasmussen (1998). Prior to that, all these taxa had been lumped as O. scops following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
It must be noted that Enteromius trimaculatus formerly belonged to the genus Barbus, but following the work of Yang et al. (2015) it has been changed to Enteromius (Skelton 2016).
Identification of collections from the upper Koto River drainage (Ubangi tributary, middle Congo River basin) in Central Africa Republic needs confirmation (Anonymous, 2002)

The synonymy of Barbus baudoni ubangensis is tentatively accepted here, but needs further investigation. Yang et al. (2015) placed B. baudoni into Enteromius.
Paugy, et al., 2003 also recognises the fish as Barbus baudoni and shows its ditribution in West Africa
Yang et al. (2015) placed Barbus camptacanthus in Enteromius.

The genus Barbus (Cyprinidae) is restricted to a small number of species mainly inhabiting the European ichthyographic region including Northeast Africa. Most of the African species that are currently included in the genus taxonomically do not appear to be closely related to the genus Barbus sensu strictu. Seegers et al. (2003) follow Berrebi et al. (1996) and use the term ‘Barbus’ for the cyprinid fish species which were previously considered as Barbus.
According to Yang et al. (2015) the valid name for this species is Enteromius apleurogramma (Boulenger 1911). 

Barbus amboseli Banister, 1980, a junior synonym of B. apleurogramma (De Vos and Seegers, work in progress), was listed with a query from the Tana River by Skelton (1994). As currently known, this species does not occur in the Tana River system (Seegers et al. 2003).
Yang et al. (2015) placed Barbus chlorotaenia in Enteromius.
Yang et al. (2015) placed Barbus citrinus in Enteromius.
Yang et al. (2015) placed Barbus clauseni in Enteromius.

The genus Barbus (Cyprinidae) is restricted to a small number of species mainly inhabiting the European ichthyographic region including Northeast Africa. Most of the African species that are currently included in the genus taxonomically do not appear to be closely related to the genus Barbus sensu strictu. Seegers et al. (2003) follow Berrebi et al. (1996) and use the term ‘Barbus’ for the cyprinid fish species which were previously considered as Barbus.

According to Yang et al. (2015) the valid name for this species is Enteromius neumayeri (Fischer 1884). The E. neumayeri group needs revision (Seegers et al. 2003).
Barbus mattozi is used as a restricted name. According to R. Bills (pers. comm.) the population from the Limpopo is considered Barbus rapax. Yang et al. (2015) placed Barbus mattozi in Enteromius.

The genus Barbus (Cyprinidae) is restricted to a small number of species mainly inhabiting the European ichthyographic region including Northeast Africa. Most of the African species which are currently included in the genus, taxonomically do not appear to be closely related to the genus Barbus sensu strictu. Yang et al. (2015) placed Barbus haasianus in Enteromius.
Yang et al. (2015) placed Barbus multilineatus in Enteromius.
Yang et al. (2015) placed Barbus kessleri in Enteromius.

Yang et al. (2015) placed Barbus miolepis in Enteromius. The taxonomy of the E. eutaenia/E. miolepis group needs revision. The name B. miolepis is used here for the relatively large species with a zigzag midlateral stripe, found in the upper reaches of several Upper Zambezi tributaries.
Yang et al. (2015) placed Barbus fasciolatus in Enteromius.
Yang et al. (2015) placed Barbus macrops in Enteromius.
Yang et al. (2015) placed Barbus lujae in Enteromius.
Armbruster et al. (2015) placed Barbus holotaenia in Enteromius.
Yang et al. (2015) placed Barbus leonensis in Enteromius.
Yang et al. (2015) placed Barbus nigeriensis in Enteromius.
The southern population, in the Limpopo system in South Africa, is now considered to be a separate species. Yang et al. (2015) placed Barbus neefi in Enteromius.
